TITLE.XREF: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 16 June.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2) as a whole and Democrat amendments Nos 5 and 10. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I moved, and it was accepted, that Democrat amendments Nos 5 and 10 be considered jointly. Subsequent to that movement, I had a discussion with the government in which they indicated their agreement with some of my propositions and their concerns about others.

SPEECH.PARA: Consequent to that discussion, I have agreed to withdraw amendments Nos 5 and 10, with the approval of the committee, and to substitute further amendments, again with the approval of the committee, for those. That final approval occurred only about 20 minutes or half an hour ago, so I apologise to the members on the cross-party benches. I am hopeful that those amendments are now available from the tabling office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the amendments, I regret to say, thus I am unable to form an opinion. I did have some reservations, however, about the original amendments being moved by the Australian Democrats and it may well be, one hopes, that my reservations are encompassed in the new changes. But I am at a loss until I see the actual words being proposed.

—The new amendments I am proposing are very short so, with the forbearance of Senator Cook and Senator Margetts, if they do not mind listening to them or just writing them down briefly, I can do it on that basis.
—I would like to see them in writing. They will need to be provided to the committee in writing and signed, as is provided for under standing orders.
—First of all, Senator Murray, are you seeking leave to have Democrat amendments Nos 5 and 10 withdrawn; is that correct?
—That is correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —May I offer a suggestion? One does not want to unduly delay this and I think Senator Harradine is absolutely right. I am at a loss, I am not sure about Senator Margetts, but can we stand this aside from the running sheet for the moment and come back to it later when we have all had a chance to look at the amendments?

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Parer) agreed to:
That Democrat amendments Nos 5 and 10 be postponed until the typed documents are circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 36, page 24 (lines 15 to 18), omit subparagraph (c)(iii), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (iii) the actual nature of the use; and

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 2, item 21, page 43 (lines 12 to 15), omit subparagraph (c)(iii), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (iii) the actual nature of the use; and

SPEECH.PARA: These government amendments to the customs and excise bill address the concerns that were expressed that the record keeping provisions in the bill could be construed as prescriptive requiring the keeping of logbooks and operating records. I might point out that this was never the government's position and its amendments clarify the proposed requirements to keep the diesel fuel records by removing any suggestions that particular types of records have to be kept. In fact, the amendment refers to the fact that it is simply in relation to the actual nature of the use of the diesel fuel itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —We will support government amendments Nos 1 and 2. We do so reluctantly. We think the next set of amendments that is to be moved by the opposition is far superior and will improve the position immeasurably. But the reason why we support these amendments is they make what is essentially a stupid position a bit better, and because that is an incremental benefit, a small change to the good, we will support them but hope that we can win the confidence of the committee for our more complete restoration of sanity with the amendments that I will move following this.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are about record keeping, as the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) has said. The Senate, as I have repeatedly said in this debate, conducted an inquiry into this legislation. The National Farmers Federation came and gave compelling evidence to that inquiry about the complicated nature of record keeping that would be required by the bill.

This is a move, as I understand it, by the government to clarify and make more simple the onerous red tape the government's original bill would have imposed on farmers in Australia. I might say, there is still an amount of complexity here. That amount of complexity flies directly in the face of the very solemn election promise given by the government at the last election—that they would cut down the level of red tape on small business. Farmers run a small business and the level of red tape being imposed here is quite high.

But the big unknown about these amendments and the reason I wish to make a few brief remarks on them is that what the government has said consistently is that one has to read the final bill when it becomes the act in order to see what the legal obligations are. But there will be a set of guidelines to the act issued by the government which will explain how people should go about complying with the act.

It is hard to understand what the government has absolutely clear in its mind until one sees that memorandum. That memorandum is still secret; it has not been published. This bill is a bill that arises from the 1996-97 budget— the budget of one year ago. I would have thought by now, given the extensive consultation the government has had with industry, they would have got around to publishing the memorandum. The fact that they have not published the memorandum does not do anything to shed any clarity on this proposal. Perhaps the minister, if he chooses to reply in this debate, might say when the government will be publishing that memorandum.

The detail here is that the claimants—that is, the farmers in this case—will still be required to provide records that could only be obtained through the use of logbooks. They will be required, in essence, whether the government wishes to assert it or not, to maintain a logbook for the purposes of settling the argument as to what amount of diesel fuel was used on which particular item of farm equipment and for what purpose it was used.

I think these amendments, as I have said, are somewhat hollow and pointless. The sole purpose appears simply to release the government from the charge that they are adding red tape to farmers and other small business claimants by not having to keep logbooks in their tractors. The additional supplementary explanatory memorandum tabled with these amendments says:

The inclusion in the original Bill of the reference to log books and other specific operating records in relation to the actual nature of the fuel used was intended to be an example of the type of record that might be kept.

The original clause does not read much like an example at all; it reads more like a veiled threat. But if the government's word is to be taken and accepted and it is just an example, then what these amendments do is remove that example from the bill. I do not think that that is a substantive change. The explanatory memorandum goes on to say:
If an applicant has other records which record the actual nature of the use of fuel, those records will be sufficient . . .
Further it says:
The onus is on the user of the diesel fuel to keep such records as are necessary to demonstrate that the actual use of the diesel fuel was in an eligible activity.

I must say, this sounds awfully like a massive tangle of red tape from a government that promised to rid small business of this burden. There are almost never any such records kept of the actual nature of the fuel used. It is simply not necessary or relevant for claimants to keep such records for the efficient management of their operations. As I have said, my amendments that I will move next will sort that problem out. We will support these amendments, however, for the reasons I have given.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a move that would seem to have been aimed at pre-empting Senator Cook's amendments to eliminate a requirement for logbooks for tractors, which will follow. The contentious terms such as `logbooks' have been excluded, but the effective requirement to substantiate the actual nature of use remains and logbooks or their equivalent may still be required. However, there is no contradiction between this amendment and the one to follow. The Greens will support this amendment. I think the more general requirement in this amendment can be interpreted to allow greater latitude in what is considered evidence of use. Therefore, we will potentially facilitate Senator Cook's amendment. The Greens will be supporting this amendment and also Senator Cook's amendment.
—The Australian Democrats support the government's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just quickly respond to Senator Cook. All of this requires sufficient records to justify that the diesel fuel rebate is being used for eligible purposes and that any user can use whatever form they like provided they can justify that the use is for eligible purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 36, page 24 (after line 35), after subsection (2A), insert:

PARA.TAB: (2AA) For a vehicle, vessel or machine which is used exclusively for a purpose for which diesel fuel rebate is payable, a statement by the applicant to that effect is a sufficient record for the purposes of subparagraph (2)(c)(iii).

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 2, item 21, page 43 (after line 32), after subsection (2A), insert:

PARA.TAB: (2AA) For a vehicle, vessel or machine which is used exclusively for a purpose for which diesel fuel rebate is payable, a statement by the applicant to that effect is a sufficient record for the purposes of subparagraph (2)(c)(iii).

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments have been suggested to the opposition by the National Farmers Federation to get around the problems that I referred to in the last set of amendments. I have here a memo from the NFF dealing with the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill—the bill currently before us. Appended to that memo is a legal opinion, which I will table in a moment, from Coors Chambers Westgarth—the lawyers that advised the NFF on this matter. The date of this legal opinion is 8 May 1997—just a short month or so ago. The text of this legal opinion is too long for me to read into Hansard , but I will table the legal opinion, not the covering memo.

What the amendments do is insert a new clause—2AA—into paragraph 240A of the Customs Act and the corresponding subsection 120A of the Excise Act. These amendments apply to situations where a machine is used exclusively for an eligible purpose and allow an applicant in such situations to simply make a statement to that effect, which is sufficient record to justify the usage of the fuel.

In the debate on the previous amendments—the government's amendments 1 and 2—I raised the point about the `actual nature' of the use of the diesel fuel. This is a very prescriptive element in this bill. What does `actual nature' actually mean? It would appear that a description of the general nature of the use of the fuel would not be adequate. In other words, a statement to the effect of `for farming purposes' would need to be replaced with a much more detailed statement, like, `86 litres of fuel were used to plough paddock 3', or `26 litres were used to spray paddock 7', et cetera. We would have farmers not actually doing any farming; they would be occupied full‐time reading meterings of the fuel level they are using, from meters which they do not currently have and which they would need to buy at great cost. They would then be doing complex calculations on what machine used what fuel for what purpose, filling in forms and signing declarations.

The point is, why should a farmer, miner or prospector go to inordinate lengths to substantiate his claim, if all the usage of the machine that is the subject of the claim is eligible anyway. Such machines may include tractors, harvesters and stationary motors—powering pumps, et cetera—which have no ineligible use. They may also include vehicles and other machines which may well have ineligible usages but are declared to be used only for eligible purposes. I am sure Customs has the wit to apply some basic tests—such as whether the vehicle is road registered and whether it could be reasonably used for non‐eligible purposes. For example, it would be fairly hard for a farmer to make a case for his road registered Land Cruiser ute to be used only for eligible purposes without further justification, unless perhaps he or she ran a half‐million acre cattle station.

The government may well say—as they have for every other amendment we have moved—that this opens the floodgates. It does not, because the penalties in sections 164A, 164AA, 164AC, 234 and 240 for people who get caught are immense—and made clear. As I said earlier, we think this makes the whole situation easier, from a record keeping point of view, without opening the floodgates and while ensuring that the revenue is protected. For those reasons, I move the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment, if passed, would remove the requirements on all claimants—farmers, miners, fishermen—for beneficiation processes. In effect, it applies a `trust me' approach to substantiating claims. The government has removed any perceived requirements that logbooks are required for all equipment and has indicated that normal records of a well run office should suffice to substantiate claims for eligible use.

BREAK.PARA: Under this amendment, all that is required is for the claimant to state that a vehicle, vessel or piece of machinery is used totally for an eligible use, and this will suffice for record keeping and substantiation. No Customs auditor would be able to look behind this statement. It would be conclusive. For a scheme which outlays $1.4 billion and has been subject to significant criticism in relation to record keeping and accountability, such an approach to substantiation would, in our view, be tantamount to a blank cheque.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a measure to ensure that farmers or other users do not have to keep detailed records on equipment that is only used for a rebatable purpose. Why should farmers have to keep logbooks for tractors that are only used in farming. With respect, if Customs is worried about rorting, it is not a solution to have farmers keep a logbook on a tractor. If they are going to lie and say a vehicle is only used in farming, they can, equally, lie and fill out a logbook and substantiate such a claim. A logbook is not a proof against lying; it is simply a lot more work. It is probably easier to prove a lie when someone says, `I only use this vehicle for X purpose and I only use my rebatable diesel in X vehicles', than when they fill out detailed records justifying the diesel used.

SPEECH.PARA: This is, basically, a compliance issue. I see no real reason to force people to keep logbooks for vehicles like tractors that do get used exclusively—or almost exclusively—in farming. There is no point in that additional paperwork. I notice that Senator Parer has said that it will open the floodgates for all users. Perhaps, in that sense, we should get a response from Senator Cook as to why this is not likely to be the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —My response is that you and I have explained it twice to the chamber now, Senator Margetts. This covers the machinery or equipment—the plant—that is used exclusively for rebatable purposes. If you have a stationary motor on a farm that is using diesel fuel, it is unlikely—or beyond comprehension—that that motor will be used off the farm in some other situation, because it is not a portable item. In that case, you would have to say that all fuel used for that stationary motor is eligible for rebate. If you go to a tractor or a harvester or some other item of equipment which is used on the farm for that purpose and consumes diesel fuel and thus is subject to the tax, it is fair to say that all the fuel it consumes is rebatable fuel for the purposes of this act. I do not think it opens the floodgates at all.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been conducting this debate for 9½ hours, I understand. We have heard in the debate that every change we propose will open the floodgates or allow a boom in litigation or words to that effect, but we have never had any substantiation of those allegations from the government. A broad brush dismissal of a constructive claim—in this case backed by the NFF—would seem to me not to be adequate from the government's side, and the government should explain—with resort to particular examples—where it sees that this would open the floodgates, because it is our contention that it will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that would be helpful. The minister has indicated that the examples come from mining rather than agriculture. Can the minister give us an example of where equipment that is used only for a rebatable purpose might be able to be rorted and used for other purposes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I should repeat, Senator, what I did say: if this amendment goes through, all that is required is for a claimant to state that a vehicle, vessel or machinery is used totally, and this will suffice. No customs auditor would be able to look behind this statement as it would be conclusive. An example could be, for instance—it does not matter whether you are on a mine, in a rural pursuit or whatever—a four-wheel drive vehicle. You could say that this is exclusively used for eligible purposes and they cannot go behind it. There are instances too these days, of course, where you have—I stand to be corrected—contract work being done in farming areas where these vehicles, that would use diesel in harvesting and moving from as far away as the Northern Territory to South Australia, you could say, were used exclusively for eligible purposes. Yet, in that transportation mode, it would not be eligible purposes.

—What is the legal reason that customs would not be able to, at any stage, audit that decision or check that decision, or perhaps respond to anybody who put in a query on whether or not such an item was in fact used exclusively?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —In the minister's example, if someone said that the item of plant or equipment was used for rebatable purposes and it was not, they would be breaking the law. They would be committing an offence. If there was any reasonable suspicion harboured by customs or any other enforcement agency that that was the case, of course they would look behind it and investigate the matter. I draw the minister's attention to section 234 of the Customs Act, headed `Customs offences', which specifically states:

SPEECH.PARA: 234. (1) A person shall not:
(d) knowingly or recklessly:
(i) make a statement to an officer that is false or misleading in a material particular; or—
and it goes on to set out a few other types of offences. Anyone who does that commits an offence.

If we put in this act a provision that they have to declare—as this amendment enables it to be done—that this plant or equipment is used exclusively for this purpose, and that is knowingly lied about by someone, they are, it seems to me, in breach of the act and subject to prosecution.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the instance that the minister gave—he talked about, say, a Land Rover coming from the Northern Territory to South Australia as an example—surely that would be a rebatable purpose.
—No.

—Why not? I know the area pretty well, actually. Using the Northern Territory for example, if you had somebody doing contract work out towards the Western Australian border in the Northern Territory and came down to the Finke and across the border into South Australia to do similar work there, surely that is a purpose for which the diesel fuel rebate would be payable? Otherwise, are you really saying that, if somebody goes down to town to buy a Land Rover for use up in the Northern Territory, they go into, say, Adelaide for that purpose and fill it up with diesel to transport that vehicle from Adelaide up to the station in the Northern Territory, that is not a purpose for which the diesel fuel rebate is payable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it never has been.
—What? Not transferring from the shop to the—

—No. It never has been. It is only for the use of eligible purposes on the property or on the mining lease. Just in response to Senator Margetts, I would refer you, Senator, to the second amendment moved by Senator Cook, which I think spells it out fairly clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: For a vehicle, vessel or machine which is used exclusively for a purpose for which diesel fuel rebate is payable, a statement by the applicant to that effect is a sufficient record . . .

That is all the record they have to keep. We are not being prescriptive on the records they have to keep. We are just saying, `Keep sufficient records so you can justify getting the diesel fuel rebate.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just double check whether the amendments—schedule 1, item 36, and schedule 2, item 21—relate to mining and agriculture?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —They cover the whole area of eligibility: mining, farming, fishing and forestry.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Cook's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw amendments 5 and 10.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw amendments 5 and 10. I seek leave to introduce amendments 1 to 8. They should be before every senator.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 25, page 19 (line 32) to page 20 (line 4), omit subsection (15), substitute:

(15) A person is not excused from making available a record when required to do so under subsection (2) on the grounds that the making available of the record makes the person liable to a penalty, but any records so made available are not admissible in evidence against the person in proceedings other than proceedings for an offence against section 164A, subsection (8) of this section or paragraph 234(1)(c) or (d), in relation to diesel fuel rebate.
Schedule 2, item 10, page 38, omit subsection (15), substitute:

(15) A person is not excused from making available a record when required to do so under subsection (2) on the grounds that the making available of the record makes the person liable to a penalty, but any records so made available are not admissible in evidence against the person in proceedings other than proceedings for an offence against section 78AA, subsection (8) of this section or paragraph 120(1)(vc) or (vi), in relation to diesel fuel rebate.

I wish to briefly speak to those amendments. As I mentioned earlier, the government, having heard the arguments I put, came to me and said that they understood what I was getting at but they felt that there was a better way in which it could be expressed. I listened to their approach and I think we have come up with a good alternative which will satisfy my needs. They reminded me—and we probably all know this, after a very long debate—that the DFR scheme constitutes an opt-in approach. In other words, nobody has to or is obliged to become a member of the scheme. When you opt-in, you are required to provide documentation or a case to support your application and then you are permitted to join the scheme.

It seems self-evident to me, both from the point of view of good business practice and from the point of view of proper accountability, that thereafter the applicant should in fact keep documentation which verifies that they have bought the fuel that is being used for this purpose. My belief is that they should be keeping records in at least a general and practical sense as to how, when and where they use it.

The ANAO did point out to the government in their review of this area that they thought the audit procedures being undertaken were relatively deficient. Customs are amongst those departments which have been subject to government budgetary cuts and, frankly, they do not have the resources and possibly not even the accounting and auditing expertise to conduct audits which are widespread and effective.

The consequence is that, by and large, this is genuinely a trust system. It is genuinely a system where the bulk of the users of the DFR are not required to substantiate their use and their application, simply because Customs cannot get around and do even a significant sample audit. So what we are really dealing with here is a minority of applicants and users who are subject to audit—and it is a minority of applicants; a number which I think government would confirm runs into the hundreds of thousands, not just thousands. If they have broken the rules and regulations, they are subject to penalty and fine.

We then move on to the issue of whether—and it is the issue that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee raised and which I recounted yesterday—the rights of appeal exist. Of course, if you have a fine and decline to pay it, then you are subject indeed to a right of appeal. You can go to the courts and have the matter overturned. So there is an outside body over and above Customs.

These particular amendments really refer to the core of the civil liberties issues which I was raising, which were the issues of the right to silence and the right to avoid self-incrimination, which characterise our principles of justice and our principles of dealing with these matters. My strong belief is that the right to silence and the right to avoid self-incrimination relate to a personal approach to matters and not to documentation. So the consequence of the amendments you have before you is that the right to silence and the right to avoid self-incrimination are preserved.

BREAK.PARA: But if you are required, and I think properly so, to be accountable in terms of your documentation then you need to provide it. I think that is entirely reasonable. It is entirely consistent with our processes and the way in which we operate our administrative and judicial system. On that basis, therefore, I was happy to accept the government's suggestions and to withdraw my amendments, which were somewhat more fulsome, and to accept their proposals. With that brief set of explanatory remarks, I commend my amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the government has said that people must answer questions or provide records, even when that shows they are liable to a penalty, but that the answer or record cannot be used against them in evidence, except in prosecutions under certain laws on diesel rebate. I need to find out whether or not the amended amendments from Senator Murray rule out prosecution under general Customs offences sections 234(1)(c) and (d).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not have to answer questions but they can be prosecuted on the records. Of course they have an option then, if the CEO decides that there is a penalty, of either paying the penalty or objecting to that and going to court. That was the very thrust, I think, of Senator Murray's amendment—in fact, it is not the thrust of his amendment; it is going to be the thrust of an amendment that I will move to his amendment.
—In a situation where a person is being audited for their tax for any other reasons, is it the case that a person does not have to answer questions about what they have done or their record keeping?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is exactly the same. They do not have to answer questions under this. Do not ask me about the tax act; I have never been audited.

—Perhaps there might be someone who could tell me. In the normal situation of a person, if they are required to keep certain records and if they want to apply for some sort of tax rebate, can they be required to answer questions about what they have spent that money on, and so on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little unsure on the tax act. My understanding is that they can call for their accountant to be present but I am not sure whether they have to answer questions. I do understand that they have to produce records—of course they do. If they do not, what the tax man can do, as I understand it, is impute a figure which the taxpayer then has to respond to. But that is part of the negotiating process when audits go on within the tax act. But under this legislation they will not have to verbally answer questions; they will just produce the records.

—Perhaps the equivalent might be the companies law or the Corporations Law where people could be required to answer questions in relation to companies law or Corporations Law, with regard to their record keeping.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, all I can tell you is that under this amendment to the Customs Act they do not have to verbally answer questions which could incriminate them, but they do have to produce records.

—I think the minister has missed my point. What I am trying to establish is whether or not there is an established right to silence in any other equivalent form of law where people are required to keep records where they are applying for a particular benefit. In other laws like the Corporations Law, companies law or whatever, if they get a benefit from making statements or putting in certain records, can they be required to answer questions about the information they have given?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The only answer I can give you on the advice I have got is that under the criminal code you have the right to silence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support this amendment. As I said before, we had some misgivings about it in its original form but those misgivings have been assuaged to a large extent by the changes.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Schedule 1, item 42, page 26 (lines 9 to 13), omit paragraphs (a) and (b), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (a) that is purchased before the day on which those items commence and in respect of which an application for diesel fuel rebate is not received under section 78A of that Act before, on, or within 3 months after, that day; or
(b) that is purchased on or after that day.

SPEECH.PARA: Government amendment No. 9 redrafts the transitional provisions in relation to the Customs Act 1901 to provide that only fuel purchased before the new provisions come into operation and in respect of which the rebate is applied before the expiration of three months after that date may be assessed under the old eligibility rules. Government amendment No. 10 redrafts the transitional provisions in relation to the Excise Act 1901 on the same basis as the amendment to the Customs Act in government amendment No. 9 does.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have debated this bill now for 10 hours. On behalf of the opposition let me say that we will support these government amendments and not debate it further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the government amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate at this stage, particularly with the minister present, to reiterate my disappointment that the bill is facing its final vote without the most positive innovation having been taken up—that is, the proposal for the sun fund. This would have enabled the people of Australia who are being subsidised through the diesel fuel rebate to have taken 10 years worth of that rebate up-front and used it to produce renewable energy for their farmhouses, their cooling systems and their machinery sheds.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only would this have been a real alternative for those conservation‐minded people on the land—there are thousands of them—but it would have stimulated local business in the small towns in regional Australia which so badly need it. Instead of the money just being circulated between Canberra and the diesel fuel companies, in effect, it would have put money into creating a sunrise industry presence in many of those small towns.

It is big business—640 megawatts is being used through diesel generation for electricity on farms which could be produced through photovoltaic cells, through wind power and through the energy alternatives which are now available in this country with the excellent technology that we have available. That is equivalent to half the output of the 39 dams in the total Tasmanian electricity grid. So it is a big domestic market which could have stimulated small business throughout rural Australia as well as given farmers a bit of cash in their pockets to be innovative about how they manage the electricity production component of energy production on their farms, not to speak of miners and other people who get this diesel fuel rebate.

It has apparently been premature of us to bring this forward, although it is just the sort of scheme that was being proposed a quarter of a century ago during the oil crisis when Australia should have taken the lead in this direction. I note that the opposition has said that they need more time to assess it. Generally, there has been a positive reception to the idea in this committee and the Senate committee hearing on this piece of legislation.

I would like to foreshadow that I will be continuing to promote this sun fund idea from the Greens. It is a very positive one from the economic, employment, energy and environ ment points of view. I will be bringing it back to the Senate. I would certainly be pleased to talk with government about how we can promote it. It is dollar neutral and it is budget neutral for the government but it gives choice to the people on the land. It is certainly beneficial to the environment at a time when Australia has a long way to go to catch up with overseas thinking and to regain its reputation as far as clean, green, efficient energy production is concerned.

I have a number of options but one of those I will foreshadow here is bringing in discrete legislation in the not too distant future to re-visit this issue. In the meantime I will spend some time giving information about how this remarkably simple and positive idea for the bush and for Australia as a whole can be implemented to reassure the opposition and the government about the all‐round merits and the win‐win nature of this very positive proposal.

I am glad to have had this opportunity to flag this positive idea from the Greens, which has basically come through from community groups. I will be promoting it. I will be giving more information to the bigger parties about the proposal. I hope in the not too distant future that we will see it taken up and adopted with gusto in Australia for all the benefits it can bring, not just to people on the land but to Australia's reputation as a country, which is an environmentally clean and progressive thinking country, developing technology, which, of course, we can export and send on to people elsewhere in our own region as they too aspire to be able to have locally produced, clean, efficient energy, cheap energy and energy which is not leading to a long-term deficit through the greenhouse phenomenon—the global warming phenomenon—a long-term problem for those generations of people who will be coming after us.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with opposition amendment No. 10 on sheet 517, moved by Senator Evans, on behalf of Senator Kernot as well. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention, with the permission of the chamber, to move Labor and Democrat amendments Nos 11 and 12 together. They relate to the decision to engage EPEs, the code of conduct for EPEs—
—What about 13?
—I thought we would do that in the order it fell. These are amendments to clauses 11 and 12. Am I not doing the right thing?
—Originally, it was said that 13 was included. I think that is where the confusion is. You are now suggesting that we deal with just the first two—that is, 11 and 12?
—I am suggesting that we deal with 11 and 12 together, but certainly not 13. That is a separate issue altogether.
—Continue, Senator Evans.
—I seek leave to move amendments 11 and 12 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Clause 11, page 11 (lines 5 to 17), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 11 Primary objectives in decision to engage employment placement enterprises

SPEECH.PARA: It is the intention of the Parliament that the primary objectives in the engagement of employ ment placement enterprises as provided for in this Division should be:

PARA.TAB: (a) the extent to which the engagement of an enterprise will be able to contribute to the provision of high quality employment assistance services to all Australians, regardless of where they live;
(b) the ability of a prospective employment placement enterprise to provide employment assistance services that will be:

TAB.TAB: (i) based on the individual circumstances of persons using the service;
(ii) provided in a fair, just and expeditious manner; and
(iii) provided in accordance with high ethical and professional standards and with respect to the right of users of the service to privacy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 11A Code of Conduct for employment placement enterprises

SPEECH.PARA: (1) With a view to ensuring that employment placement enterprises will contribute to the achievement of the objectives set out in section 11, as soon as practicable after the commencement of this Act the Minister must, after consulting with the National Committee established under section 85, make a written determination setting out a Code of Conduct to be observed by employment placement enterprises.
(2) A determination under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 11B Other factors in Commonwealth's decision to engage employment placement enterprise

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Minister may make a written determination specifying:

PARA.TAB: (a) matters additional to the primary objectives set out in section 11 and additional to the matters contained in the Code of Conduct determined under section I I A to be taken into account by the Employment Secretary in deciding, on behalf of the Commonwealth, to engage an employment placement enterprise under section 10; and
(b) the procedures to be followed by the Employment Secretary in relation to the decision and the engagement. A determination has effect accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) A determination under subsection (1) must be complementary to the achievement of the primary objectives set out in section 11.
(3) A determination under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 11C Accreditation as Employment placement enterprises

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Employment Secretary may, by written determination, provide that an entity is an accredited employment placement enterprise.

(2) The Employment Secretary must not make a determination under subsection (1) in respect of an entity unless the Employment Secretary is satisfied that the requirements of the Code of Conduct determined under section I IA, and any other matters specified under section I IB, will be observed by the entity.

(3) Where the Employment Secretary considers it reasonable to do so because of the performance of an entity, the Employment Secretary may, by written determination, provide that that entity is not to be an accredited employment placement enterprise.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 11D Register of private employment—placement enterprises

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Employment Secretary must maintain a register listing all private employment placement enterprises engaged under section 10, recording, in respect of each employment placement enterprise:

PARA.TAB: (a) details of payments made to the enterprise by the Commonwealth;
(b) the results of the work performed by the enterprise, in particular the success of the enterprise in enabling persons to gain employment; and
(c) whether the enterprise is an accredited employment placement enterprise for the purposes of section I IC; and
(d) details of any complaints made under section 59 in connection with the enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Employment Secretary must provide to the National Committee appointed under section 85, as soon as practicable after each 31 December and 30 June, a copy of the register updated in respect of the preceding 6 month period.
(12) Page 13, after clause 14 (after line 16), insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 14A Annual report about employment placement enterprises

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Minister must, as soon as practicable after the end of 30 June in each year, cause an annual report to be prepared. The annual report must include (but is not limited to):

PARA.TAB: (a) a report about the operation of employment placement enterprises;
(b) a summary description of any complaints the Employment Secretary regards as substantial in connection with an employment placement enterprise;

(c) an explanation by the Minister of the Minister's actions, or proposed actions, in response to any complaints reported on under paragraph (b), or any other problems of which the Minister is aware in connection with the provision of employment services by employment placement enterprises.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Minister must cause copies of the annual report prepared under sub-section (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the completion of the annual report.

These amendments are the first step, if you like, in the set of regulations and monitoring provisions that we are seeking to insert into the bill. They relate to the code of conduct and the accreditation of private providers. Later, the Democrats will be sponsoring amendments, which we will support, which go to an employment council.

What we are seeking to do is place into the bill the proper safeguards which we think are necessary for the creation of this new employment services market. Because the government has announced its intention to effectively set up a private market for services which have in the past been delivered largely by public sector authorities but in part by private sector case managers, we think it is very important that the accountability provisions in the bill are strong and that the protections for community interests are well established.

The government has announced that up to $1 billion of taxpayers' funds will finance the new market, so we have a very keen interest in ensuring that that market operates effectively and efficiently and is properly accountable. This transfer of taxpayers' funds solely to fund these private players in the new market makes this whole area a real responsibility for this parliament.

Our first amendment to clause 11 sets out the primary objects in engaging the EPEs, reinforces the objects clause and seeks to make clear the sorts of values we think should be primary in the market. Clause 11A sets out the code of conduct for employment placement enterprises. All we are suggesting is that that code of conduct be drawn up by the minister after consultation with the national committee.

I am aware, subsequent to our approach to these matters, that the government has in its tender documents for the new market institut ed a code of conduct for potential tenderers. We think that is a good thing and, on a quick analysis of that, I think it is going down the right path. We think it is very important that that code of conduct is included in the act and that the necessity for EPEs to comply with the code of conduct is stipulated. That should all be contained in the legislation.

The amendment relating to section 11B makes provision for the minister to make other decisions in relation to the engagement of employment placement enterprises. The provisions ensure the minister is not limited at all by the primary objectives provisionally placed earlier so as to take into account other issues if they are relevant, but making that a disallowable instrument so that the parliament can have some review over that process. The amendment dealing with section 11C provides for accreditation of employment placement enterprises. It puts in place the accreditation regime which makes sure that only those persons who comply with the code of conduct can be tenderers.

There is a great deal of concern within the community from current providers and consumers that there is the potential for persons to establish EPEs which may not necessarily have high ethical standards and may not necessarily act in the best interests of their clients but rather purely operate for quick profit. We think that is the danger in this new market system so we are very keen to ensure that the accreditation system provides, with other measures, those safeguards to ensure that the $1 billion of public funds are utilised properly and that the clients, who are the unemployed of Australia, receive first‐class service and the best value for money that the public dollar can buy for them.

The section 11D amendment seeks to establish a register of private employment placement enterprises. This is to ensure reporting of those who engage in industry, allowing for the parliament to monitor what is occurring in the market by means of the employment secretary maintaining this register of who is engaged to fulfil what—the Public Service function, if you like—in the new market.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment 12, which I am moving as part of the same package of accountability measures, seeks to provide for an annual report on the operation of the employment placement enterprises and the provision of that report to the parliament. It is all part of an approach to providing proper accreditation, accountability and review by this parliament of the large amount of public funds to be invested in this new market. It is part of some broader approach to accountability, which includes other measures that will be moved later on. We think these are very necessary amendments to ensure that the public interest is protected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans has made the case for the amendments but I would like to concentrate on two parts. It is important to point out that amendment No. 11, which deals with section 11, actually outlines what we think are some of the standards that EPEs should be able to meet. We think things like providing services in a fair, just and expeditious manner are important. Meeting high ethical and professional standards with the rights of users and privacy considerations is important too. I know the government thinks it is doing all this via other means. It is the same argument we had yesterday about whether we want to see it be more explicit or not. We do want to see it more explicit.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to amendment 11 dealing with section 11B, I am conscious that the government has said that the result of this amendment will be that all the selection criteria for every EPE will have to be set out in writing. I wonder if the minister could tell us why this is such a problem. Do you recall making that comment?

Section 11B allows the minister to make objectives in addition to the primary objectives and in addition to the code of conduct, which need to be taken into account by the employment secretary when deciding if an EPE should be engaged. I thought you said that if we went ahead with this amendment it would result in all the selection criteria for every EPE having to be set out in writing. I think you said you thought that was an un necessary and onerous burden that would undermine the process. I wondered if you would be able to elaborate on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated to the Democrats that we are quite keen for providers to comply with a code of conduct. We have an alterative version that we would be happy to accept in place of your 11A.
—Is that in your amendments?

—Yes, if you are prepared to entertain them. We would need to work out a way to do it so that we moved an amendment that provided for a code of conduct and an amendment that provided for a register of employment placement enterprises, but not any of the other amendments contained in amendment 11. In other words, you would have to withdraw those amendments and accept ours. On that basis we would move them, otherwise we would just be wasting time.
—Is it possible to come back to this?

—Yes, you can look at it. What you are actually asking for in relation to 11(b) is matters additional to what you set out in 11 being able to be taken into account. I presume by that you mean in specific circumstances where there ought to be some other factors taken into account, in which case you would be setting out different criteria in each of those situations. We do not agree with 11 in any event. As I am advised, 11 would give right to an AD(JR) appeal on the very differences that we have already argued about, and I do not think it is worth rehashing them. In 11, you say that you want:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the provision of high quality employment assistance services to all Australians, regardless of where they live;
Of course, that does not happen now; it is not possible for that to happen now. If you go to somewhere like Laverton, 300 kilometres, or something, north of Kalgoorlie—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a long way from anywhere.

—I know it is a long way from anywhere. We went there to do something in relation to indigenous employment and it took a long time to get there and a long time to get back. There is not much in the way of employment services provided there. Yet, consistently, to cover places such as that you want to put in these aims of provision which are not there for the existing service that is offered. We just think that is unreasonable for you to create that expectation and provide that opportunity for AD(JR) appeal on that basis. It is not provided now. No government will be able to provide it. It is just another example of wanting to frustrate this government's intention by saying, `Well, if you want to make a change, you are going to have to provide everything to everybody.' And you know, Senator, that that is not possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not really think that the amendments are seeking to do what you suggest, although there may be consequences that have not been contemplated. Senator Evans made clear that what we are seeking to do with the amendment that you just referred to is to maintain rights that now exist. Minister, if you have a view that that goes beyond those rights in some way, then in the spirit of the comments that you made about amendment No. 12, or aspects of it, it may be worth while looking at precise wording that overcomes the difficulty that you suggest exists in relation to remote locations and legal implications of this amendment, whilst at the same time preserving the intent behind the opposition‐Democrat amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: It may not be a matter which you wish to contemplate. You may be prepared to see this amendment go to a vote in its current form knowing that there may be an unintended consequence, and you may be relying upon that to seek to defeat it. I suggest that perhaps it would be better policy to find out if there is support for the principle that we are espousing with this amendment. If there is support—if the amendment is to be passed and we are to go with this bill in some amended form ultimately, notwithstanding the comments that were made about whether this bill will be ultimately passed into law—better policy might be served, as I say, by looking at, firstly, the question of whether there is support for the principle which we say lies behind the amendment and, secondly, if there is, dealing with the question of what drafting would best serve that aim whilst not raising the consequences that you provide.

I did want to make a couple of other comments but, if the minister wishes to respond now, I am happy to sit down, bearing in mind the time, to hear your response and resume comment about other aspects of these two amendments later.

TALK.START.PARA: —This might assist in the consideration of the matter. I am inclined to support the amendments that are currently before the chamber. I support the comment by Senator O'Brien that, if there is some unintended consequence involved, it might be useful for the minister to reconsider the matter and let us know how best a form of words could overcome that potential problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor opposition is happy to listen to arguments from the minister about any unintended consequences and, if convinced of that, to make appropriate amendments. As yet, we have not had a very informed debate on some of these amendments to go to any of those concerns. The minister raised some concern about a duplication argument with accreditation yesterday. I actually turned my mind to that overnight to see how we could accommodate any legitimate concerns that might be there. The minister has not raised that again today.

SPEECH.PARA: I have now been given a couple of amendments that the government might decide to move. Obviously, I have not had a chance to consider those; they have only just been handed to me. The point made by Senators O'Brien and Harradine is the main one. If the government has detailed in‐principle objections about unintended consequences of any of these amendments, you ought to argue them. I am sure you will find that we will respond positively to them. We have not had that sort of debate. What we have had is a press release from you that said that these things were non‐negotiable. If we do have issues that arise here or later on in the amendments, we are happy to take them as they come and treat them on their merits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some things that are non‐negotiable. One of them is that people on benefits who are unemployed will be put first in any queue. All through these amendments—
—We have all said that we agree.

—Senator, you have had your go without interruption. At least do others the courtesy of allowing them the same opportunity. All through these amendments, you have sprinkled things to frustrate the government's objective. Senator, it is very nice of you to say that you are prepared to talk but, when you had your amendments ready, you were not prepared to release them. You were not prepared to talk. Not all senators are available for briefings on this matter—conveniently, some might suggest, not available. It is perfectly clear what the determination of the opposition senators basically is. It is to frustrate the government's intention on this bill. We will not be frustrated on it. We will put unemployed people on benefits first. SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, why has the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, once again pre-empted your statutory role and announced the green light for the Jabiluka uranium mine before you have even received an environmental impact statement and made a recommendation to the action minister? This is just what he did in the case of the Port Hinchinbrook development. On what grounds did Mr Fischer conclude that the Jabiluka mine should go ahead? Are his comments on Sunday's Face to Face program not just another example of your government's complete disregard for the environment and complete disregard for due process, and just another confirmation of your irrelevance in the Howard government's decision making processes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Mr Fischer was referring to the changing market situation for uranium, in particular a growing demand, and the fact that we are in competition with Canada to provide the resource. That is a good point, it is an important point, because it is an industry in which we can be internationally competitive. We can, therefore, use it as a basis to create wealth with all the benefits that flow to Australian people as a result thereof, in particular the benefit of jobs because this government, in contrast to the Labor Party, is vitally interested in the provision of new jobs. We want an expanding economy. We obviously want it in areas in which we can be internationally competitive, and this area of mining is one such area. That is the background to these statements.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the particular application for consent concerning the Jabiluka prospect, the EIS, as I understand, has been delivered to my office by the consultants today. It will receive proper attention, and I will no doubt receive advice from my department on it in due course. Senator Collins will recall that, when it was put out in draft form earlier, my department made representations at that time, and they have no doubt been taken into account. Obviously, I have not considered the final report because, as I said, it has only just arrived on the desk. When it has been properly considered, I will be giving advice to Senator Parer in terms of the EP(IP) Act and the government will ultimately be making a decision. So I ask you to distinguish the two issues.

There are a few uranium prospects before the government at the moment. This government does not have the crazy policy that Labor had—that is, three uranium mines were legitimate but a fourth was illegitimate. We have said that each prospect will be examined and it must reach the highest environmental standards before it will be approved. If it reaches those standards, obviously it would not be blackballed on the grounds of environmental issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, how can you deny that this has not been the green light? This is what Mr Fischer said on Sunday:

QUESTION.PARA: We've got a narrow window of opportunity now to start up some clean new uranium mines . . . we can stuff around and see another mine open in Canada . . . or we can get on with it and have more jobs in WA, the Northern Territory and elsewhere from processing Jabiluka properly but quickly.
Are you trying to tell us that such an announcement, before you have had the chance to look at the EIS, in no way pre-empts proper decision making processes?

TALK.START.PARA: —No way at all. It is totally consistent with what I have just said to the Senate. I understand it is true that there is a narrow window of opportunity for an expansion of uranium sales in competition with Canada. I would have thought that all Australians would want to see an expanding economy and the creation of more jobs. That is not in dispute, at least not on this side of the chamber. But, in relation to Jabiluka, Kintyre or any other application, as I have said on many occasions, it would need to reach the highest environmental standards. We now have that EIS before us and decisions will be made upon that in due course.

—My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. The minister would be aware that the latest survey on home loan affordability shows that housing affordability is now at its best level in three years? Minister, how has the Howard government's economic strategy benefited Australian home buyers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for that question which is important to many Australian families. The fact of the matter is, as Senator Watson implied in his question, there is more good news for families and home buyers from the Howard government. The latest Citibank and Real Estate Institute of Australia quarterly survey on home loan affordability shows that Australians have benefited from further reductions in interest rates with a 5.1 per cent jump in affordability. The Commonwealth Bank‐HIA index has jumped 6.4 per cent to its highest level ever in its 12½‐year history.

ANSWER.PARA: The Citibank survey shows that since the Howard government came to office the proportion of family income going to fund loan repayments has dropped considerably, which, I trust, everyone in this chamber would welcome. When the Labor Party left office, home loan repayments amounted to, on average, 28 per cent of family income. Today that figure is down to 24 per cent. That is, of course, before the latest interest rate cut is taken into account. As Citibank says:
We remain confident that low mortgage rates will bring even more first home buyers into the market and set the scene for strong housing growth over the next few years.

Under this government, home buyers with a $100,000 loan are now saving some $292 a month in interest payments. What did the Labor Party give them? The Labor Party gave them home mortgage rates of up to 17 per cent with families paying well over $1,400 a month in interest repayments. Under the coalition, many people can get home loan interest rates of the order of 6.99 per cent with interest payments at around $700 a month.

This has not all happened by accident. This government has been prepared to take the tough decisions to reduce Labor's $10.3 billion deficit we inherited. This takes the pressure off interest rates and keeps inflation low. What would the Labor Party have done if they had been, by some sad mischance of history, re-elected at the last election? Mr Gary Johns, a former minister in the Keating government, has essentially let the cat out of the bag. Mr Johns was quoted in the Herald‐Sun on 14 June 1997—fairly recently—
Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know if Senator Sherry read this report but, in a blunt assessment of Labor's failings in office, Mr Johns—as I said, a former Keating minister—said:

BREAK.PARA: The landslide defeat had rescued the ALP from confronting hard policy choices over how to repair the budget and reduce national debt.
That was not a Liberal Party person saying that; that is a former Keating minister.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would suggest, seeing they are making so much noise over there, that opposition senators should read Mr Johns's critique of the Labor Party's failings in the Institute of Public Affairs review. The IPA is a very distinguished body. If Senator Sherry wants a copy of the article, I will see if I can arrange that for him. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, are you aware that advice from the Taxpayers Association of Australia encourages people to take out the cheapest form of private health insurance at around $670 per year and still be treated as public patients in public hospitals if required? Does this not mean that a person earning $120,000 a year would save around $530 a year by not paying the additional one per cent Medicare levy and could continue to use Medicare and the public hospital system, contrary to the government's intention? Minister, will you now accept that your proposals for increasing private health insurance and thereby reducing reliance on the public health system have been a failure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to find that after about 15 months in opposition and 13 years in government the Labor Party has finally discovered private health insurance as an issue. They were very much averse to it in government. We saw that in government, the then Prime Minister, who had five dependants, and the health minister, Carmen Lawrence, found it quite okay for them—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections and the level of is discussion is too high.
—It was quite okay for well paid ministers of the crown in the Labor government to—
—And the Prime Minister.

—Yes, I have said the Prime Minister—thank you, Senator Calvert. This was Prime Minister Keating, of course. They were all prepared to take their place and shoulder other people out of the queues for public hospitals.

ANSWER.PARA: This government went to the people of Australia at the last election with a commitment to improve the affordability of private health insurance. We are doing that in two ways: we are making sure that those who are on low to middle incomes are given incentives by way of tax assistance. We are also making sure that those who are on higher incomes actually have to pay a higher levy if they do not take out private health insurance. It is important to start to recognise that the public system cannot keep going while people who could be using the private system are not doing so.

So it is very important that the opposition has at last recognised the relationship between private health insurance and the success or otherwise of the public system. We have always understood that connection and that is why we have offered incentives. For the same reason, we have put disincentives on those on high incomes to rely solely on the public purse.

People in the circumstances Senator Bishop asked about will clearly still have private insurance. They will have the opportunity to draw on private health care when they choose to. They can also, just as anybody can now, go to the public hospital for health care. We hope that by making it clear to them that the private sector is appropriate and that it is not appropriate for them not to pay their way when they have the means to do so, we are sending a pretty powerful message to the Australian people. I am hoping that Senator Bishop, by asking his question, implies that he would agree with that message.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you managed to avoid answering the question, so I will rephrase it. I ask you now: why did the government decide to introduce this measure knowing that the full impact of the levy could be avoided by the method outlined by the Taxpayers Association and at the same time that it would not reduce the use of the public hospital system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already answered the elements of that question. There is nothing further to add.

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The minister would be aware of a draft report by the US Department of Energy supporting the Australian government's view that uniform greenhouse reduction targets are not an equitable or efficient means of achieving environmentally effective outcomes. What effect would adoption of uniform greenhouse gas reduction targets have on jobs in Australia, and can the minister please explain what other costs, relative to other countries, Australia would have to bear.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a reference in the media this morning to a US energy department report which supports aspects of our own Australian analysis. There has, in fact, been something of a flurry of comment on the economic impact of uniform reduction targets in recent days. I have not as yet seen the draft report referred to by Senator Ferris, but let me make the general point that it is not only ABARE's economic analysis which points to significant economic and sectoral impacts on some countries, including Australia, as a result of uniform reduction targets; it is also instructive to note that some 30 to 40 United States senators—from both sides of their chamber—have supported a resolution expressing concern at the financial and economic impact of any United States support for uniform reduction targets. As we have repeatedly stated, the European led push for unrealistic uniform targets across annex 1 countries achieves very little for the environment and has the European Union bearing the least cost of all—surprise, surprise!

BREAK.PARA: It is also interesting to note that the reported resolution of the US Senate says that the US should not sign a treaty `which would result in serious harm to the economy of the United States'. That is exactly the view of Australia. Economic analysis undertaken by ABARE highlights the damaging sectoral impacts on our economy under a uniform target. ABARE has found that a uniform reduction target—even one far less stringent than that proposed by the European Union—would decimate the non‐ferrous metal industries in Australia and the iron and steel industry.

Output in the non‐ferrous metal industry would be some 50 per cent less than it would otherwise have been by 2010, which makes it substantially less than today's level of production. This would lead to serious job losses and regional effects in Victoria and Queensland. Production in the iron and steel industry would be some 25 per cent less than it would otherwise have been, with dramatic regional employment dislocation, particularly in New South Wales and South Australia. Australia's coal output would also decline significantly relative to business as usual, with significant job losses in Queensland and New South Wales.

Some of the critics of ABARE would like to make out that the GDP reduction of some two per cent which we would experience is insignificant. They overlook two important factors. Firstly, a two per cent reduction in our projected GDP level is far from insignificant. The loss to Australia in 2010 would be about twice the reduction in GDP we experienced in 1990 because of the drought—or half the benefits of micro‐economic reform.

Secondly, dramatic regional dislocation would be experienced in places like the Illawarra and the Hunter in New South Wales, the Bowen Basin and Gladstone in Queensland, Geelong in Victoria, Port Pirie in South Australia and the Kwinana region of Western Australia. The Latrobe Valley would be all but shut down. Major resource projects that are energy intensive would be delayed or cancelled.

Australia is ready to do its part in reducing global gas emissions. Our domestic record is already comparable to that of most OECD countries. We have strong commitments from industry, state governments and local governments, and we are currently drawing that support together into an effective national greenhouse strategy.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation: Funding

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. Can the minister confirm that the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation has had its funding cut to the tune of $300,000 and has been told that it must find alternative sources of funding by September? In light of the fact that Coopers and Lybrand, who reviewed the APSF, recommended that APSF funding should continue, who made the decision to cut their funding and what are the reasons for that decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the issue you have raised. However, the funding is administered by the Minister for Health and Family Services and his portfolio. I have with me a note from the minister, and this might help you. The briefing is that the national secretariat component of the community sector support scheme has recently been reviewed to ensure that funded organisations provide focused and representative input to the health and family services portfolio. The decision about which organisations would continue to be funded under the CSSS was very difficult and, in considering the outcomes of the review, it was necessary to balance the competing demands for limited CSSS funds while at the same time ensuring that the scheme supported the government's priorities.

ANSWER.PARA: As such, it was not a decision about savings but rather a decision about allocating the available funds to meet existing priorities. Dr Wooldridge and Mrs Moylan, who have both been involved in this course, are very pleased with the overall outcomes of the review. It means that organisations at the lower level of funding will receive an increase in their funding level. Several organisations, such as the Deafness Forum of Australia, the Carers Association of Australia and Asthma Australia, move from seed funding to ongoing funding, and two new organisations, Heart Support Australia and the Australian Council for Volunteering, will now be funded.

It is unfortunate that a small number of organisations, including the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, will lose their CSSS funding. There remains, however, a significant capacity for input to aged care policy through other organisations funded under the CSSS. APSF will continue to receive funding at their current level under the scheme from 1 July to 30 September this year, to enable them to investigate other avenues of funding. These arrangements will also apply to the other defunded organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I would like to ask a supplementary question. Has the cut any bearing on the fact that the APSF has been doing its job in acting as a consumer advocate for hundreds and thousands of elderly Australians and has recently been critical of the government's aged care policies? Is the defunding of this peak body nothing but another example of the government cracking down on dissent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a pity for Senator Denman to put it in that context. It would be churlish of me, wouldn't it, to remind the opposition of the treatment of so-called dissident organisations by the previous government, particularly Prime Minister Keating. But, nevertheless, having said that, I think it is important to understand that, from the answer I have already given you, Senator, it was a question of prioritising the needs from the limited budget.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps what the opposition would not realise is that I, for example, and a number of other ministers, have had a long and continuing, and I believe pretty good, working relationship with APSF. I hope that that continues, because they have been pretty supportive of a number of measures which I have been taking in the area of retirement income for pensioners and superannuants. I think the slur that was in your question is not deserved, Senator. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services and concerns electoral matters. Is the minister aware that the Liberal Party proposed to the electoral matters committee that the $1,500 disclosure figure for donations should be radically weakened to $10,000, and that the AEC said that this would allow just under $90,000 per year, or $270,000 per election cycle, to go unreported? Although the committee majority later recommended half that figure, they first stated that `a sum of just $90,000 spread over the state and national branches of a party is hardly likely to engender corruption'. Does the minister agree with this statement? Would it not be contradictory for him and his government to be seen to be significantly loosening the financial rules for political parties at the same time as tightening the rules for parliamentarians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters has brought down its report. That report makes a number of proposals. Those proposals will, of course, be considered by the government in due course, Senator Murray.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am no better informed. Does the government agree that $135,000 or $270,000 are significant amounts? I ask whether the minister read a Weekend Australian article on the `Catch Tim donation scandal' in South Australia, where former Senator Olsen's faction coached the state Labor leader in pursuing a $150,000 donation to the Liberal Party as part of his campaign to bring down his factional opponent of over two decades—then Premier Dean Brown. In this example, was not just $150,000 a very significant amount? Will the government ensure that donations such as this continue to be reported by rejecting this section of the report which was tabled yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is of course concerned to make sure that the electoral system operates in a fair and responsible manner. Within that context, of course we will consider any recommendations which have been brought forward by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. In relation to the Weekend Australian article, the answer is no, I have not read it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Is it true that your government's decisions to lower the income ceiling for child-care assistance, to means test the child-care rebate and to remove operational subsidies from community child-care centres have resulted in fees of $10,000 to $16,000 a year for babies under two and $7,500 to $11,000 a year for children aged between three and five? Minister, how do you expect low income working families to be able to afford such fees? Is it not the case that your policies are forcing parents out of the work force and back to the home?
