Was this consequence of your child-care policies unintended or is it, in fact, precisely what you are trying to achieve?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, it is interesting: we have had this sort of question in one form or another from the opposition over several months now. We also had it for some hours in the Senate estimates committee a week or so ago. I do not think they are prepared to listen to what the facts are. The facts are that in the last year of the Keating government over a billion dollars was spent on child care. Last year, the first year of the Howard government, we spent $1.1 billion. That is an increase of $100 million, or a 10 per cent increase last year over the Keating government's spending. This year, spending on child care will be $1.146 billion. Over the next four years, this government will spend $4.8 billion on child care, and it will continue to grow at three per cent real growth in each of the next four years.

ANSWER.PARA: Since coming to government, we have created over 31,000 new child‐care places at a full-year cost of $86 million. In addition, we have made available a further $31 million over four years to ensure that children with high levels of additional needs get appropriate access to child‐care options. That is hardly the actions of a government trying to cut out child care.

We have had a bit of fanciful footwork by some members of the opposition about this so-called claim that we are sending women back home and that that is somehow some terrible plot. We are doing no such thing. The opposition spokesman was using figures recently which were quite mischievous—or certainly very ignorant and ill-informed. The March figures that she purported to use, saying that women with dependent children were all going home because of our policies, in fact showed that women with dependent children had increased as a proportion of the work force and that it was, in fact, student women and women without dependants who were no longer in the work force.

We have been doing a number of things that in fact are going to actually help women in the work force with their child‐care needs. The one thing that you never hear the opposition talking about is the major reforms in the area of out of school hours care because the focus there is going on the parents and their ability to afford it, not on the centres and their ability to use taxpayers' money to be less efficient than they need be.

Through all the questioning that we had in the Senate estimates committee, the only questions in this area were about how it would affect the centres. There was not one single question about how parents would be affected by out of school hours care. For women in the work force, there is nothing more important than before and after work care. We have a policy of improving access to child care and making it affordable. There is a considerable increase in the child‐care assistance that is going to families, where currently many families get no assistance at all and even those who do stand to gain from the removal of the operating subsidy to some of the out of school hours care centres.

It is something which has been badly needed for a long time and, Senator, as the minister who was responsible for a long time, you of all people should know the holes that were in the system that needed fixing and that this government has had the guts to address. It is a shame that you did not do it. Parents could have been helped more quickly. The problem with your government was that you listened to the unions and the centres; you were not as interested in the parents' access to child care. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note in your answer, Minister, that you ignore the increased costs of child care and admit to the 50,000 women out of the work force in March. How does your Office of the Status of Women view the dramatic increases in the cost of child care and the retreat from the work force of so many women and how does the head of the Office of Status of Women view these increases when a recent article in the New Idea introducing the head of the office is silent on these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I just addressed that very question. Is the senator deaf? That is really stupid. Women with children in fact increased their work force participation during March and it would be a good idea if Senator Crowley went back and had her staff take her through the figures and explain to her just how it worked. It is an absolute nonsense that women are leaving the work force because of child‐care issues. I have already made it clear that some of the child‐care centres were increasing their rates, as they do at the beginning of every year, but that had nothing whatever to do with operational funding cuts and changes to assistance that were taking place in April and July.

ANSWER.PARA: The opposition might find it convenient to pretend that increases is child‐care costs have all been related to that, but in fact the child‐care centres were getting in for their cut very much earlier than there were changes to their finances. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it true that next Monday afternoon, while leaders of Japan, Russia, Britain, Korea and Germany are speaking at the UN Earth Summit in New York, Mr Howard will be taking tea with Baroness Thatcher? Is it also the case that next Thursday, while Presi dent Clinton is travelling to New York from Washington to address the summit, the Prime Minister will be going in the opposite direction, to Washington, to do coffee with Newt Gingrich? Is this what the Prime Minister meant when he promised that Australia would be relaxed and comfortable under his leadership? Why is the Prime Minister headed for has‐beens and hawks instead of seizing this opportunity to give Australia global leadership on the environment, including the problems of deforestation, overpopulation and global warming? (Time expired)

—Madam President, this is a very important trip by the Prime Minister to substantiate our relationship with Britain in the context of contemporary issues, in particular the economic and trade agenda, and to do likewise with the United States a little later on in the trip. There is an inaccuracy in the question from Senator Brown because, as I understand it, Mr Clinton will be travelling from Washington to New York on Monday.
—To meet you.

—And if he is really lucky, he will meet me, that is right. I understand the attempt of Senator Brown to make a bit of fun of the Prime Minister's trip. But it is an important trip in the national interest. It is the first trip by the Prime Minister since the election to both Europe and the United States. They are vitally important relationships for Australia across the whole range of our activities—the economy, trade, defence and in other areas—and I am sure that he will do Australia proud and substantiate relationships that are vitally important.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In response to the economy, trade and defence mix that the minister says the Prime Minister will be representing overseas, will he be raising the issue of the environment at any stage or at any place, even with Baroness Thatcher over the tea cup? When he does finally meet President Clinton back in Washington, will he be in a position to announce that Australia is no longer the only OPEC country which opposes mandatory greenhouse gas targets and has joined Norway in changing its mind and falling into line with the more progressive environmentally minded countries in OPEC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the last two conservative leaders of Britain, he will be speaking of an economy that was left the strongest in Europe. So those issues, particularly employment issues, Senator Brown, may not be of interest to you but they certainly are to us. I have little doubt that the Prime Minister will take the opportunity in Washington to press the issue of Australia's position on greenhouse which is a position that is designed to bring both economic and environmental advantages, which can be done with skilful leadership. Our case is a good case. It is for a fair and achievable Berlin mandate outcome.

ANSWER.PARA: You would have noted, Senator Brown, that we are now starting to make some progress. It is hard work, but those who are working hard are getting results because there is merit on our side and I trust the Prime Minister will have success in convincing President Clinton of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Is it true that Radio Australia's General Manager, Mr Derek White, had a meeting with you to discuss proposals from the BBC World Service and the US State Department for leasing Radio Australia's Darwin transmitter in such a way as would provide sufficient transmitter time to Radio Australia to maintain its full Asian audience? Why did you claim before the Senate estimates committee last Wednesday that you were `not aware of any proposal along those lines'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I did have a discussion with Mr Derek White, who came to see me in my office several weeks ago. It was of a general nature. Mr White was endeavouring to indicate that he would like to see Radio Australia maintain a service emanating from the Cox Peninsula. In particular, he asked me whether there was any particular sanctity about the cut-off date of 1 July, which is the date from which the Expenditure Review Committee and subsequently cabinet had calculated the savings that would flow from the closure of that particular transmission facility. The question I was asked in the estimates committee was in relation to—
—This will be feeble.

—Yes, it is, because I am referring to the question and it is by Senator Schacht. So you are absolutely right; it is a particularly feeble question. We will come to the answer in a moment. Having put your head on the block, you can hardly blame anybody if it gets knocked off. Senator Schacht asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it possible, Minister, that we could be a little bit creative and get a price out of some of these commercial interests or other overseas countries—enough money—to get Radio Australia a bit of free access to the transmitter, so that they can keep their programs going in Asia in the areas they are aiming at and being funded to produce the programs for?

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.

—What do you mean, `Absolutely'? You have no interest in the matter, otherwise you would have asked the question. Why are you palming it off onto someone else who does not understand it any better than you do? I am surprised you get paid, son. You cannot take these rostered days off by sitting in this chamber. If you are going to be the shadow minister, you ought to be able to bowl up the odd underarm at the very least. But, anyway, I will respond. I said, `I am not aware of any proposal along those lines.' In other words, the question was whether Radio Australia was going to get a bit of free access—a classic, grammatical expression; but, nonetheless, that was the question asked. That was not a proposition.
—Why didn't you tell the truth?

—That is an appalling suggestion, Madam President; I will ignore it. The fact is that I am telling the truth in its entirety. Mr White was asking me in general terms whether Radio Australia might be able to remain a user of the service. He was not asking whether it might be able to get free access. Indeed, as I understood it, he was talking more in terms of—
—Oh, you are kidding!

—If you want to ask the wrong question, son, do not blame me if you get the wrong answer. If you want to ask a very specific question about free access, and I tell you that I am not aware of proposals along those lines, can I help it if I am aware of proposals along other lines? The fact is that Mr White asked me in terms of whether other international carriers might have an interest in obtaining facilities, and it may be, of course, that Radio Australia would be able to piggyback on those services. But whether or not they paid for the privilege is obviously a matter of detail and it was not a matter that was addressed in my discussions with Mr White.
—You are kidding.

—If you think I am kidding, then presumably you take the question about as seriously as does Senator Schacht. But the fact is that the government is interested in the issue. We are very concerned to explore the possibilities. I subsequently had discussions to ascertain whether 1 July was an important date. When I discovered that the service could be mothballed and reopened at very short notice, it became apparent to me that we were able to proceed with the original proposal but still accommodate any subsequent interest that might be registered. As I understand it, discussions are still proceeding and no doubt there will be a conclusion in line with those proposals. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I do understand the issue, Minister.
—The minister doesn't.

—That's right. I would just like to draw to your attention the first part of the question, which was not answered. Was there discussion between you and Mr White in relation to the BBC World Service and the US State Department leasing Radio Australia's Darwin transmitter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not claim to have an infallible memory on the subject, but I do recall a discussion about the Voice of Free America, I think it was, or some arm—
—It is the American State Department.

—Do you mind! The bloke who claims he knows a bit about this, in marked contradistinction to his colleague who has formal responsibility, is asking me about the US State Department and I am saying that I do not recall that precise term being used. It may have been. My recollection was more in terms of something specific like Voice of Free America or some such—I am not sure that it is quite the Voice of Free America.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Forshaw interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a different question. If you want to ask me that, then you get Senator Schacht's permission and you get up and have a go later on. I do not recall the BBC being mentioned. As I say, it was a discussion in general terms about whether there might be possibilities worth exploring. As I recall it, the most important single issue as far as Mr White was concerned was the criticality of 1 July, and I have told you my response to that. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. On 14 May 1997, Senator Carr stated, in relation to the budget, `What you will see is a very savage impact on regional universities in particular.' He went on to say, while criticising the government, `What are you doing to defend public education in the regions and towns of this country?' After 13 years of Labor government, young people from country areas of Australia were still under‐represented in higher education. In the government's higher education budget statement last year, this government indicated that the needs of regional universities would be given particular consideration. Will the minister inform the Senate what the government is doing to support regional universities?
— Good question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very good question, Senator Troeth, and I thank you for it. It is a very important issue. People from rural and isolated areas in Australia remain among the most disadvantaged groups in Australia in terms of their access to higher education. It is true that, after a decade of growth in the sector, country people have still not achieved equitable participation in higher education. We believe that a strong network of regional universities is an important foundation for addressing this problem. Despite the predictions of doom and gloom from that creature over there—
—The Bollinger Bolshevik—
—the Bollinger Bolshevik—
—Senator, that is not the way to refer to a colleague in the chamber.

—I am sorry, Madam President. Across Australia as a whole, the number of Commonwealth funded undergraduate places will grow by some 13,000 between 1996 and 1999. That is an across Australia increase of 3.7 per cent. However, Commonwealth funded undergraduate student places in regional universities will grow by 4.5 per cent between 1996 and 1999—that is, there is a stronger growth in the regional areas. That is an extra 3,300 undergraduate student places for regional Australia, student places that will provide opportunities for young people in central and northern regions of Queensland—Senator Reynolds, you should be supporting our policies—and in country areas of New South Wales. That would give others reason to support us as well.

ANSWER.PARA: Enrolments at regional universities are very healthy this year—much to Labor's dismay. Fortunately, students in regional areas have not been deterred from enrolling at university because of all the misleading babble coming from the other side. Preliminary figures from my department show that regional institutions have in fact overenrolled at the undergraduate level by four per cent this year—nearly 3,000 students. Students from country areas, like their city counterparts, are well able to see the value of higher education and the bargain that they are getting through HECS.

As to revenue for teaching, the fact that regional universities are overenrolled at the undergraduate level this year is significant because, from next year, the government will give institutions the minimum up‐front HECS payment for every undergraduate student enrolled above the Commonwealth target—more money than the previous government would have given them. Regional universities, like metropolitan universities, will benefit from this measure.

I have asked my department to do some projections on the income that regional universities will receive for teaching in the period 1996 to 2000, and it makes interesting reading. The operating grant that the Commonwealth pays to regional universities is known, and that will effectively remain the same over this period, at around $870 million. To this base figure we need to add projected payments for overenrolments which, if universities are overenrolled by the same amount as they are this year, would be another $11 million.

If enrolments of fee paying overseas students increase by 10 per cent a year for the next three years, regional universities will earn an additional $60 million a year by the year 2000. That is not an unreasonable proposition. If the enrolments of fee paying postgraduate students grow by 16 per cent a year over the next three years—much less than the growth this year—they will have more money from that.

The bottom line is that the funding for regional universities is assured. Total funding for teaching at regional universities is therefore projected to increase by about eight per cent. Regional universities will benefit from reforms to higher education that we have introduced and the government's commitment to regional Australia is absolutely unequivocal.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to Senator Vanstone, in her capacity as the Minister representing the Attorney‐General. Minister, is it a fact that the firm of Burson‐Marsteller was awarded the guns buyback public relations contract only after the Attorney‐General intervened to have it included on the short‐list? Is it a fact that Mr Jonathan Gaul switched camps in the midst of the selection process to pitch for Burson‐ Marsteller at the ministerial committee meeting? Is it also a fact that Mr Gaul has submitted bills on behalf of his firm of Canberra Liaison for work which the Attorney‐General's Department have been unable to relate to authorised work, even though they have tried for over three months to do so? Minister, is this the same Jonathan Gaul who wrote to businesses after the federal election boasting of his close links to and friendship with coalition ministers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I cannot believe you took the opportunity to demonstrate that you have not been able to keep up with the news. You have asked me a question that relates to matters that were canvassed very adequately in this place last year, and you are simply re‐asking the same questions. You have nothing new to ask. No wonder you people were kicked out of government: you have nothing new to ask. In respect of the first part of your question, I refer you to the numerous questions that were asked in this place and in the estimates committees last year. As to the latter part of your question, I refer you to the answers that you were given only last week. Unless you are suffering from short‐term memory loss, they should be at the forefront of your mind. They are in the Hansard of the estimates committee and I refer you to those answers instead of wasting the Senate's time.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question to you, Minister, goes to the relationship between Mr Gaul and coalition ministers. Is it a fact that this person received favours because of his close relationship with coalition ministers? What inquiries have been made by your government to ensure that the account that he put to the government in respect of the important gun buyback scheme is a legitimate account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel sorry for Senator Bolkus. The pressure of opposition and relevance deprivation is obviously getting to him. He canvassed these questions in the estimates last week and I refer him to the answers he was given then.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, following Senator Denman's question about the government de‐funding of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, I would point out that this cut follows cuts in funding to the United Nations association, the Human Rights Commission, the Family Planning Association, family resource centres, the Australian Conservation Foundation and many others. Minister, are these cuts part of your government's agenda to ensure that any organisation which criticises the government will be closed down? In answer to Senator Denman, you said that the cuts were in line with the government's priorities. Minister, aren't pensioners, migrant women and users of family planning services a priority for your government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —In the answer I gave Senator Denman earlier I thought I gave a pretty detailed coverage of Minister Wooldridge's approach to the question of funding for organisations out of his portfolio. I also have a quotation here from Dr Wooldridge's interview on PM . He pointed out that he had to find new money for some organisations and it was a tough decision as to which organisations were not going to get funded. He said that it is not as if the Family Planning Association or the Pensioners and Superannuants Federation have done a bad job. They have not; they have done a good job. But in the end he decided that it was more important to keep money going for asthma, for carers and for deafness and to find new money for volunteers and for people who had had heart attacks. Nevertheless, he has allowed that extra three months of funding to enable the pensioners and superannuants, for example, to find new sources of funding.

ANSWER.PARA: There is not a lack of sympathy for organisations. For example, in other portfolios, organisations get funded one year and they do not necessarily get funded the next year. It varies from year to year. The previous government was in the habit of doing exactly the same sort of thing. There is nothing new about this. It is not a question of retribution, as has perhaps been implied here today. It has simply been the case that the government has to make sure that some bodies do get some funding some time. To leave some organisations on a permanent fund for a long time is not fair to the others as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, can you name one high profile, independent community group which has been critical of the government and has kept its government funding during the life of this parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I would point you, for example, to ACOSS, which is not funded by my department; they are funded by Dr Wooldridge's department. They have had a bit to say at different times about things that I have been doing in my portfolio. They are still being funded.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw your attention to some of the descriptions which the previous Prime Minister used for people who disagreed with him. For instance, about Hugh Morgan he said:
He has never been thoughtful, and he has never been a thinker. What we have here is just bigotry. It is the voice of ignorance, the voice of hysteria and the voice of the nineteenth century.
He said of Nobby Clark:
Had it not been for . . . subsidies from the Commonwealth Government, Nobby's board would certainly have had him selling shoelaces and pencils in Collins Street.

He said that many Australian business people would not `get going in a barrel of yeast' and he talked of the drones in the Australian banking industry. If you want an example of real retribution, I direct you to those quotations. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, Senator Vanstone. Minister, you are no doubt aware that the Northern Territory police have just paid $440,000 of money levied from taxpayers under the national gun buyback scheme to an individual for 22 Second World War 20 millimetre Hispano-Suiza aircraft cannons which were illegally imported into Australia, which must have seemed like Tattslotto for the owner. You may also be aware that the gun curator of the National War Memorial, Mr Peter Aitken, has stated publicly that `millions' of these old cannons are lying on scrap heaps around the world. The responsibility for this farce has been laid squarely at the feet of the Commonwealth government by the Northern Territory Chief Minister and Minister for Police, Shane Stone. Is the Chief Minister correct in his public assertions? Is the Commonwealth responsible for this? If so, can you explain to the levy payers why their money was spent in this way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I was up in the territory last week and I saw some press coverage of this matter. I do not have a brief on it from the Attorney. I will get it for you. I am sure it will make interesting reading. I will read it before I give it to you because it sounds like an interesting story.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Can the minister inform the Senate of the outcomes from the recent meeting of Australia's environment ministers in the form of the National Environment Protection Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will recall that this process was started in about 1992 but Labor was unable in the remaining years of its government to even arrange one face‐to‐face meeting of ministers. I am pleased to say that now under the coalition government, with good cooperation around Australia between environment ministers, real progress is being made. For Australians who are vitally interested in issues of environmental protection, that is good news.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, at the meeting of the National Environment Protection Council last Friday in Cairns, it was decided to release in terms of the act a draft national pollutant inventory. This is another subject that Labor talked about for years but was not able to deliver to the Australian people. This will enable Australians to have the information that they deserve and are entitled to about emissions into the air, land and water in their local environment. It will provide individual communities and business with detailed information about pollution emitted into the environment, whether it be from nearby industry or passing traffic. When established, the NPI will pinpoint emission areas down to the size of the postcode zones of residential and industrial areas across Australia.

The NPI is a process that we expect to be concluded early next year after we have been through the statutory period of consultation. To implement it successfully, I can advise that we have been having trials in Port Pirie, Launceston, Newcastle and Dandenong. They have been undertaken successfully. We have also initiated three new programs to help a successful implementation. The first is with Western Mining Corporation and the Western Australian government, which will begin a trial in Western Australia, particularly looking at areas of industrial and mining emissions. Secondly, the New South Wales EPA is developing emission estimation techniques, which will assist industry to implement the NPI. Thirdly, the Queensland government, in partnership with my department, is planning an integrated trial of the NPI in south-east Queensland.

You can see that it is a cooperative venture with governments and with the private sector to deliver to the community the information to which they are entitled. In order that the information might then be properly disseminated to the public, my department continues with its development of an on‐line interactive Internet database, through which the public will receive this information.

Secondly, we have released an official's draft of an ambient air quality measure. You will be aware that the issue of air quality is the highest issue of environmental importance to the Australian public. This measure will set air quality standards, targeting the six most significant pollutants to which the majority of Australians are exposed—carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, photochemical oxidants, sulfur dioxide, lead and particles.

Thirdly, the NEPC is proceeding to a measure on the movement of hazardous wastes across state and territory boundaries and also a measure on the approach to contaminated site assessments. In the future, it will be producing national measures on diesel emissions, ambient water quality and waste minimisation. You will see from that that this body is now active in producing outcomes for the benefit of all Australians that will lead to a better environment for them and their families to live in.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, representing the Minister for Defence. Minister, is it true that the first draft of the upcoming defence strategic review has been completely discarded by the government? Was the decision to discard it made on the basis that it advocated an interventionist stance, including in north Asia? Is it a fact that General John Baker and Mr Hugh White have had to completely rewrite it, and will the strategic review be released on time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The strategic review has not been completed. It is a classified document, as it always has been under previous governments. I am not about to comment on the content of either the final document or drafts along the way. I do not think that the senator, who had some experience in the defence portfolio before she came back as a senator, would be expecting me to answer that question.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—I have a little supplementary information for Senator Schacht. His question to me yesterday regarded the transfer of power to the provisional legislature in Hong Kong. I undertook to seek further advice on whether representations were made to the government from other countries with a view to boycotting the swearing‐in ceremony. I think I said in my answer that I suspected that the government might not be of a mind to provide such information. As a result of seeking that further information, I have to advise Senator Schacht that I have nothing to add to the answer I gave yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop today, relating to private health insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —She's not answering.

—Senator McKiernan is absolutely correct: at no stage during her answer, and in the answer to the supplementary question, did Senator Newman, who is the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, attempt to deal with the issues raised in the question. I remind the Senate that the minister was asked a specific question: was the government aware of advice being given out by the Taxpayers Association of Australia which encourages people, particularly those on high incomes, to avoid the Medicare levy increase and, at the same time, continue to use the public hospitals system?

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that, when this government came to office, it trumpeted loudly how it was going to solve the problem of the declining membership of private health funds. It introduced two specific measures. Firstly, it introduced a measure which was to provide a rebate of up to $450 per year for persons who took out private health insurance. Secondly, it introduced an increase of one per cent in the Medicare levy, which would apply to persons who did not take out private health insurance.

The theory was that, by their having to pay that extra one per cent levy, the high income earners in particular would be forced to take out private health insurance. I well recall the Treasurer, Mr Costello, saying that this was a charge that he hoped he would never have to collect. He hoped that it would force high income earners who did not have private health insurance to take out health insurance. The theory was that, rather than paying $1,500 or $2,000 in tax if you happened to earn $150,000 or $200,000 a year, and then continue to pay your own health costs and be treated as a public patient, you would opt for private health insurance.
The fact of the matter is that these proposals are simply not working. The industry is saying that. For instance, in last Sunday's Sun‐Herald a spokesman for the HCF is quoted. The article says:
. . . the Federal Government's prediction that people would flock to private health insurance to avoid paying the tax `sounded great in theory, but it hasn't happened so far'.

Of course, it is not going to happen. You would expect that, if people were going to avail themselves of the opportunity to take out private health insurance and avoid a higher Medicare levy, they would have done so by now. It is a system that is just about to come into force.

The second and most important point—this was really the nub of the question that was asked which the minister failed to answer—is that it is possible for high income earners to avoid paying the Medicare levy increase—the one per cent—where that amount is substantially higher than taking out the cheapest form of private health insurance, that is, taking out the discounted private health insurance packages that are available.

As was indicated in the question, and as has been reported, the Australian Taxpayers Association is actually advising people to do this. They are saying, `You can go to a private health fund and purchase private health insurance on a discounted basis for, say, $500 or $650 a year. If you happen to be earning $120,000 a year, you are no longer going to have to pay that one per cent levy, or $1,200.'

TALK.START.PARA: —They've taken out private health insurance.

—`They have taken out private health insurance,' Senator Ferguson says. But the point of the matter is that the health insurance these people are going to take out in order to avoid that higher levy is the health insurance that will still mean they will continue to be treated as public patients in public hospitals—clearly contrary to the intention of this government.

BREAK.PARA: That is the advice that the Taxpayers Association is actually giving people. The association is saying to people, `You don't have to pay the one per cent levy. Go and buy the cheapest form of private health insurance on the market but continue to rely upon the public hospital system when you happen to need hospital care.' That is going to do absolutely nothing to encourage people to opt for private health cover. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say, as I have said before, there is a very hollow ring to the concern of the ALP about the need to attract people back into private health insurance, when one considers that they set out with Medicare to destroy the private health insurance industry and to destroy the whole private health sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Regardless of what they say, I am sure that was the political objective of the ALP—that is, to introduce a state health system to Australia—and that is what has happened. When the March quarter figures came out this year, they showed that just 33.2 per cent of the Australian population now have private health insurance. Before Labor came into power in 1983, somewhere close to 80 per cent had it.
—That is a gross distortion of history. How many had no coverage at all, Senator Eggleston?
—Those people, Senator Collins, had access to private hospitals.
—Oh, really!

—They were well treated there. Most people had private health insurance and availed themselves of the private health sector. What has happened since Medicare was introduced has been the destruction, as I have said, of the private health sector. We have seen long waiting lists in public hospitals, an underutilised private hospital sector and close to the collapse of the community rating factor in our private health insurance industry—which meant that our health funds insured everybody regardless of their history.

BREAK.PARA: What it seems we are looking at now is a situation where the Australian private health insurance industry can no longer operate on a community rating basis and may have to go to the kinds of policies which are offered in America—where people either insure for specific illnesses or, if they have specific illnesses, are excluded from private health insurance. That is the triumph of Medicare and, as I have said before, I think the ALP should hold their heads in shame over what they have achieved.

What the government packages offer from 1 July are inducements to get people back into the private health sector so that the private hospitals can be used and some of the pressure can be taken off the public hospitals. Let me just run quickly through the list of inducements which will operate from 1 July, either as an up‐front deduction off premiums or as a tax rebate at the end of the year.

Firstly, singles earning up to $35,000 a year can claim between $100 and $125 per annum. Couples earning up to $70,000 a year can claim between $200 and $250 a year. Couples earning up to $70,000 a year and with a child can claim $350 to $450. The threshold rises by $3,000 with each additional child.

Individuals who do not have private health insurance and earn more than $50,000 a year will pay an extra one per cent Medicare levy on their taxable income. Couples who earn over $100,000 per year who have children and who do not have private cover will also have to pay the extra one per cent on their Medicare levy.

These measures are designed to get people back into private health insurance, to redress the drift away and to overcome in some small way the legacy Labor created of the hopeless situation we have in Australia at the moment—with overcrowded public hospitals, long waiting lists and crowded outpatient departments alongside empty private hospitals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —We just had an interesting recitation from Senator Eggleston. He obviously is one of those members of the Liberal Party who has a policy of getting rid of Medicare. What else would be the basis of his attack on Labor and its policy to support Medicare? He just made an outrageous outburst and attacked Labor for introducing the most forward‐looking health reform this country has seen this century.

SPEECH.PARA: When we did hear from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) in yet another one of her non‐answers—it was another question this side has asked during question time and not received a reasonable or proper answer to—we were told, `We have discovered health insurance.' Let me say clearly that this side of the chamber knows more about this issue than does the government.

We said this scheme would not achieve the results the government claimed. That has been borne out now not only by the continuing reduction in the number of people who hold health insurance and the continuing decline in health insurance applicable to families, but also by the fact that the health insurance funds have taken the government's move as a signal to increase their premiums. If anything that, combined with the public's distaste for the private health insurance system and the way that people are loaded up with extra charges after they have paid their premium, has driven more people away.

When we look at the figures, we see that, since the government announced its policy, HCF has increased its premiums by more than 12 per cent, its second premium increase this year; Medibank Private, by up to 23 per cent; Manchester Unity, by 17½ per cent; MBF, by 15 per cent; and Australian Unity, approaching 20 per cent. So we have seen people pay more now in terms of their premiums and, when they get the rebate, they will still be worse off.

Why would this government be able to say with any authority that they know more than we do about health insurance? Clearly they do not. Their scheme has backfired. It is costing people more and it is driving more people away from private health insurance. Not only is it not going to increase the amount of take‐up of private health insurance but people who are allegedly going to pay more because they did not take it out will find a way to get a backdoor reduction in the tax they would have had to pay by joining up to what is a health insurance scheme that you have when you do not really have health insurance. As was outlined in the question, to save $530, an income earner on $120,000 can take out a $670 premium which is not really going to be of great assistance to them. The main benefit of the premium is to avoid the tax they would have to pay if they did not take it out. Those people will still have access, as is conceded my Minister Wooldridge, to the public health system.

We have a dodgy health scheme and we have no saving to the public health system if these high income earners choose these low cost schemes. For them the public health system will remain the cheapest option. The cost of fund membership growth has negated the benefit to families who were promised a net benefit out of the government's scheme. As I said before, in most cases those families are going to pay more, even with the government rebates.

Minister, we understand this system much better than you do. That is obvious by the outcome of your policies. Your policies are costing families more, not less. People are voting against these proposals by continuing to desert fund membership. Now the income that you were planning to receive through the government charging high income earners a higher levy will be reduced without any real effect on the demand for public health services.

The Australian Taxpayers Association, in their magazine Taxpayer, has published this scheme, which means that this will be widespread knowledge. We can therefore expect those people to use the scheme to employ various mechanisms to minimise their tax burden. The Taxpayers Association, in an article in the Daily Telegraph Mirror on 10 June, said that the health funds provided the tip—that is, MBF in particular—on how high income earners could save on their Medicare levy. As I said, the minister has said it is viable. Provided they are prepared to use this scheme, there will be no saving out of the government's rebate—there will be a cost to the community. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it absolutely fascinating that we are yet again having this debate considering it has been generated by a Labor Party that was in government for 13 years and that, over the entire period, showed absolutely no regard whatsoever for declining private health insurance membership. We have seen it drop from over 60 per cent to just over 32 per cent under the administration of the very people who have raised this debate here today. Surely they are not trying to convince the parliament or the Senate or me that they are now born‐again advocates of the private health insurance industry. They could not give a continental because if they did care something about the private health insurance industry they would have done something about it in the 13 years of their administration.

SPEECH.PARA: They presided over a government that made sure that everything they did was designed to ensure the decline progressed as opposed to the decline being arrested. To hear Senator O'Brien talking about people continuing to desert fund membership as though it is some fault of a government that has been in office for 15 months is nothing short of amazing, because it was the Labor government, the party of which he is a member, that made sure that the decline came about.

We have a situation today where Australia's public health care system has always involved health care providers from both the private and the public sectors. Yet here we have an opposition, which has presided over the decline of private health insurance, nitpicking and criticising every single solitary initiative that this government is taking to ensure that that is turned around. Not only that, they are crystal ball gazing about the results of what is going to happen on 1 July as if the initiative has been in place for 15 months. It is just absolutely remarkable.

Let me remind you, Madam Deputy President, of what the previous government did because the Labor Party will refuse to remind themselves of these short facts. The previous government—your former Labor government, Senator Forshaw and Senator O'Brien—took out $846 million from the private sector. Yet you come in here today criticising initiatives for getting people back in the system. You abolished the bed day subsidy. You removed the reinsurance subsidy. You required the funds to pay a 25 per cent gap for medical benefits. We are restoring much of this funding through the private health insurance incentive scheme and you have the gall to come in here and criticise the initiative. Maybe Senator Crowley will take the opportunity to stand up here and explain to the Senate and to the people of Australia why it was her government that took out $846 million from the private health system.

This government supports the application of the principles of competition in the health arena. It supports the financing of health services on the basis of output and outcomes rather than inputs. It supports health services that provide continuity and integration of care; that find ways to break down artificial boundaries between providers, between the public and private sectors and between levels of government; and that improve our national performance in public health and especially in prevention. But we do not hear anything about that from the Labor senators any more—not a word. We hear nothing about making sure people get quality health care or about equality in access, because we had 13 years of a Labor government that made sure the whole system went down the gurgler. Now they are doing nothing but criticise everything that is designed to turn around what they created.

This government is about meeting increasing demands. Medicare needs to be able to evolve and adapt itself to meet the changing conditions, something that the Labor government failed to enable it to do. The state and territory governments are investigating the use of the private sector to provide public hospital services. This reflects changes in the nature of public health service delivery, which means that it is often better and more efficient for some hospital related services to be provided in the community. But these changes will be explored in the context of negotiating the next Medicare agreement. You know that to be true and you should stop distorting the facts. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to rise on this matter and, first of all, to say to Senator Eggleston, `Sometimes you actually get your facts right, but you got them very wrong today.' Firstly, do you know what Medicare did, Senator? It dealt with the two million Australians who had no insurance in the years of the Fraser government. You made sure that there were two million Australians with no insurance cover at all—people who stayed away in droves from doctors and hospitals because they were terrified of big bills. Medicare fixed that. The Australian people voted strongly for Medicare. You went to the last election swearing that you would defend it to the death and protect it forever. It is another broken promise of yours. If you look at the polling, already the community is saying, `They have broken that promise. If you want health care, if you want Medicare, vote Labor.' So you are done on that one, Senator.
—Is that why you're behind us?

—We are ahead on Medicare, Senator, so you just watch out! We are here today taking note of Senator Newman's answer. Firstly, Senator Newman had no answer. Secondly, very importantly, she contradicted what the spokesperson for her Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) said on this strategy. Senator Forshaw brought to the attention of this place the proposal for how people on the top incomes can avoid paying their full private health insurance costs and dodge their liability. An article quotes the spokesman for Dr Wooldridge as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone with private health insurance could opt not to use it and rely on public hospitals instead, he said.
But he said if high income earners adopted this plan it would undermine government attempts to relieve the burden on the public hospital system by forcing more people into the private system.

That is what Minister Wooldridge admits and what Senator Newman could not admit in this place: that this proposal runs counter to government policy. She should have at least been able to say that, but she could not. She defended, in a vapid and pathetic way, what is quite clearly a strategy that is counter to your government policy, which your health minister admits.

It is about time that he admitted that something was wrong because what you are doing by way of policy to help people is spending $1.6 billion dollars of taxpayers' precious dollars. There is no money for pensioners and superannuants. There is modest money for family planning services. There is no money for the Non‐English Speaking Background Women's Association—$40,000 or $50,000. But there is $1.6 billion to subsidise people who will not take out private health insurance—subsiding people to pay for costs, which subsidy rebate has already gone in the massive increase in private health insurance costs.

The previous Labor government were passionately concerned that people get access to good health care. That is why they introduced Medicare to make sure that that good health care was introduced in a way that did not cripple those people with huge debts. What you get with private health insurance are big debts. Senator Eggleston says that we are overloading the public hospital system; people are queuing up to get in. Of course they are. Why? Because it is so good. That is where the health care is good. It is where the doctors direct you and where the cost is no extra than your Medicare levy. Why wouldn't people go there? It is a very good thing to do.

Senator Eggleston also says that there are underutilised private hospital beds all around this country. If that is the case, why are we now seeing more and more people trying to build private hospitals? Probably because they are making the same daft decisions that they have always made in private health. There are $1.6 billion precious taxpayer dollars going to subsidise people in private health insurance. Now we have a system where people can actually avoid their full responsibility for private insurance. They can duck out of about $530 by way of advice from the Taxpayers Association. Under your bizarre system, people on the top end of town, who might have contributed a little bit to some kind of equity, are actually being encouraged to avoid the system.

BREAK.PARA: Minister Wooldridge admits that it is undercutting the intention of his proposals, but Senator Newman in this place could not bring herself to say that—either she could not or she did not know the answer and, on the evidence, it is more likely the latter. Senator Newman did not understand and did not know the answer. Your policies are outrageous; they are not working; they are costing the taxpayers thousands of dollars. Citizens in this country wanted Medicare. They trusted Mr Howard with it. He has broken their promise and they will not trust him with it at the next ballot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley has ranted and raved on the other side of the chamber. I remind people about what happened with her major contribution to health when the Labor Party were in government. Mr Howe, the then minister for health, went around the whole community selling a package of a co‐payment for people to attend general practitioners. As a member of the Left that must have been quite a difficult thing for him to do, but he had a commitment. Three reports that were given to us in estimates committees showed that there was about a 75 per cent acceptance of a co‐payment in the community. What happened about that?

—On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: I understand that quite often people might range a bit wide of the topic, but the question and the answer were specifically directed to private health insurance and to the issue of coverage for public and private hospitals. Senator Patterson is talking about co‐payments and fees for general practitioners, which are way off the subject.
—I am sure that Senator Patterson is going to get to the more specific details but it is a really wide ranging debate.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I appreciate your ruling. Senator Crowley did not like the idea of a co‐payment and, despite the fact that the community accepted it and despite the fact that Mr Howe said that it would reduce the pressure on people attending general practi tioners, and that therefore there would be more money in the system to fund public hospitals, et cetera, Mr Keating, in order to get Senator Crowley's vote, totally wiped it out. So a policy that was actually going to do something to reduce overservicing was wiped out because Senator Crowley did not like it, and Mr Keating needed one or two votes to oust Mr Hawke. So do not let Senator Crowley come in here and pretend that she has got all the answers to health.

SPEECH.PARA: On this issue of health and health insurance, when Labor was in government they could not even make up their minds. On the one hand, in 1993, Mr Keating said:

Medicare is working so well that people are leaving the private health system and joining the public health system. In fact, if anything, Medicare has been very successful in taking clientele from the private health system to the public health system.

That just showed how out of touch he was. People were saying, `We can't afford private health insurance. We want it, but we can't afford it.' At the same time in the same year, Senator Richardson said:
At a bare minimum, we must try to stop the decline in private health insurance.

When we started off in 1983, it was 63 per cent: almost two‐thirds of all Australians were covered by private health insurance. By 1996, under 13 years of Labor, it was 34 per cent. Senator Richardson knew. No wonder he got out of here and went off and did other things. He could not bear to be with you any longer because he was saying these sorts of things when his Prime Minister was saying, `It's all wonderful. Everything in the garden is rosy. Medicare's really working. They are just leaving the private health insurance system because the public health system is so good.' That is not what Senator Richardson was saying.

I just want to remind honourable senators on the other side of this. I do not know whether they read their policies before they went to the election last time. Have they read their health policy? Have they gone back and read their health policy? I reckon the new parliamentary secretary should go back and read their health policy because Labor's health policy says:

BREAK.PARA: Many families with children—around 40 per cent—already take out health insurance—
that was really stretching the figures anyway—
to meet the health needs of their families . . . Many other families would like to take out health insurance to better manage—
which is the most split infinitive, but do not worry about that. It should be `to manage better' or `better to manage'—
their health costs but find the premiums too high.

TALK.START.PARA: —`To better manage' is quite correct English.
—Go and read—
—Order! Senator Patterson and Senator Forshaw, through the chair, please.
—It continues:

BREAK.PARA: These families will be able to claim $350 to this cost.
So in their own policy they were going to give an incentive for people to take up private health insurance and here they are now today—

TALK.START.PARA: —They had forgotten.

—They did not read it. They had forgotten that that is what they were going to say. When we first talked about this, Dr Wooldridge said, `Mr Beazley shows his ignorance on health insurance,' and it is exactly the selective amnesia that the parliamentary secretary and Senator Crowley have shown.

BREAK.PARA: They actually forgot to remind us that this was part of their policy. They had stolen it. They said, `Here's a good idea. We've got private health insurance bleeding,' and, as Senator Richardson said, `we've got to find some way to get it back.' In their own policy, they were advocating a payment to people who take out private health insurance. Now on the other side they have had some sort of conversion on the road to Damascus and they have to oppose every single thing because it does not suit them, because they cannot now be big enough to say, `We need to get people back into private health insurance.' (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongarra sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate their extreme concern at the proposal to charge entry fees for people needing nursing home care. Furthermore, the petitioners are extremely concerned that the charging of up front entry fees will force people to sell their homes in order to gain a nursing home bed.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate act to ensure that access to nursing home care is available on the basis of need and further that the family home is exempt from any asset test used to determine eligibility for such care.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Public Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned members of staff of the Australian Public Service (APS) express strong dissatisfaction with the Government's current approach to workplace relations in the APS, especially its intention not to negotiate an APS‐wide Agreement on pay and conditions of service. The undersigned believe that any agency level agreements should be subordinate to an APS‐wide agreement on common core conditions, negotiated on their behalf by experienced union negotiators. The undersigned are opposed to the use of Australian Workplace Agreements in the APS.

Your petitioners request that the Senate take the strongest measures it can to persuade the Government to agree to negotiate on an APS‐wide basis, including serious consideration of the Log of Claims of the Community and Public Sector Union. Your petitioners further request that the Senate closely scrutinise the Government's consultative process for revising the APS Act, and rigorously oppose any amendments to the Act which would fragment and weaken the ability and morale of the APS to maintain its high level of service to the Australian people.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Calvert, Sen Paul; West, Sen Sue
PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned nurses and members of the public shows their concerns with the Aged Care Bill 1997 and the accompanying changes to the funding and regulation of Aged Care announced by the Government in the 1996 Budget. In particular regarding the abolition of specific funding for the provision of nursing care to residents of nursing homes.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate amend the Aged Care Bill 1997 so as to provide a requirement that funding of aged care be in such a form that specific funds are allocated to aged care providers for the provision of nursing care to nursing home residents and that aged care providers be allowed to spend that money only on the provision of nursing care to nursing home residents.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert(from 35 citizens)and Senator West(from 22,417 citizens)

STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 WINTER SITTINGS
MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3)

PARA.EMPHASIS: Purpose of Bill

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will make amendments to the provisions in the Migration Act 1958 ("the Act") relating to the Migration Agents Registration Scheme (MARS).

MARS was established to provide consumer protection for visa applicants from unscrupulous and/or incompetent migration agents. The scheme's main elements are to act as a register of agents and assess their proficiency, and to administer and enforce a legally binding code of conduct to guide agents in their business activities.
The proposed amendments will ensure that MARS can continue beyond 21 September 1997 for a further six months.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reasons for Introduction and Passage in 1997 Winter Sittings

SPEECH.PARA: Subsection 333(1) of the Act contains a statutory sunset provision which will automatically terminate the entire MARS scheme on 21 September 1991. Following a review of MARS the Government has decided on changes to the existing scheme.

The review recognised that the MARS scheme had assisted in improving consumer protection and the performance and reputation of the industry. It was supportive of the migration advice industry moving to self regulation as a means of continuing consumer protection, improving competency standards and reducing the compliance costs of regulation on business.

However, the Government recognised that the industry was not yet ready to take on regulation without the backing of statute and assistance in developing the infrastructure to self regulate. Consequently, the Government has decided to introduce a form of self regulation supported by statute as a transitional stage with an eventual move to full self regulation.

Under "statutory" self regulation, regulatory power is delegated to an industry association and, subject to an agreement between the association and the Minister, the association takes on the administration and enforcement of regulation. It is proposed that legislation will be introduced shortly to implement this arrangement.

Introduction and passage of this Bill in the Winter sittings is sought to enable MARS to continue after 21 September 1997 for a further six months while the Bill implementing changes to the scheme is considered by Parliament. Legal advice indicates that it will not be possible to revive the existing scheme if the sunset clause is not amended before 21 September 1997 and that it may be necessary to refund substantial sums which have been paid as migration agent registration fees.
(Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 WINTER SITTINGS
ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT (TSRA) BILL 1997

The Government considers that the current arrangements in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 for funding the Torres Strait Regional Authority (TSRA) insufficiently recognise its separate status.

Consequently, it seeks to introduce and pass this Bill to enable the Parliament to appropriate funds directly to the TSRA, rather than through the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) as is currently the case. Both the TSRA and ATSIC support this change.

The Government considers it desirable to implement the new funding arrangements for the TSRA for the 1997-98 year. For this to occur, the Bill will need to be introduced and passed during the current sittings

Moreover, the Bill is not complex and the nature of its purpose and subject mater is not controversial. Consequently, the Government does not believe that extended debate on the Bill will prove necessary.

Given this, should the Bill be exempted from the cut-off rule, the Government will seek to have it scheduled for debate and passed this sittings during time set aside for non‐controversial legislation.
The Government considers this a reasonable course of action given the nature of the Bill and seeks Senate support for exempting it from the cut‐off rule.
(Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This bill proposes amendments to remove the budget for the Torres Strait Regional Authority (TSRA) from the budget for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) effective from the 1997/98 budget.

The Torres Strait Regional Authority (TSRA) was established, on 1 July 1994, following a review of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 which recognised the separate and distinct nature of Torres Strait Islanders.

The current funding arrangements for the TSRA require the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to consult the Chairperson of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, the Chairperson of the TSRA and the Commissioner representing the Torres Strait zone on the TSRA's budget.

Since its establishment on 1 July 1994, the TSRA has demonstrated its ability to discharge its functions and responsibility in an exemplary manner. As the TSRA matures, increased autonomy should be accorded to enable it to manage its own affairs and prioritise its functions. The separation of funding arrangements from ATSIC would facilitate this.

This bill amends the act to allow the TSRA to negotiate its estimates directly rather than through ATSIC. Its budget bids will be competing with all of the Commonwealth government's other spending priorities.
The amendments are in line with the government's policy of the TSRA becoming more autonomous from ATSIC.
Madam President I commend the bill to the Senate.

Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the Spring sittings 1997, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.
