The responses read as follows—
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE—SENATE EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING REFERENCES COMMITTEE.
REPORT OF THE INQUIRY INTO THE AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL TRAINING AUTHORITY.
The Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee tabled the report on the Inquiry into the operation of the Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) on
30 November 1995.

The committee acknowledges that the establishment of ANTA represents a good working example of cooperative federalism, but recognises that there is a requirement for fine tuning and modification in some areas and for this reason has made a number of recommendations for the improvement of the operation of the ANTA Agreement.

Progress has been made on implementing a number of the committee's recommendations. Several recommendations are being considered further in discussions with the states and territories on a revised ANTA Agreement. It is the commonwealth's objective to have a revised Agreement finalised as early as possible in 1997.

In relation to committee recommendations 3, 5 and 11 the government, through the ANTA Ministerial Council (MINCO), has made a commitment to the development of a national vocational education and training (VET) system that is responsive to and accessible by business, including small and medium enterprises. It is the government's intention to ensure that business is given a leadership role in the system and that training provided is relevant to business needs.

Recommendations 6, 7 and 8 are being addressed through the recently established ANTA Performance Review Committee and the National Advisory Committee on Vocational Education and Training Statistics (NACVETS). The Performance Review Committee will advise the ANTA Board on an appropriate set of Key Performance Indicators for VET. The commonwealth regards the development of better national data and performance outcomes as one of the primary objectives of its involvement in the ANTA Agreement. NACVETS will be the vehicle for addressing improvements to data collection methods and will provide advice and policy direction on national information requirements.

In relation to recommendation 15 and Minority Report recommendation 7, it is a priority of the government to work with the states and territories to create a national VET system that is accessible and equitable to all groups in the community. The government recognises the importance of TAFE as a key provider of VET in Australia, particularly in regional areas, and recognises the important social and "second chance" role that TAFE plays in providing further education and training for students from disadvantaged groups. Within this objective, the allocation of funds to individual training providers is a matter for state Training Agencies.

Recommendation 16 is currently being addressed through work being undertaken by ANTA in developing national principles for the operation of group training companies (GTCs). This work includes consideration of funding arrangements for GTCs and how governments purchase group training services, with the overall objective of increasing the number of apprentices and trainees.

In response to recommendation 17 and Minority Report recommendation 4 the government has taken steps to ensure that schools will have an increasing role in vocational education as providers of accredited training, particularly for students seeking to begin apprenticeships and traineeships while they are still at school. The government's reforms to the apprenticeship and traineeship system incorporate key initiatives for school to work transition. In the 1996‐97 budget $187 m over four years has been provided for school VET programs.

The government supports the need for ongoing professional development of VET teachers referred to in recommendation 18 and Minority Report recommendation 5. A committee has been established by ANTA CEOs to address professional development issues. In addition, the National Council for Vocational Education Research (NCVER) has been funded by ANTA to conduct research into VET professional development.

In relation to recommendations 19 and 20 and Minority Report recommendation 2, the ANTA act was amended in December 1996 to increase the size of the ANTA Board from five to seven members. MINCO Ministers will be consulted on appointments to the additional places. The government will be seeking to ensure broader business participation on the Board.

The government's position on the recommendations relating to use of growth funds and planning arrangements will be addressed in the context of the development of a revised ANTA Agreement. The revised agreement will also address the recommendations of the Report of the Review of the ANTA Agreement commissioned by the Council of Australian Governments.
committee recommendations that will be addressed in the context of the development of a revised ANTA Agreement are 1, 2, 4, 9, 10, 12, 13 and 14.

It is envisaged that, under a revised ANTA Agreement, there will be streamlined planning and improved accountability arrangements to replace the current State Training Profiles. The commonwealth and the states/territories would continue to provide funding stability for the national VET system.
The following Minority Report recommendations are inconsistent with the government's position on new arrangements for the national VET system for the reasons stated:

1 The proposed new national planning and accountability arrangements to be introduced with the revised ANTA Agreement will outline clear responsibilities for State Training Authorities and will focus on the achievement of national objectives. It is not the role of ANTA or the commonwealth to intervene in the internal operations of State Training Agencies.
3 The government's proposed new funding arrangements allow for future growth to be derived from increased efficiencies.
6 The government supports the use of competitive arrangements where these contribute to increased efficiency and effectiveness in the VET sector.

8 and 9 The National Framework for the Recognition of Training (NFROT) will be superseded by the National Training Framework (NTF). The NTF will provide the basis for mutual recognition through nationally consistent quality assurance arrangements. The NTF will continue to be competency‐based.
10 The revised ANTA Agreement will reinforce the partnership nature of the national VET arrangements. It is appropriate for the MINCO Secretariat to continue to be located within ANTA.
11 and 12 The government supports continued shared responsibility for vocational education and training between the commonwealth and the states and territories.

PARA.EMPHASIS: FIFTH REPORT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND THE ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER LAND FUND:
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Annual Reports for 1994-95 Prepared Pursuant to Part 4A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989

SPEECH.PARA: PREAMBLE

The Fifth Report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund related to annual reports for 1994‐95 prepared pursuant to Part 4A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 (ATSIC Act).

The annual report of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, including the financial statements, was prepared by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), which has administrative responsibility for the Land Fund. The report was published as Appendix 14 of the ATSIC Annual Report.

The Indigenous Land Corporation (ILC) published a separate annual report, including the financial statements for the Corporation. They provided an overview of the operation of the Land Fund on the basis of its significance as a funding source, stating correctly that it was administered by ATSIC.
Both annual reports covered only the period of one month from 1 June to 30 June 1995, as the legislation only came into effect at 1 June.
The report contains two specific recommendations, and formal responses to those recommendations are attached.
The Committee made reference to the short‐comings in ATSIC's administration of the Land Fund in relation to a draw down towards the end of the financial year and the reporting of that transaction.

ATSIC remains of the view that the payment to the ILC through the draw down arrangement (an advance and a draw down) facilitated the avoidance of an early redemption of an investment and thus a loss in revenue to the Land Fund.

ATSIC and ILC thank the Committee for very detailed comments on requirements for the annual reports, and the suggestions will be taken into consideration when compiling the respective 1995‐96 reports.
The attached responses relate to recommendations 4 and 5. Recommendations 1, 2 and 3 are contained in the Committee's fourth report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RECOMMENDATION 4
That the ILC and ATSIC coordinate their annual reporting on Land Fund matters to ensure consistency, completeness and accuracy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports Recommendation 4 on the basis that cross referencing occur in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund report and the Indigenous Land Corporation report to identify the role of the other organisation, and the complementary reporting responsibilities. The cross referencing would be along the lines suggested by the Committee at para 3.2:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "In its next report, that for 1995‐96, the ILC should ensure that it articulates fully the limitations of its reporting pursuant to Part 4A of the ATSIC Act and notes the legislative reporting requirements that should be covered by ATSIC's reporting at the Minister's direction"

SPEECH.PARA: Information about the structure of the Land Fund in the ILC report was not intended to be a repetition of reporting required by ATSIC.
The reporting requirements, together with references to the relevant sections of Part 4A of the ATSIC Act, have been clearly described in the 1995/96 annual reports of both the ILC and ATSIC.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RECOMMENDATION 5

SPEECH.PARA: That, pursuant to s.193I(1) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989, the Minister request a single coordinated annual report for 1995‐96 about the administration of the Land Fund.

The Government does not support Recommendation 5, however in the interest of combining all relevant information in one document, the ILC has reproduced Appendix 11 of the 1995/96 ATSIC Annual Report which relates to the operation of the Land Fund, at Appendix 1 of their 1995/96 Annual Report .
We believe that it is important to stress to the Committee and other readers of annual reports that ATSIC and the ILC:
. have different responsibilities, roles and functions under the legislation;
. are accountable in different ways to (in some respects) different stake holders;
. are distinct legal entities;
. have separate administrative structures and processes; and
. have different reporting obligations under the Act.
The Government believes that coordination in Recommendation 4 will support the recognition of this separateness.

Advice from the Department of Finance, which is responsible for policy on annual reports of Statutory Authorities, is that there must be separate annual reports, although this should not necessarily preclude the publication of a single document encompassing both reports which has occurred in the production of the 1995/96 ILC Annual Report as noted above.

GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY.
LAW ENFORCEMENT IN AUSTRALIA—AN INTERNATIONAL PERSPECTIVE

The Report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee (PJC-NCA), which summarises some of the topics discussed at a meeting the committee held with Mr Raymond Kendall QPM, Secretary General, International Criminal Police Organisation (Interpol), was tabled in the Parliament on 24 February 1 997.

The committee report has concluded that inter-agency cooperation at an international level is essential in order to benefit Australia's readiness and capacity to confront international criminal activity. The committee's report summarises discussions held by the committee with Mr Kendall on Australia's relations with Interpol, law enforcement and security, electronic commerce, immigration issues, paedophile activity, and mutual assistance.

The committee's report makes recommendations on three matters; Australian representation at the Executive Committee of the International Criminal Police Organisation; the need for Australia to take a leading role in developing cooperative arrangements between law enforcement bodies in the south-west pacific region; and the importance of ensuring that there are no unnecessary legislative barriers to inhibit the flow of information and intelligence between security and law enforcement agencies.
The recommendations, together with the government response to each recommendation, are set out below:
(1) The committee recommends that the Australian Government promote the appointment of an Australian representative to the Executive Committee of the International Criminal Police Organisation.

The recommendation is accepted. The government is actively promoting the appointment of the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police as an Australian representative to the Executive Committee of the International Criminal Police Organisation (Interpol). Representation in this forum by a senior Australian law enforcement officer would provide an opportunity for Australia to contribute where appropriate to the development of Interpol policy, including resource allocation, outcomes, and increased effectiveness. That said however, Interpol, while facilitating contact and the exchange of information between agencies, does not become involved in actual operations. More often than not, Australian law enforcement agencies either relate directly with overseas agencies or through the Australian Federal Police (AFP) interna tional liaison network for actual operational outcomes. This will continue to be the case in the future.
(2) The committee recommends that the Australian Government take a leading role in the development of cooperative arrangements between law enforcement bodies in the south-west pacific region.

The recommendation is accepted. The government assists in the development of cooperative arrangements between law enforcement bodies in the south-western pacific region. Some areas of contribution include the involvement of the AFP, the Attorney-General's Department, AusAID, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), the Department of Defence and the Australian Customs Service(ACS) in the coordination of Australian support to law enforcement in the South Pacific by an Inter-Departmental Committee chaired by DFAT, regular meetings of Customs Heads of Administration Regional Meeting (CHARM), of the South Pacific Chiefs of Police Conferences, and of the Australasia and South West Pacific Region Police Commissioners' Conference.

Commonwealth agencies continue to support south pacific nations' law enforcement agencies through the provision of operational cooperation and training where appropriate. The AFP and ACS are working with the South Pacific Forum Secretariat to deliver illicit drugs training and identification programs. The AFP's South Pacific Liaison Officer assists regional law enforcement authorities by promoting effective cooperation in tracking the movement of criminals in the region, working to strengthen fraud prevention, and providing assistance to improve regional authorities' awareness of, and ability to counter money laundering activities. The Liaison Officer also provides appropriate practical assistance such as conducting international criminal checks on behalf of south pacific nations.

(3) The committee recommends that the Australian Government take steps to ensure that there are no unnecessary legislative barriers which would inhibit the flow of information and intelligence between security and law enforcement agencies.

The government accepts that there should be no unnecessary legislative barriers which would inhibit the flow of information and intelligence between Australian security and law enforcement agencies. There are several points that should be kept in mind. While the flow of relevant information and intelligence between security and law enforcement agencies is desirable, and in some circumstances operationally essential, there need to be appropriate legislative controls in place to protect the legitimate civil rights and privacy of Australian citizens. Legislative controls currently in place ensure that the activities of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) are restricted to legitimate security interests.

There are areas of overlapping interest and responsibility between security agencies and police forces which necessitate close cooperation. The committee's report notes the particular need for exchange of information between agencies in relation to countering international terrorism. This is mentioned in the report as a particular concern in the lead-up to the Sydney Olympic Games. The Commonwealth and New South Wales governments are cooperating closely in planning for the security and enforcement needs of the Sydney Olympic Games. In this respect, there are already mechanisms established to ensure close cooperation between ASIO and law enforcement agencies, including relevant New South Wales agencies. Whether amendments to current legislation are necessary to facilitate such cooperation is currently under consideration.

The ASIO act provides a mechanism for provision of relevant information to law enforcement agencies. The functions of ASIO include obtaining, correlating and evaluating intelligence relevant to security and, for purposes relevant to security, to communicate any such intelligence to such persons, and in such manner, as are appropriate to those purposes. In relevant cases, this includes communication to law enforcement agencies. In addition, paragraph 1 8(3)(a) of that act specifically provides for the communication of information to law enforcement agencies in relation to the commission or intended commission of offences. While that paragraph is limited to indictable offences, this merely recognises the balance which must be found in a democratic society between collection of intelligence for national security purposes and the protection of the individual. It would scarcely be appropriate for ASIO to be providing intelligence in relation to summary offences, unless that information was relevant to security, as defined in the ASIO act. Subsection 19(1) of the ASIO act specifically provides for cooperation with authorities of the Commonwealth, Departments, Police Forces and authorities of the States and authorities of other countries approved by the minister as being capable of assisting ASIO in the performance of its functions.

There is also cooperation the other way, from law enforcement agencies to the security agencies. For example, both the AFP and the National Crime Authority (NCA) provide relevant information to Australian security agencies, subject to the secrecy provisions of their respective legislation. The AFP and the NCA are restricted from providing information to other persons or agencies except in the performance of their respective statutory functions.

Concerns implied by the committee in its report that either security or law enforcement agencies may be "protecting their patches" were examined in the 1994 Report into the Review of Commonwealth Law Enforcement Arrangements. In implementing that report's recommendations, additional steps have been taken to ensure improved cooperation and consultation between security and law enforcement agencies. So called "turf protection" has not been an issue. A prime example of the degree of cooperation that exists between security and law enforcement agencies is the national counterterrorism program. The counterterrorism program demonstrates the utmost cooperation between ASIO and the AFP and other relevant Commonwealth and State agencies. There have not proven to be any legislative barriers to that cooperation.
Importantly, the AFP, the NCA, and the ACS are members of the Consultative Committee on Security Intelligence, which:
. provides a consultative forum on security intelligence priorities;
. enables agencies and departments to identify their security intelligence requirements (and so help ASIO and others to manage their product and research programs effectively);
. provides a mechanism for coordinating the provision of security intelligence; and
. provides a consultative forum on policy issues affecting more than one agency, so that responses can be developed and brought to government's attention.

A related issue is the need for law enforcement agencies, both onshore and offshore, and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) to share information on criminals to ensure that DlMA's visa systems effectively exclude criminals/terrorists from entering Australia.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS AND SECURITIES ON THE APPLICATION OF SECTION 1316 OF THE CORPORATIONS LAW
Background to the Report

The reference for an inquiry into the effect and role of section 1316 of the Corporations Law (the law) was given to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Corporations and Securities (the committee) by the then Attorney‐General, the Hon Michael Lavarch MP, on 30 November 1994. That reference was given following the committee's recommendation, in its June 1994 report to the parliament on the 1992‐93 Annual Report of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC), that the Attorney‐General should give early consideration to the possible effect of section 1316 of the law and its role.
2. On 7 December 1994 the committee resolved to inquire into, and to report to both Houses of the parliament on the operation of s.1316 of the Corporations Law with particular regard to:
(a) which offences under the Corporations Law (if any) should be subject to a limitation period, and how those offences should be identified;
(b) what the limitation period should be;
(c) whether some discretionary element such as the consent of the Attorney‐General should be retained, and if so, whether that decision should be subject to review; and
(d) the potential impact of limitation periods imposed by other laws.

3. The committee received 10 submissions and conducted two public hearings: in Canberra on 28 June and in Sydney on 16 August 1995. The committee sought submissions by advertising in the major newspapers and by writing directly to the State and Territory Attorneys‐General, the ASC, the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), the Australian Institute of Company Directors, the Law Council of Australia, the Australian Stock Exchange, civil liberties organisations, professional bodies and other individuals and organisations who were considered likely to have an interest in the issues being considered.
4. The committee's inquiry focused on competing arguments about the need for change to the operation of section 1316 of the law. Section 1316 provides that:

Despite anything in any other law, proceedings for an offence against this Law may be instituted within the period of 5 years after the act or omission alleged to constitute the offence or, with the minister's consent, at any later time.
5. The work of the committee and the participation of the individuals and groups that made submissions to the committee is gratefully acknowledged by the government.
Recommendations of the committee

6. The committee made two recommendations. The first recommendation dealt with the appropriateness of the 5 year limitation period for the prosecution of alleged offences under the law and, the appropriateness of the Attorney‐General's discretion to permit the commencement of a prosecution outside that 5 year limitation period. The second recommendation called for the provision of detailed information in the Annual Reports of the ASC and the DPP on investigations and prosecutions under the Corporations Law to ensure that there is appropriate public information on the ASC's and the DPP's administration in relation to those areas of their responsibilities.
RECOMMENDATION 1
Section 1316 of the Corporations Law should be amended to provide for:
‐ abolition of the limitation period on the prosecution of serious or indictable offences under the Corporations Law;
‐ prosecution of summary offences or minor regulatory matters under the Corporations Law be subject to a limitation period of 5 years; and

‐ abolition of the present requirement in section 1316 of the Corporations Law for the consent of the Attorney‐General to commencement of the prosecution of offences under the Corporations Law more than 5 years after their alleged commission.
Limitation period

7. The government agrees with the committee's first recommendation that the five year limitation period on the prosecution of serious or indictable offences under the Corporations Law should be abolished and that the 5 year limitation period should be maintained for summary or minor regulatory matters.

8. The Corporations Law does not distinguish between summary and indictable offences. The distinction between summary and indictable offences is provided for by the Commonwealth Crimes Act 1914. Section 4G of that act provides that "Offences against a law of the commonwealth punishable by imprisonment for a period exceeding 12 months are indictable offences, unless the contrary intention appears", while s.4H provides that "Offences against a law of the commonwealth, being offences which: (a) are punishable by imprisonment for a period not exceeding 12 months: or (b) are not punishable by imprisonment; are summary offences, unless the contrary intention appears".

9. The Corporations Law contains a wide range of penalties for breaches of the law. Penalties for offences range from a fine of $500 (ie 5 penalty units) for matters not set out in Schedule 3 of the law, and which are not otherwise specifically provided for, to a fine of $200,000 (2,000 penalty units) or imprisonment for 5 years, or both the fine and imprisonment. A penalty unit is defined in the Corporations Law to equal $100.
10. Examples of indictable offences under the Corporations Law are:

. knowingly or recklessly contravening a civil penalty provision of the law and dishonestly intending to gain an advantage, personally or for someone else, or intending to deceive or defraud someone (s1317FA—2,000 penalty units or 5 years imprisonment, or both);
. issuing or offering prescribed interests without an approved trust deed (s.1065—200 penalty units or 5 years imprisonment, or both);
. failure to pay client's money with intent to defraud (s.867(4)—100 penalty units or 2 years imprisonment, or both);
. failure by the holder of a securities or dealers licence to notify the ASC of a breach of a licence condition (s.787—50 penalty units or 1 year imprisonment, or both).
11. Examples of summary offences under the Corporations Law are:

. the failure by a company to notify the ASC of a change of address of its registered office, or hours during which the registered office is open, within 7 days after the change occurred (s.218—5 penalty units);
. the failure by a company to set up and maintain a register of members, options granted over unissued shares, and debenture issues (s.216A—10 penalty units or 3 months imprisonment, or both); and
. exercising a function or power as an officer of a company where the company is being wound up in insolvency or by the Court (s.471A—25 penalty units or 6 months imprisonment, or both).

12. In relation to indictable offences, the government acknowledges that the growing complexity of corporate investigations, and the often considerable time between the commission and detection of alleged corporate offences, makes it more important that sufficient time be allowed for investigatory processes carried out by the ASC, and for the commencement of prosecutions.

13. The government agrees that it is in the public interest that minor regulatory matters giving rise to summary offences should be dealt with promptly. While matters such as a failure to lodge company documents are generally detected, investigated and prosecuted within a reasonably short time, other relatively minor matters such as the failure to keep and maintain certain registers required by the Corporations Law may not be obvious and may not be detected until some considerable time has passed.

14. The government has noted that data provided to the committee by the DPP showed that while the number of summary offences prosecuted is quite small, the majority of those offences were prosecuted more than three years but within five years after commission . The government considers that maintaining the 5 year limitation period in relation to summary offences will allow a balance to be maintained between promptly dealing with readily detectible matters and those which may not be so obvious or detectible. The government supports the maintenance of the 5 year limitation period for the prosecution of minor regulatory matters giving rise to summary offences.
Attorney‐General's discretion

15. The committee concluded that the discretionary element in s.1316 providing for the Attorney‐General to give consent to the initiation of proceedings outside the five year period should be abolished. The government supports the recommendation in conjunction with the maintenance of the 5 year limitation period for the prosecution of summary offences and its abolition for indictable offences under the Corporations Law.

16. The government supports the conclusion of the committee that the existing discretion in s.1316 of the Corporations Law does not significantly add to the proper and desirable protection of persons accused under various provisions of the Corporations Law. As indicated by the committee, persons facing the probability of prosecution by the DPP would be aware of such a probability some considerable time before charges were preferred against them, particularly where a matter has been under investigation by the ASC for some time.
17. The government proposes to introduce, as soon as is reasonably practicable, appropriate amendments to the Corporations Law to give effect to this Recommendation.
RECOMMENDATION 2

Future Annual Reports of the Australian Securities Commission and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions should provide detailed information showing the time that has elapsed since the commission of alleged offences under the Corporations Law and the time that has elapsed since the commencement of active investigative and prosecutorial processes

18. The government agrees that the Annual Reports of the Australian Securities Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions should be required to provide specific information on investigations and prosecutions under the Corporations Law to enable an accurate assessment of the administration of their areas of responsibility.

19. The government considers, however, that information concerning the time elapsed since the commission of an offence and the commencement of active investigative and prosecutorial processes will not, in many instances, provide a meaningful gauge of ASC or DPP administration. There are many reasons, including deliberate concealment in a large number of cases, why the ASC may not learn of a contravention of the law for weeks, months or years after it occurs.
20. In this regard, the government proposes to give substantial effect to the recommendation of the committee by requiring the ASC and DPP to provide in their Annual Reports statistics on:
(i) the time taken by the ASC from the date of commencement of an investigation to the point at which a matter is delivered to the DPP (in the ASC Annual Report);
(ii) the time between the delivery of a matter by the ASC to the DPP and the laying of any charges (in the ASC Annual Report);

(iii) the number of cases referred to the DPP by the ASC where proceedings (whether under the Corporations Law or state Law) have been instituted more than five years after the alleged offence with an indication of the reasons for delay in instituting proceedings (in the DPP Annual Report).
21. Implementation of this Recommendation will not require legislative amendment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN LAND FUND MATTERS
The Government has noted the majority and minority reports of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Land Fund Matters, as presented on 30 November 1995.
The former Government considered that the funding allocation to the Northern Territory was a matter for ATSIC alone.
This Government notes that ATSIC had accepted the Federal Court decision on its land acquisition allocations to the states and reviewed its priorities in November 1995.

The Government supports the view of the Committee majority report, which concluded that the ATSIC Board in reaching its original decisions on land acquisition allocations did not fully consider the implications of its decisions in relation to its constituents in all parts of Australia.

The Government further notes the findings of the minority report and agrees that i) there was no evidence to support allegations of a secret agreement between ATSIC and others and the former Government in relation to land acquisitions in the Northern Territory; and ii) ATSIC failed to follow an adequate decision making process in coming to its original decision.
The attached schedule provides a set of responses to each of the three recommendations made in the majority report.

SPEECH.PARA: SCHEDULE OF RESPONSES TO MAJORITY REPORT RECOMMENDATIONS

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Federal Government ensure Ministerial responsibility for Aboriginal land issues be clearly identifiable, preferably with only one Minister having responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has primary responsibility and accountability through powers vested in that Minister by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act (as amended) and the various Commonwealth land rights legislation. The Minister also has responsibility for the Native Title Act except to the extent administered by the Attorney‐General.

The Government supports the Indigenous Land Fund as an element of the reconciliation process with Indigenous peoples. The Government also proposes to proceed with a number of amendments to the legislation establishing the Indigenous Land Corporation to ensure that benefits from land acquisitions will be maximised to the indigenous community.

The Committee recommends that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 be amended to provide measures to increase the transparency of ATSIC Board decisions and the accountability of the ATSIC Board to indigenous people and the general community.

The government has proposed measures to improve the accountability of the ATSIC Board. The Government is encouraged by the ATSIC Board's recognition that it must be fully accountable to its constituents through the democratic process and its willingness to accept the Federal Court decision in respect of the distribution of its land acquisition funds.

The Board takes submissions and advice from many different sources, including ATSIC's Regional Councils. Its Commissioners are also represented on these Councils. Decisions of the Board, including those which were the subject of the Senate Select Committee report, are required to be published and made available to Regional Councils and their local constituents. The Government recognises that there will be times when material prepared for consideration by the Board, or decisions taken, will be confidential or subject to Privacy Act protection or subject to Section 90 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act. . However ATSIC, like other Federal agencies, must be subject to the same principles of administrative law, and fully accountable to indigenous people, to the Parliament and to the general community.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Auditor‐General conduct a performance audit of the ATSIC Land Acquisition and Maintenance Program, to assess program effectiveness and to make recommendations on the operations of similar programs that will be operated by the ILC.

SPEECH.PARA: Previous audits and evaluations of the Land Acquisition and Maintenance Program were undertaken in 1992 and 1994 by ATSIC's Office of Evaluation and Audit. A further evaluation of the program has commenced and will be completed by mid‐1996.

The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) has noted the Committee's recommendation. ANAO is developing its 1996‐97 Performance Audit Strategy, and expects to present the strategy to Parliament towards the end of June 1996. The ANAO will consider the concerns the Committee has raised in the development of its performance audit strategy for ATSIC.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This government response reflects the appalling, deceitful and, as far as I am concerned, degenerate approach this government has taken to the funding of the Australian National Training Authority. This is yet another example where this government says one thing while it is doing exactly the opposite. We have seen time and time again by ministerial press release, and now by the government's response to the Senate education committee's report of the committee's inquiry into the Australian National Training Authority, quite dishonest responses to the government's actions that are being taken and quite clear attempts to misrepresent what is being done by this government. This report says, for instance, in a disingenuous way:

BREAK.PARA: The Government's position on the recommendations relating to use of growth funds and planning arrangements will be addressed in the context of the development of a revised ANTA Agreement.
And similarly:
The Government's proposed new funding arrangements allow for future growth to be derived from increased efficiencies.

What this report by the Senate education committee entitled Report of the inquiry into Australian National Training Authority originally was all about was trying to come to terms with the enormous growth that is occurring within the TAFE sector and the vocational education sector across this country. It devised mechanisms by which there could be a rational and effective broadening of this parliament's commitment to the provision of resources to ensure that all Australians had access to vocational education and training. But what this government has done, quite contrary to what it says in this response, is to dramatically cut back the opportunities that are in fact available to Australians to participate in the vocational education training sector.

This government implies that it is giving consideration to growth funding arrangements for future growth in this industry; what it does not say is that it has already taken the decision to stop the growth funding. It has already taken the decision. What this government says is that it is providing $4.5 billion for funding for the TAFE and vocational education sector. What it does not say is that it has cut back $183 million from the last budget, $72 million in so-called efficiency dividends over the next four years; it has unilaterally ended the $70 million in growth funding available for TAFE; and it has reduced the operating budget for ANTA by some 27 per cent over the last two years.

This is why I say that this is a disgracefully dishonest way in which to approach these issues and an attempt to present to the public a position which is quite contrary to and inconsistent with the facts of what this government is actually doing. I think it is an appalling way in which to treat what is a very important part of the education industry in this country.

The minister says that the government has introduced a new program, the so-called new apprenticeship scheme. What he does not say is that the government has not provided the money to actually operate it. It would be an extremely unusual set of circumstance where a major initiative, a flagship initiative, is introduced without the necessary resources to actually fund it.

I have seen state estimates, based on advice given by Commonwealth officials to state officials, that the total cost of this program is in the order of $3.7 billion. How much money has this government budgeted for this program? Somewhat less than half of that amount. The exact level of future demand is a matter for some conjecture. The recent KPMG consultancy entitled `The cost and resourcing of new apprenticeships' highlights the range of projections that are in fact open. It all depends entirely upon what policy decisions are taken by the government. But what is quite clearly, unequivocally, the case is that all in the industry agree that the growth in the so-called new apprenticeships will be quite dramatic.

The level of growth in the first couple of years, I think all would say, will be slight. But by the year 2000 there will be significant growth. I have seen, for instance, comments by the minister that the states are likely to see a dramatic growth. I saw a speech recently, delivered in Sydney by the chief executive officer of the Australian National Training Authority, that said that he thought there could be up to a 50 per cent increase in the level of new apprenticeships as a result of initiatives taken. No-one in the industry is actually suggesting that there will be anything other than growth in this sector. But what does this government do? It budgets for a very minimal increase.

The KPMG report highlights that the present rate of spending is around 20 per cent. In their opinion, it will need to grow, in terms of resource allocation, to 30 to 40 per cent of total resources. No-one disputes that that growth will be dramatic, while there may be some comment about whether 30 or 40 per cent is appropriate of total outlays. Some say in fact it could be greater. What does the KPMG report suggest as the way in which that money should be found? It says there are basically five policy options that need to be considered.

The first is the issue of so‐called displacement. It says that you could transfer students from one course to another. Very limited options are available there. You take could away people's rights in terms of doing diploma courses or associate diploma courses. What it also says is that you make the states pay. Clearly, what the minister has indicated in his statement recently is that the states will need to find in productivity savings some $300 million a year. This is how he suggests there could be some 100,000 additional TAFE places found—the states themselves should fund them.

The report also suggests that there could be some shift to the enterprise, that employers should be asked to pay more. Of course, we have seen that this government has no real interest in that. Also, this report suggests that there should be some increases in user charges and the introduction of a deferred payment scheme, which this government has been considering. On 23 May this year at the ministerial council meeting Minister Kemp introduced and sponsored a proposal by the Australian National Training Authority to do just that and could not get the support of the states. Why did he do that? Because he knows fundamentally that the `New Apprenticeship' program is substantially under funded, by as much as up to 50 per cent under funded. This is an appalling way in which to run a government. This is why I say that it is a disgrace that it should be suggested to us, in response from the government, that actions have been taken by this government which clearly are not being taken.

We have a major initiative, a major flagship of this government being introduced without the resources to support it and, on the contrary, the moneys being made available for the vocational, education and training sector are being dramatically cut back. What growth there has been in funding, which the minister boasts about, in fact, is no more than the normal inflationary growth, no more than the normal expenses you would expect. In fact, many of the incentives for employers to take up apprenticeships, such as those under the craft scheme, have been dramatically reduced—between 67 and 72 per cent for many of those programs. What you have is a dishonest and disgraceful approach being taken by this government which has been exposed by the KPMG report. The government is now trying to cover this up by trying to make the states pay for a program which they, the Commonwealth, have introduced and the Commonwealth is seeking to draw the political credit for. What is all this about? It is a complete contrast to debate in recent years which the Senate committee exposed in terms of the maintenance of effort by the states.

In the past the argument was about whether the states were holding up their end of the bargain for VET funding, whether they were paying their appropriate share. We said in government that the Commonwealth should and did provide very large sums of increases in terms of resources to fund the growth in TAFE and vocational education.

The case now is quite contrary. The Commonwealth is bludging on the states and on the Australian people in the most dishonest and hypocritical manner. It is displaying what I suggest to the Senate is a totally inappropriate way in which to present and manage a government program and it is totally inappropriate for this government to introduce responses to reports which are quite clearly misleading and deceptive. In my judgment, it is an intellectual disgrace that a minister can present such a report which is blatantly untrue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris
