During the break, I had a chance to look at those amendments and discuss them with Senator Kernot who is co‐sponsor of the opposition amendments. I would like to indicate to the minister that we have had some further amendments drawn up which seek to address her concerns at least in relation to those matters, first of all to indicate that in terms of the code of conduct there is no difficulty from our point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not quite clear what the minister is saying about that but I understood there was some argument yesterday about CPSU members having the effect of a double process with the department having to put people through the accreditation process and then review the tenders. I was conscious of that. The minister's amendment seems to meet that concern by saying, in subclause (2):
It is a condition of an employment services agreement that the employment services provider with whom the agreement is made must comply with the code of conduct formulated under subsection (1).

That really does meet our concerns there. What I am suggesting, and I think they may be able to be circulated now, is an amendment which picks up the two concerns the minister had but continues to pursue our other amendments to clause 11, so that our other amendments seem to pick up the concerns the minister raised.

But, in terms of her suggested amendment 11A, `Register of employment placement enterprises', we still want greater detail than her provision implies. I think we pick up the thrust of what her suggested amendment goes to, but we still want a range of detail that her amendment does not contain. So the impact would be that we would persist with our amendment 11 in the sense that clauses 11 and 11B would be retained but clauses 11A, 11C and 11D would be amended.

TALK.START.PARA: —As they have not been circulated, would you care to move that consideration of amendments 11 and 12 be postponed until a later hour?
—Reluctantly, Mr Temporary Chairman, at your suggestion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That consideration of amendments 11 and 12 be postponed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Page 14 (after line 6), at the end of Part 2, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Division 4 Public Employment Placement Enterprise
15A Establishment of Public Employment Placement Enterprise

SPEECH.PARA: (1) A body called the Public Employment Placement Enterprise (PEPE) is established by this section.
(2) PEPE consists of such employees of, or persons appointed by, the Department as are directed to work in PEPE.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 15B PEPE's functions

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The functions of PEPE are to ensure that a high quality labour exchange service is available to all persons throughout Australia, and, in particular, to ensure that high quality employment services are available in areas where private employment services providers may not provide or be able to provide employment assistance services to Such standards.
Note: ILO Convention No. 88 (Anicles 1. 3 and 6) outlines the obligations in this matter on Australia as a party to the Convention.

(2) The Employment Secretary must, on behalf of the Commonwealth, engage PEPE to provide labour exchange services to any job seeker, including job seekers not in recept of benefits under the Social Security Act 1991, or employer seeking such services.
(3) The terms and conditions of the engagement of PEPE are to be set out in a written agreement between the Employment Secretary and PEPE.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 15C PEPE's staff

SPEECH.PARA: PEPE's staff are to be persons employed or appointed under the Public Service Act 1992.
Note: ILO Convention No.88 (Articles 2 and 9) outlines the obligations in this matter on Australia as a party to the Convention.

Amendment 13 seeks to deal with the PEPE. We, when considering this bill the other day, passed an opposition amendment which inserted into the definitions clause a definition of the public provider—the PEPE—as that organisation as established under clause 15. In this amendment we are seeking to give effect to that clause and to describe the role of the PEPE.

Without wanting to go over the whole debate again, the bill, as drafted by the government, contained no reference to the public provider at all. The opposition and Democrat amendments are seeking to place into the bill that public provider and ensure that the functions that are being provided by the CES continue to be provided. So this is the clause and the amendments that seek to do that.

They do that in a number of ways. Clause 15A, as proposed in our amendment 13, establishes the public employment placement enterprise and provides that the `PEPE consists of such employees of, or persons appointed by, the department as are directed to work in PEPE'. So it sets it up as a Public Service provider.

Clause 15B sets out the PEPE's functions. It is quite clear that this reflects the model that we have been arguing for throughout this debate. I do not know whether it is necessary to go through all of the arguments again; I suspect not. What we seek to do here is oppose the government's proposition that the PEPE be a private corporation unaccountable to parliament and establishes a private com pany. Instead, we want to set it up as a public provider. We think the effect of these amendments is to do that.

Clause 15B(1) sets out the PEPE's functions. This, I think, is the key amendment in terms of the opposition and Democrat approaches to this bill, in that we provide that the PEPE will provide the ongoing community service obligations to backup the establishment of this market. We want to ensure that the high quality labour exchange services that have been available to Australians since 1946 are maintained, that that universal access to those services is maintained.

Despite what the minister says, we are not seeking to impose restrictions on the government. We are seeking to maintain those services, those basic rights that Australians currently enjoy to access labour exchange services and to access them regardless of where they live or their ability to pay. As I say, this is the critical amendment, in my view, in this whole debate. We are very concerned that those services continue to be maintained and available to people who live in rural and remote Australia and to people who might live in areas where the market fails to provide a competitive market for employment services.

We have pursued at estimates and other venues the question of how the government's model is going to work in rural and regional Australia. Quite frankly, the answers have been less than satisfactory. The answer is basically, `Trust us. The market will work. Here we are establishing a market to pick up the failure of the labour market, but we have complete faith in that market.' Quite frankly, I do not share the minister's faith.

She has admitted in a number of her documents that there may be holes and deficiencies in the market that might be addressed. But none of those is addressed in this bill. None of those guarantees is placed in the bill. None of the assurances the minister has given is placed in the bill. What we seek to do is to make sure that that basic community service obligation is met, that it is laid out in the bill and, quite frankly, that the PEPE has the role of providing those services where the market cannot, will not or fails to. So that is very important in terms of the PEPE's function.

The other thing we do, which we are quite open about, is seek in the second clause to ensure that the PEPE provides labour exchange services to those job seekers who the minister says are no longer a priority—that is, those who are not on unemployment benefits. We have had this argument over and over again with the minister saying that she wants to ration those services only to those who are on unemployment benefits. We are firmly of the view that other Australians—newly ar rived migrants who are not eligible for unemployment benefits, workers retrenched, workers with spouses in employment and a whole range of groups and categories of people—who have enjoyed the ability to access labour exchange services free of charge wherever they live or whatever their personal wealth should continue to be able to do that.

We think that is a basic community service obligation. It is a basic role of government. It is one enshrined in the ILO conventions relating to these areas. It is something that the Liberal Party supported in its policy platform at the last election and is something that has had bipartisan support for many years in Australia. If this bill is not amended in this way it will be a retrograde step. We think this is a key amendment and ought to be supported by the parliament.

The other aspect of this amendment is clause 15(c) which seeks to offer the staff the same conditions they currently enjoy under the Public Service Act and which were enjoyed by those employees who moved to the Commonwealth service delivery agency. Senators might recall that we had this debate then and the government finally accepted that those employees continue to enjoy the status of persons employed under the Public Service Act. That, again, is part of our ILO commitment.

The minister will argue—and I understand this has been part of the rationale inside the government for looking to move people out of coverage by the Public Service Act—that this will not allow for a level playing field. My own view is that the changes mooted to the Public Service Act and the changes to the Workplace Relations Act which the government has lauded and has said will bring all sorts of tremendous results for Australian workplaces can well be applied in this area as well.

There is no reason for us either to walk away from those people who have given service and want to continue to give service as public servants in the area of servicing the unemployed, or to walk away from their career structure and from the ethos of the public service that they wish to continue to provide. It is not unreasonable that we provide those protections for those employees. The flexibility exists within the current industrial relations system to ensure that the arguments about a level playing field, in terms of the employment conditions of those in the public and private provider areas, are addressed.

The alternative argument is to say that the public servants who transfer to the PEPE must be forced to accept the same wages and conditions as the lowest level of conditions provided by a private provider. That is the corollary of the argument; that we must, in order to have a level playing field, bring them down to the lowest level of employment conditions. I do not think the Senate can accept that. I do not think it is necessary that we take that view.

For all those reasons, this is a critical amendment. I know it is strongly opposed by the government but I think it really goes to the heart of the sorts of employment programs and services we have in this country. This is central to ensuring equality of access to labour exchange services, which is a fundamental right of all Australian citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with all of those remarks. We, too, support the role of government in the public provision of basic services and community service obligations. We support a strong and vigorous public sector. In previous discussions with Senator Vanstone I said that, because the wider public service reform was being debated, I would listen to her arguments on whether staff should be left under the Public Service Act. I got the impression from her that, in discussions with the CPSU, they had said that they were reasonably satisfied with some of the conditions that they would expect to work under. I have asked for further clarification from them. I am still happy to listen to the minister's argument but I would say to her that the CPSU said—
—You are happy to listen, but you are not happy to change your position. Why don't you tell the truth?

—Minister, since we had that discussion, I went away to check that your retelling of their position was true— which I think is fair. You can argue with their retelling of their position to me if you want to. According to those who speak for the public servants involved, they are surprised by your comments. They say the clear majority of their members are absolutely committed to working under the Public Service Act. They say that you have provided some very limited guarantees that the government will honour accrued entitlements such as accumulated recreation leave and superannuation. They also say that, unfortunately, there are no guarantees about salary structures, hours of work, leave entitlements, allowances or other conditions that are traditionally associated with public sector workers. I do think that we have to acknowledge that when people in this country choose a public sector career in many instances it means they forgo other opportunities. We should make sure that we structure salary and leave components to reflect some of those things.

SPEECH.PARA: The CPSU argue that, given that there will be 6,000 CES employees competing for an estimated 2,000 jobs—but I am sure that some of those 6,000 will have found other work since this was first mooted—there will be very high competition for the jobs. They argue that their negotiating position in securing an agreement in the PEPE will be weakened. I think that the best thing to do—unless the minister has a compelling argument—is to leave all those entitlements in place. We will have the wider debate about public service reform generally and I think that is more appropriate than leading with our chin and asking the staff of the PEPE to be the bunnies in this case—the bunnies at the end of reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that I seek to engage the minister on—I see that the minister is engaged in taking other advice—is, in part, related to those comments which I referred to in my speech during the second reading debate. In September last year the minister was talking about this being an experiment which was not irretrievable and which therefore should not be equated to a jump into a `very big deep pool' because `you are not throwing out the CES; you are simply corporatising that portion of it which does not go to the shopfront'.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to find out why the validity of those comments then in the mind of the minister has been overtaken. Rather than what was understood to be the creation of the CES as the Public Employment Placement Enterprise as some form of statutory corporation, it appears that what we have now is its creation as a commercial corporation. I take the term `commercial corporation' to mean what I think it must mean—that is, a corporation which stands or falls on its commercial capacity. If there is a level playing field and if there can be no guarantees to the PEPE about contracting and about work, as a commercial corporation, it is not guaranteed existence, in the same way as the minister indicated that none of the charitable organisations are guaranteed a role or an existence in this area and in the same way as those private employment agencies now are not guaranteed a role in this system.

I would contrast that situation with some of the provisions in your exposure draft about contracting some of the services. It is stated that at the first tender process certain services in certain areas are not able to be let to tender because of perhaps a lack of interest and there will be an approach for services to be provided by fee‐for‐service. If that fails, the public provider, the PEPE, is expected to take it up on some sort of fee‐for‐service basis. I take it from the exposure draft that the PEPE does not necessarily—or perhaps just does not—get a look in at the second phase of that process.

If you do get to that third phase, if the commercial corporation that the government proposes as the PEPE fails, there will not be anyone there to provide the community services organisation unless you create a new one. In other words, if you create a commercial corporation and the commercial corporation fails and the tender process fails, what do you do then? Do you start afresh? Do you start with an organisation which may now potentially have expertise? You see it fail potentially and you then have to create it again from nothing. That is the very big deep pool that I think you, Minister, were referring to in September last year.

I am concerned because in some of those more remote areas in Australia—perhaps it will not be in Tasmania because of the relative decentralisation in that state and the availability of population centres right around the state—and in some of the states where population is more widespread, it will not be economic to deliver these employment services that you talked about. I think you mentioned Laverton before question time earlier this afternoon. I have a fear that we may end up with an experiment which fails in those areas.

It is true that the CES services could be improved. We did have a debate about how we might deal with our concerns about that in the context of this legislation earlier today. What we are faced with here is potentially a collapse of the services that people in these employment service areas receive. I would appreciate, Minister, to hear your views about that very big deep pool so that perhaps we can pursue the matter further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do find this debate somewhat difficult because I regard some of the contributions as being slightly platitudinous. I say that with some degree of regret because it is not normally the sort of insult I like to pass to colleagues. There is currently no requirement on the CES to deliver any employment services anywhere— no legislative requirement at all. This is legislation approved of by the previous government and supported by the Democrats. There is no requirement whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: All this government is trying to do is to ensure that unemployed people on benefits get treated first in any queue and that we end the segregation that they have been delegated to—which is that they can go to the CES and get services free and everyone else who has a few bucks in their pocket can go to other professional providers like Morgan and Banks, Drake Personnel, the Brotherhood of St Laurence or Centapact. There are a whole of range of providers that they are locked out of. We intend to have a situation where unemployed Australians on benefit can pick and choose the employment provider of their choice. We will pay the employment provider of their choice to provide them with a service.

In response to that, we have people on the other side saying, `This is a shocking thing; you will not guarantee that the newly corporatised PEPE will be in every town, every region and every place.' They say that without any embarrassment, maybe not knowing that the CES is basically one line in the act at the moment—`There will be a CES.'

The CES does not have the requirements placed on it that you want to place on the new public employment placement enterprise. You want to ask a whole lot more of the new enterprise. I do not know whether you have predetermined to be difficult about this legislation just because you want to look after the CPSU, or whether you do not understand how the CES is now structured. It is effectively described in one line in the act—`There will be a CES within the department.' I understand that prior to 1994 there was some legislation but no more than that—just the establishment. Then in 1994, under Labor's Employment Services Act, we shifted to the single‐line reference to the CES.

Senators opposite stand up and demand so much more of the new corporatised public employment placement enterprise than they were prepared to demand of their own government for the CES. I find it unacceptable that you would demand more of this change than you were prepared to demand of yourselves. It points to the pretty shallow debate we have had thus far and indicates a predetermination on your part not to support this bill.

Reference has been made to the benefits of the staff. Senator Kernot, who is not technically in the chamber but is in the room, has indicated that we had a conversation, which we did. She asked how the CPSU felt about the arrangements we had made for CPSU staff, Public Service staff, to shift over to the PEPE. I indicated to her two things. Of course they are not saying, `Yes, we'd like to go!' There was never any pretence that they were jumping around and clapping their hands with glee saying, `Yes, we'd love this change!' But, in the circumstances where the government had the capacity to make change, want ed to do that and the change was going to be made, it was said that the conditions the staff would be provided with were much more than they expected we would be offering and that they were pleased with them.

If you go to speak to them, Senator Kernot, it will be no surprise that they will say, `Of course we do not want to change.' No-one ever made any pretence about that. But, in the circumstances where there is going to be change, do they believe that these benefits are pretty good? My answer to that remains yes.

Let me run through what the benefits are, lest anybody think there has been some attempt on the government's or my part to reduce the benefits available to these people, who are currently doing an excellent job and who, frankly, are sick of waiting for this bill, are wanting to get on with the job and are wanting to show that they can compete without extra protection and that they will compete very effectively and will do the job.

What are the staffing arrangements that we have negotiated? The current substantive salary will be maintained and protected under the first PEPE certified agreement, which obviously will operate from the commencement up until the following year, with future remuneration being negotiated through subsequent PEPE certified agreements, consistent with the Workplace Relations Act, including the no disadvantage test. There will be ongo ing access to CSS and PSS, that is, superannuation. Obviously sick leave and recreation leave credits which have been built up will be retained and carried over.

The existing coverage of the long service leave act will continue. At least the equivalent of APS redundancy entitlements prevailing at the time will apply in the event of a redundancy—at least the equivalent. There will be mirrored APS and maternity leave provisions until any new arrangements are agreed on. There will be the indefinite right to apply for APS vacancies advertised in the Gazette. Prevailing APS mobility provisions will apply on transfer to the PEPE, such as the right to return to the APS in certain circumstances, notably if staff become excess in the PEPE. This is a very good package of conditions, with which senators will be aware.

Let me deal with a couple of other points. I think Senator O'Brien raised the question of whether this is going to be a corporate entity and whether it therefore will be like a corporate entity that rises or falls on its commercial success. Well, it is a commercial entity in terms of the Corporations Law. In a sense, it does commercial work: it will compete commercially to provide services to unemployed Australians on benefit and young Australians. How well it does in that respect depends on how many young Australians and unemployed people on benefit it places into jobs. If it is good at its job, it will continue to get a very successful share of contracts from the Commonwealth; if it is not, it will have a diminishing share—just like everybody else.

Over and above that, it has other obligations. It has a community service obligation. It can be directed by the minister to provide services where the minister decides that services ought to be provided. Where the initial tender arrangements have not found an adequate supplier and a secondary round of fee‐for‐service has not found an adequate supplier, then the minister can direct the company to do that. It is unlike a range of other companies in that the Commonwealth is the only shareholder. So it is subject to direction of the Commonwealth. But in all other respects, it competes commercially.

BREAK.PARA: We are absolutely committed to proceeding with PEPE staff shifting out of the Public Service so that we have a genuine level playing field for staffing arrangements. We have gone to great lengths to ensure that the staff who move over in the beginning—they probably are not going to be there in 15 years time—have all of those protections there so that they can move back into the Public Service, and apply to and shift to other areas and have in place at least the APS conditions for superannuation, et cetera. I will not bother repeating them.

We have gone to great lengths to ensure that those people are protected in that respect. Those who stay will be able to negotiate the conditions that they choose to negotiate under the workplace arrangements, including the no disadvantage test. That is in respect of 15C in opposition amendment No. 13.
The second thing that is unacceptable is in respect of 15B, which provides that:

The Employment Secretary must, on behalf of the Commonwealth, engage PEPE to provide labour exchange services to any job seeker, including job seekers not in receipt of benefits . . . or employer seeking such services.

This is where we fundamentally disagree. There is no point in me repeating this time and time again. I know that you people have a degree of intelligence and can understand English. We have made a decision. We are the government. We are determined to put unemployed people on benefits first.

I had a discussion with Senator Kernot earlier today while waiting for a division or during the counting of a division. I asked Senator Kernot whether she was going to persist in raising the example of the person whose spouse is in employment and who would like assistance. She wants that person to be considered. To that, I effectively said, `You mean you want that person to get priority over an unemployed person on benefit?' No, she does not want that. I said, `Well, you want them to be treated equally?'

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—She says, `Yes.' Therefore, the difference is that we want them to get a better deal. We want to put them first. Some people are reluctant to face a large group of people who might want a service and say, `We've got to put an order here. We've got to put a priority. Therefore, some difficult decisions have to be made.' Some people would rather wave their hands in the air and say, `I can't stand it. It's all too difficult. I'd like them all to be treated equally.' That is fairyland.

BREAK.PARA: We believe it is unfair to unemployed people on benefit not to put them first, so we are prepared to make that decision. We will put them first. I do not think Senator Kernot will deny that when I said, `But hold on, we want to put unemployed people on benefit first,' she said, `So do we.' I said, `Hold on. You can't have both of these propositions.'

TALK.START.PARA: —You can.
—You cannot.
—You can; you're making the decision not to have them.

—You cannot put unemployed people on benefit first and have everybody else treated equally. Equal means treated the same as. Being first means ahead of. It is fairly simple. We are determined to put unemployed people on benefit first. We will do that.

BREAK.PARA: We have such an unacceptably high level of unemployment in Australia after 13 years of Homer Simpson in the shower pulling all the right levers. I do not know what he was pulling, but it was not the right levers in the economy because look what we got left with. We got left with a disgraceful stain of unemployment on the economy thanks to Homer Simpson's enormous contributions.

Do you remember the economy when champagne was bubbling over, everyone was going to have a job and there were going to be no children living in poverty? Australians listened to all of that, and now they know it was all a load of rubbish. We were left with a very, very high and unacceptable level of unemployment and an ingrained stain on the economy.

What does that mean? There are people out there who want jobs. They are not on a benefit because they want a benefit. They are on a benefit because they cannot find a job that they want. We think it is perfectly fair—more than fair; it is appropriate—to put those people first in any unemployment queue.

Yes, other people might like more work or they might like some work. But we do not think you can argue the case that unemployed people on a benefit and young Australians should be put anything other than first, and that is what we intend to do. That is why we reject your amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone, I was looking forward to hearing some comment from you about the reason for the change. Nevertheless, I cannot resist the challenge to respond to a couple of things you have said.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, to suggest that there is only a one‐line mention of the Commonwealth Employment Service in the Employment Services Act is a little removed from reality. There is a definition which establishes it in one line in clause 8, but I have not been able to count the number of times it is mentioned in relation to a number of services in the act. What we are talking about in terms of creating the public employment placement enterprise is one‐and‐a‐bit lines in 15A(1). After all, 15A(2) could only be considered as a transitional provision. So we really are not doing much more than preserving it in the form that you said you would preserve it.

But when we go to the question of the PEPE's functions—and you have touched upon some of the reasons why we differ on the role of the PEPE—we need to specify the function of the PEPE in the context of the changed role. The fact is that part of the CES functions have gone to the service delivery agency and it remained as some form of labour exchange.

We disagree on the form and we put a proposal in amendment 15B(1) for, effectively, the charter for this new organisation. In 15B(2) we implemented what we believed ought to be a guarantee, particularly to those 400,000 unemployed people who are not catered for by the PEPE or by any employment placement enterprise in the bill as it stands. We agree that we disagree on that. We are putting forward our position in relation to providing a labour exchange service to those people who are not covered by your provision as well as those who are. Okay, we can have a debate about that.

I am tempted to suggest that your prioritisation of those on benefit is probably the only measure that I can see from your government which attempts to deal with the long-term unemployed. Because they cost the government money, they are going to be prioritised in the provision of some labour exchange service, and those people who do not cost the government money are not.

The fact is that all that will achieve is the shuffling of the unemployment queue. For those people who are not entitled to benefit, they go down the back of the queue. For those people who are, they go forward. That is the inequity of the whole system. Because someone is on a government benefit, they are to be preferred, and someone who is not on a government benefit will go to the back of the queue. So if they cannot afford to pay for a service and if they are in a state where employment agencies can charge for that service, they are in a pretty difficult position.

In a climate where you are actually encouraging a relationship between employment providers and employers who provide jobs, you could see a lot of those people locked out of employment opportunities that now arise under the system where you have got the CES and private providers. You do not really have a facility, for example, where it would be quite feasible that an employment placement enterprise would be paying commissions for jobs to get the fee for service that you are offering.

You could see the circumstance where some of these people who are shuffled down the back of the queue are denied opportunities to jobs that they would now have because they are available on the open market. Your scheme is likely to remove some of the jobs from the open market. As I think you said, Minister, these agencies will effectively be selling jobs because they will establish relationships with employers. They will be passing the jobs on and being paid by the Commonwealth to do that, having established those relationships. Your system is going to deny some of the 400,000 who are not going to attract the benefit the opportunity for employment that they now have, whether they go to the CES or not. But you are also saying to them, `You are not going to get the services that you can go and get now, whether you get them now or not, because that will not be available.'

That is one of the problems that we have with your system. We are not saying, Minister, that we are going to frustrate your system. We are saying that there are deficiencies in your system that we are trying to correct. So, let us get away from this question of whether we are gilding the lily as it were on replacing the CES from the Employment Services Act with the public employment placement enterprise in the Reform of Employment Services Bill. I think that is a red herring. Let us get down to the real debate, which is: what are we going to do and what are the circumstances going to be for the 400,000 people who are not going to be entitled to any service as a matter of right under this bill as it stands unamended?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The establishment of the CES in the Employment Services Act is effectively one line. There are numerous other references to the CES but they are in relation to the legislative framework surrounding case management. It does not deal with the distribution of labour market programs or labour exchange—not at all. It deals with case management, which was the innovation introduced in 1994 by the previous government and put in the legislative framework. So, in terms of the establishment, it is effectively one line. There are other references and they relate to case management. I do not know why you are shaking your head.
—Because I am reading the act and it's not in there.
—Case management was given a legislative framework. It did not, as I am advised, need it but it nevertheless had it.

BREAK.PARA: Senator, you say this government wants to put unemployed people on a benefit first because they are costing us money. I suggest that you go and ask an unemployed person on a benefit whether they would like to be put first in the queue or whether they would like to be mixed up in the queue with other people whom Australian society have not judged, at the moment, to be as much in need because they have not allowed them a benefit. Would you ask the unemployed whether they would like to be put first?

With respect, that is an unnecessarily cheap shot. Of course pensions cost money. But I would have thought we had a common goal, whether it is for money or for the benefit of getting someone who wants a job a job, of agreeing that those people ought to come first.

Senator, you mentioned again the people you describe as being locked out. These are the people we will not put first in the queue. I have explained to you before—you made reference to it in the debate—in discussions about it in this place, which I will not go on about at length, that these people are not locked out. They have available to them the touch screens and the national vacancy database to find out where jobs are. Some of them will be open, some will not. Some will have to go straight to an EPE.

I have put the view to you that in some states those EPEs will not be able to charge in any event. Even in the states where, by state law, they would be able to charge, I am not at all confident that the EPEs would. The range and mix of people that an EPE has on their books is going to be the key indicator of their success. If they only have on their books unemployed people on a benefit and young people—that is, people for whom they can get a payment from the Commonwealth—I venture to say they will not survive. That is because, in order to be successful, they must supply what industry wants.

What industry wants at any one time in Australia will not be available solely from the pool of unemployed people on a benefit and young Australians. They will have to have others on their books in order to provide what industry wants. The EPE that says, `No, sorry, I am only dealing in this group of people because that is what the Commonwealth will pay me for,' will pretty soon find that industry is not interested in dealing with them. They will have to have other people on their books.

As you know, in a variety of states at the moment when someone wants to find someone for a job and they go to an agency they pay a fee. The employer pays a fee rather than the employee. But there will be competition amongst EPEs for the non‐entitled people to be on their books because if you want to be a successful EPE you will need a big range of those non‐entitled people on your books so that you can fill industry's needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, we might needs some rules for how you can repeat conversations that we are having all around the place. I think the rule will be that I will never say anything I do not want repeated. That is fine. I think you misheard me, though, in that conversation we had. I stressed wanting them to be treated as individuals. I wanted to work out why people should be excluded because they are in a relationship with others. I said to you I wanted them to be treated as individuals, not excluded because they are either married or in a permanent relationship with others.

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, I did say that of course everybody says to put the unemployed on benefits first. But the point we have been making all along is that there is a difference this time because people might have to pay a fee or, through various means, they are either being excluded or having their services severely reduced for the first time. When you keep saying Labor wants more than it was prepared to give you might be right. But I think the relevant argument is that we are totally changing the regime now.

We are moving into a deregulated corporatised regime where you rely again on competition and level playing fields. If anything we have learnt in this place over the last 10 years is true then we all should look at the theories we are talking about here. We have learnt that the more you deregulate the more you require safeguards. If you take the example of banks and you apply the theories, you look at what deregulation has done, whether competition exists and what level playing fields exist, you find out that when you give up the public provider, which the Commonwealth Bank might have been an equivalent of, you take away levers to influence competition and better standards.

All that is left is for you to say to the banks, `You naughty people; you are not passing on the interest rates' or, `You naughty banks; it looks like there has not been much competition there.' You keep berating us for wanting to put in place a few more safeguards. But we need to do these things because we are moving into a much more deregulated regime. The lessons of the last decade are that you need to be more careful; you need to protect people more, not take rights away from them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point that I think the minister has done a good job at arguing an argument that is not at stake here. If you are reducing services to the unemployed and you are cutting funds for labour market programs and training programs, to come out and say, `This is all about giving priority to the unemployed' is a nice try, but it is one of the worst arguments that I have ever heard, and it is a dishonest argument. What this amendment is about is trying to protect the position whereby people continue to be entitled to the labour exchange services on a universal and free basis that they have enjoyed since 1946, both for employees and employers. We are not trying to stop you giving priority to the unemployed. Your market provides variable amounts of money to allow those people who are long‐term unemployed—those most disadvantaged—to be allocated additional funds to give them priority, to give them special assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: What this amendment is about is stopping you from removing services to rural and regional Australia, to the 400,000 people who currently are registered but not entitled to unemployment benefits, and ensuring that the Commonwealth continues to provide the community service it has provided for 50 years to all Australians. What we are seeking to do is to enshrine that in the legislation. And you are right: a range of these provisions have not been enshrined in the legislation before, because no‐one has suggested before, except in the Fightback document in 1993, that we would walk away from those obligations.

This has not been a live debate. It is not a debate that you had with the Australian public at the last election. It is not one that you have been keen to have now. You have been keen to change the subject. What this is about is ensuring the maintenance and provision of basic labour exchange services as part of the community service obligations in this community. It is not about denying to those registered unemployed the ability to receive assistance in their search for work. That is achieved now under your competitive market. We are supporting that.

This is a separate issue. This is about providing services to those others in the community who are without work and in search of work. You can argue about prioritising the unemployed all you like. It is dishonest. That is not what this is about. It is about your decision, because of the cutbacks in the budget, to save money by not providing that service to those who have received the service in the past. We say that they should continue to receive that service, and we also say that those who are long‐term unemployed, those with other disadvantages, should receive the employment assistance as proposed in other sections of the bill. Let there be no misunderstanding by people who are listening to the debate: the minister's argument is a nonsense. This is about whether you continue to provide basic labour exchange services to all Australians and to Australian employers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about this. You have been through this proposed amendment again and again, Minister, and I think you have put your argument, as Senator Evans says, very well. As I understand it, your argument is that you are going to make services available to people on a competition basis; that competition will provide some regulation and, in addition, there will be some regulations provided by contract, statute and regulations; but, fundamentally, it will be a provision of services on a private enterprise basis with a regulatory regime on top.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that this particular provision provides a much needed insurance against the situation that might arise under the proposed legislation, if this particular amendment is not passed. Section 42 of your amending bill illustrates that. It talks about the terms of agreement to be approved by the Employment Secretary. Subsection (1) reads:
The terms of an Employment Assistance Activity Agreement . . . are to be approved by the Employment Secretary.
This sets up a regime. But then, under subsection (4), it says:
The Employment Secretary may, by writing, delegate all or any of his or her powers under this section in relation to agreements with a particular employment placement enterprise to:
(a) if the enterprise is an individual—the enterprise; or
(b) if the enterprise is a body corporate—a director or employee of the enterprise; or
(c) if the enterprise is a partnership—an individual who is a partner in, or an employee of, the enterprise; or
(d) in any other case—an officer or employee of the enterprise.

What that, in effect, means is that an employment assistance activity agreement can be written by the employment enterprise, which really does not give the person who is entitled to proper services any insurance that he will get those proper services, whereas this amendment suggested by the opposition and the Democrats certainly ensures that. So this does give a much needed protection to people looking for employment services, which the bill does not give. As an illustration of that, I refer you to section 42, but you could go right through division 2 of part 4.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of questions to ask the minister. There have been a number of contributions to this debate on the Reform of Employment Services Bill, and I have listened to it largely on the radio. A number of them have not been specifically addressed towards this particular measure.

BREAK.PARA: The point that Senator Kernot made a while ago was quite valid with regard to there being a system established whereby the PEPE and the EPEs could be scrutinised very carefully as to whether they are efficient, whether they are providing the services that we all want them to provide and whether they are doing that in a fair and reasonable manner. I am attracted to the amendment that the senator is going to move at a subsequent stage of this debate with regard to the establishment of an employment services council. I personally think that ESRA has done a fairly reasonable job to date and I would be inclined to support the amendments that will be subsequently moved by Senator Kernot.

That having been said, I must say that there are some concerns about what will become community EPEs. That is, the provisions of the amendments that we are now discussing may in fact have the result of giving to the PEPE a monopoly over the labour exchange services. I do not know if anybody would care to make a comment on that, but I would like to ask the minister—and I do so saying that I am inclined to support the amendments that have been moved by Senator Evans: is the minister saying that, no matter what we do here in this legislation, the government would have the power to corporatise the public aspect of the service?

Under the current legislation—I am not talking about this legislation—would it then be able to direct the particular organisation to target its services in line with priorities established by the government? Is that what she is saying? Is she saying that, if we pass this legislation now, and if that is not acceptable to the government—and I understand the minister has said there are certain matters that are not acceptable to the government and it is not going to cop it—it will enable her, or the government, to do what she wanted to do anyhow under the provisions of the existing legislation?

I would like to know that but, even if the answer to that is no, I would be inclined at this stage to support Senator Evans's proposals. I must say that I have been in two minds about the whole thing because of what the government appears to be saying—that is, it has power in any event to do the things it wants to do. One then wonders why it brings the legislation before the Senate. I do not know whether one takes from that that there is a commitment on the part of this government to bring parliament into its decision making processes in the widest possible sense.

If that is the case, this government is somewhat unlike other governments that have governed this country, for the 22 years that I have been in the Senate anyhow. But I would hope that the government does look on the parliament as being an important part of the decision making process. Even though it can get its own way by other means, I suppose it is putting forward these matters because 140 minds are better than one, or better than the cabinet. Minister, is it a fact that, if this legislation in the end is not acceptable and if we adopt what Senator Evans is proposing here together with other amendments that have been made or will be made to the legislation, the government is saying that it can achieve its purposes under current legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney referred to the powers of delegation. I will explain it this way. They are exactly the same as what is in the Employment Services Act now. There might be some words slightly different, but for all intents and purposes they are the same. What that relates to is the agreement that the provider makes with the unemployed person under, for example, case management. The previous government set up a system whereby a case manager made an agreement as to what ought to be done and then nobody cared whether the person did it or not. We were not going to have a situation where large amounts of money were being paid for someone to be case managed so that they could not ring their case manager when they were meant to, not go to appointments that were scheduled, not attend training courses or whatever was set up.

SPEECH.PARA: The powers that are delegated, basically, is a system that relates to the continued payment of their income benefit. In a sense, they make an agreement to undertake these activities. If they break that agreement, then they can be breached in relation to the income payment. It is a mechanism to relate the two together. It has nothing to do with the contract that the secretary makes with the employment provider to provide services generally; it has to do with the contract that the employment provider makes with the unemployed person—the agreements that they come to as to the activities they will undertake and the capacity to breach them for not undertaking that activity. That is the difference there.

In relation to Senator Harradine's questions, I am advised that the Commonwealth does have the capacity to establish a PEPE as a separate corporate entity and that it does not require legislative approval to do that. I am advised that the PEPE could be directed to provide services—I would not say willy‐nilly—within certain constraints in accordance with the government's wishes. I have indicated that before.

That would not necessarily be exactly the same as the proposal now before the chamber. This proposal before the chamber obviously differs, in the case of the intents of employment assistance, from case management. It is an extension of it, but it has become something more, something different. Similarly, if we were to go down another route it may be different again. But we would still be talking about providing services and targeting them to unemployed people on benefits and to young Australians first because we are determined to put them first. So, yes is the answer.

Then, Senator Harradine, you asked a question which I think, with respect, we did deal with last time. So I will not go to it at length—that is, if you can do what you want anyway, why would you come to parliament? I hope you meant, kindly—and I do not know if you meant it that way, but I hope you did mean it that way—that you approve of the approach that even if you do not have to come to parliament you might do so.

That is the situation we are in. We knew all along that we would be able to do things differently—not under the Employment Services Act, but under social security legislation. I looked at the two and realised that to go the other way was administratively more difficult. It is just a simple choice. It is administratively more difficult to go the other way, but it may in the end provide better services if that is what we had to do.

The flexibility that is there is just enormous. I was surprised by the degree of flexibility that is there, under existing legislation, for the Commonwealth to provide these services. There is enormous flexibility with almost—in the bounds of this generality that we are discussing—no restraints. That is why I expressed the frustration that now, when we want to corporatise that portion of the CES that has not gone to the shopfront, the opposition that allowed the situation for enormous flexibility in the services it provided when it was in government seeks to restrict this government's flexibility. I do find that particularly frustrating.

I made the decision, for a variety of reasons, that the legislative path would be the one that we would try. But it was not a decision that said, `We have the legislative power to go another way, but we will discard that completely and we will only proceed with these changes if parliament approves every aspect of them.' That was not the decision. The decision was to see if it was possible to get parliamentary approval for these particular changes with certain things that were essential. If that was not possible, there was always the other position to fall back on—administratively more difficult but, nonetheless, there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to respond to Senator Harradine's concern about the question of a monopoly over labour exchange services. I just want to indicate to him that, quite clearly, that is not the intention nor the drafting instruction nor the effect, in my view, of these amendments. Section 9 gives the employment secretary the ability to engage an entity to provide employment services. That entity is defined in the definitions section and includes: individuals, body corporates, partnerships, government departments, et cetera—the whole range of service providers. So the employment secretary may engage any of those entities to provide employment services. Employment services are defined, by the success of our amendment, to include labour exchange services. So we have already established in the amendments already carried to this bill that the employment secretary may engage an entity to provide those services.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are doing with this amendment is not to provide a monopoly but to provide universal access. That is the issue: where persons are ineligible because of the government's decisions and because of their failure to receive unemployment benefits, where the market does not provide, where the service needs to be provided to meet our community service obligations, then the PEPE shall be engaged to provide those.

None of that prevents the government from taking a decision to expand its market or for that market to provide more of those labour market exchange services. Nothing prevents that at all. But what we are saying is that where the government does not provide that as part of the market then it must ensure that the universal access continues to be available to all Australians. So it is not about monopo ly; it is about universal access and providing the PEPE to fill those holes to provide the services to those people who the government would otherwise refuse to provide services to.

I also want to indicate that, from my reading, my attendance at the committee hearings when we inquired into the bill, my letters and my contact with community service providers, I think they would have a concern if there was a suggestion of our moving to make it a monopoly, but they generally support a strong public provider in the marketplace and the continuation of the public provider in that area of the market which is not be let out to competition. That is what this amendment is about—that section of the market that is not part of the competitive model being established by the government. They see a continuing role for the PEPE to service those clients and provide services to those people.

Their major concern is one that I share and which I have raised in estimates committees and other places—that is, the funding of the community service providers and their ability to compete equally on this so‐called level playing field. They have concerns—which, as I say, I share and would appreciate the minister addressing—that, because of their limited capital base, they will not be able to compete effectively in this market with the major international companies who provide employment services. As you know, they have been writing to senators and other members of parliament, seeking support for some measures to try to protect their position so that they are able to compete effectively in the market.

We have a tremendous investment in terms of skills and expertise in those community organisations. When I asked the question at estimates—because the minister had indicated in one of the consultation documents that some provision might be made—the answer was, `No, it is a level playing field. They don't get any advance payments; they compete on the same terms.' As we well know, their view is that that will discriminate against their competing on the same terms, because of their lack of a capital base.

I looked at the question of whether or not we could effectively move an amendment to help in that regard. I do not see it as being possible. If Senator Harradine—or anyone else—has a suggestion as to how we might do that, I would be happy to hear it, because we want to see a market where the PEPE competes on equal terms with community groups and private organisations in the intensive employment assistance area. We want to see them bring all their skills and experience to the market, without facing disadvantages or hindrances because of any particular problems.

So this is not about a monopoly at all. We looked at that question and rejected it. What we are supporting is the continuation of universal access to those labour exchange services for those persons that the government seeks to exclude from the market. If they are in the market, the government can choose to provide those labour exchange services as part of that market approach and, indeed, if the government decided to market just labour exchange for a wider group of people, they could do that also. But what we are insisting upon in these amendments is the maintenance of that universal access.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add one thing to that. When that complaint was made to us, we took our amendments away, re‐examined them and said, `That is not our intention,' and we faithfully believe that the redrafted amendments do not bestow monopoly service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister, for the very lucid explanation of section 42 of the bill. I am still concerned about sections 40 and 42 of the bill and the proposed amendments by the opposition and the Democrats. What sections 40 and 42 do is to make vulnerable people even more vulnerable. If you have vulnerable people who must go to one of a range of employment placement enterprises, and if the government enterprise—the PEPE—is to be no different from the others, it seems to me that no reassurance can be given to a participant in these schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: With the proposed amendments, there is a statutory obligation on a government body to ensure that a high quality labour exchange service is available. It gives a participant in this scheme an ability to go to members of parliament and to government and perhaps even to have the provisions of the proposed section 15A and section 15B enforced. If you do not have that, you have a situation which is perhaps best illustrated by the draft employment assistance activity agreement on page 92 of the tendering conditions and draft contract for employment services—the exposure draft.

That agreement is headed up `Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs', and at the bottom it says, `This form is approved by the employment secretary and the social security secretary under section 42 of the Reform of Employment Services Act.' The impression you get from that is that the agreement to be made between the job seeker and the agency providing it is all agreed to by the government, which is not necessarily so, given the provisions of section 42.

BREAK.PARA: If you carry the proposed amendments, at least you have a protective measure, in so far as you have a government body which can, quite properly and without any confusion, have an agreement—such as that one set out on page 92—signed. Nobody is going to be misled, innocently or otherwise—I am not, in fact, proposing that it would be done dishonestly. Where you have a form that says it is approved by the employment secretary and the social security secretary—whereas in fact it is approved by one of a range of employment agencies—you also have the situation of vulnerable people, as I said before, being misled and taken down a road to their disadvantage. At least to some extent, the amendments proposed by the opposition and the Democrats avoid that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, you made a suggestion that you might need to be careful about what conversations were repeated. Let me assure you that that was a conversation about the bill and I did not, therefore, take it to be a conversation that you were apprehensive about being repeated. It was not a conversation in the nature of a personal conversation. If, however, I have caused you any embarrassment by doing that, then I certainly apologise for doing so. The inference certainly was that you had been caused embarrassment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say that the rudest thing you can say to a fellow lawyer is, `I'll now deal with you in writing.' I have on occasions been tempted, Senator, to say that to you, but I have not thought that you would understand the depth of the insult that would be meant to be passed over in doing that, so I did not bother.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're so charming!

—The point of dealing in writing, Senator, is that what someone says, they stick to. That is the point of it. You have got them then. They are on record, they are in writing and you have got them. If they change their mind, you can wave the letter around. That is why lawyers say that.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Chris Evans—a small amount of polemics on your part. You want to stop us removing services to rural Australians when you know that in your own legislation there is no requirement for them to be provided. I just caution you that your polemics about this government wanting to get stuck into rural Australia will be shown to be as shallow as the polemics offered in relation to higher education, for example, where regional universities were going to fall apart. You were here in question time; you would have heard that they are doing very well. Don't you worry. We will look after regional Australia and look after them very well. They have great confidence that we will do that and are probably looking to improved services.

Senator Cooney, as I understand the points that you are raising, you are looking to ensure the protection of the persons seeking services. I think it is fair to say that part 6 and part 10 provide those protections. There is recourse at the moment, for example, under case management, to the Ombudsman. I genuinely believe there is every protection provided here for a potential employee seeking work.

Yes, Senator Evans, we did believe that your initial amendments provided a lex monopoly to the PEPE. You did not believe that, I know, but you have subsequently changed them. What you are now providing, by way of your amendments, is a guarantee that the PEPE would get lex work. We have the same position on that as we do on everything else, that there are no guarantees that the PEPE, the private providers or the public providers will get any particular services. It will depend on how well they compete for them. I think that might clear up that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that answer, Minister. Referring to the form on page 92, is it the intention that, whatever employment assistance activity agreement is signed, whether by a government organisation such as the PEPE proposed by the opposition and the Democrats or a private provider, the document will have the insignia of the Commonwealth on it; it will be headed, `Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs'; and it will have, at the bottom, `This form is approved by the Employment Secretary and the Social Security Secretary under section 42 of the Reform of Employment Services Bill'? If it does, is it reasonable to suggest that such a form may create in the minds of job seekers—and some of them may not be the most sophisticated people—that what they have signed is set in concrete by the government, that it is a government document, and that they really do not have a way out of the terms of the agreement? If that is so, why don't we abandon such headings?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator, I do not think that is the case, because they freely negotiate the agreement. What goes into the form is an agreement between them and the provider. People will clearly know what their appeal rights are when they want to express some dissatisfaction.

SPEECH.PARA: There are just a couple of points I perhaps have not covered. I am sorry, Senator Evans, you did raise the point about people wanting advance payments and not having sufficient money in the kitty to go ahead with that. Of course, for the intensive employment assistance, they will get an advance payment of 30 per cent. We think that is enough. If you think they either need more advance payments for intensive employment assistance or some advance payment for labour exchange work, I just refer you to Senator Brown's contribution last time in this debate. He raised a concern that a fly-by-nighter might get an advance payment and take off.

You do have to find a balance. We want to provide some advance payments in intensive employment assistance, because it may be expensive to get the services required. But there has to be a limit there somewhere. One of the protections is to say, with respect to labour exchange, `We'll pay you when you get the person the job.' But those current skillshares who tender and get intensive employment assistance work will of course have advance payments for that. But there is a balance to be found. I appreciate that point.

Senator Kernot, just in case I did not answer your question as to the spouse who you say wants to be treated not equally but as an individual, they are treated as an individual and they are assessed by the current Social Security Act as not being an individual in need of a benefit and, therefore, are down the queue from an unemployed person on a benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that fair? Why should they be assessed because they are financially dependent on someone else? That is all I am saying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —And all we are saying—and I think I might have said it to you—is that that is an argument for the Social Security Act. What we have said is that we think that those people who have been judged by the existing legislation to be in need of a benefit are the ones who are most in need and they are the ones we are going to put first, except for young Australians, who we also think, because of the high unemployment rate facing young Australians who are not in education and training and are looking for work, for example, and the difficulty they have with the diminishing number of jobs that are available at the lower and unskilled level, also deserve to be up the top in terms of assistance. But your argument, to the extent that you have one, is with the existing legislation establishing social security entitlements.

—We have to face the facts and see what is going to happen down the track. Whatever happens with this piece of legislation, it is not going to have a great effect, in my view, on the employment situation because the problem of unemployment is that there are more people in or seeking paid work than there are jobs available, at the same time as traditional jobs are being slashed by technological change. Whilst this is an important initiative, I think we are fooling ourselves if we think that we are looking at a panacea for the problems we have. I do not think anyone around this chamber, including the minister, is seeing this as a panacea. But let me go down the track a bit.

BREAK.PARA: I heard what the minister said—that, yes, the government do have the power under existing legislation, the Social Security Act or whatever other legislation there may be, to in fact establish a PEPE and to do so in the manner that they have told us they want. As the minister has indicated, that is going to be administratively more cumbersome than going this particular way and I am encouraged by the statement of the minister that this government does recognise that there is a parliamentary input into various policy matters.

With the minister having said that, if we adopt Senator Evans's proposals, the ones that are coming up for the establishment of the employment services council and some of the other measures including the objects of the legislation, my concern is that, having done all that work, we may see the government then pulp this legislation and do what they want anyhow. That does concern me.

I would like to feel that, even if we do accept the propositions that are currently before us as proposed by Senator Evans, the government ought to give full consideration to these, go back to the House of Representatives and let them give full consideration to these matters and to what is being said in support of them in this chamber. No doubt there will be further matters raised in the House of Representatives and we will see what they think then.

I would hope that would occur. It would give the opportunity for the government to reconsider but in the end I think the amendments, the improvements that the Senate wishes to make to this legislation, should not just be thrown out the window. It may be that, on a sticking point such as this particular matter, the government might say, `We'll amend that in the House of Representatives and bat it back to the Senate to see what they do with it.' Let us see what we do with it at that particular stage but I am rather inclined at this moment to vote for Senator Evans's proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, if I used the word `cumbersome', I did not intend to. It is less convenient but not necessarily much more difficult. You are quite right: I have been at pains to explain to people because this is quite a big change in one respect, yet very simple in another. Some people have said, `Aren't you hoping to fix the unemployment problem by this?' and the answer is no. This is about job matching. It is about what we believe is a better design of employment services and that is a way to match those people who are available for work with the jobs that are available. It is completely unrelated to the generation of jobs. You are quite right in that respect.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chris Evans's ) be agreed to.
