DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (14) Clause 28, page 22 (after line 16), after sub clause (l), insert:
(1A) In making a determination under this section, the Employment Secretary may have regard only to

PARA.TAB: (a) the participant's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition; and
(b) the state of the labour market in the locality where the participant resides; and
(c) the training opportunities available to the participant.

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Clause 31, page 23 (line 29) to page 24 (line 2), omit subclause (1), substitute:
(1) If the Employment Secretary considers that the person could reasonably be referred to one of a number of employment placement enterprises, the notice under section 30 must also:

PARA.TAB: (a) contain, in respect of each employment placement enterprise listed in the notice, details of:

TAB.TAB: (i) any particular areas of specialisation or expertise of the agency;
(ii) results already achieved by the agency in the placement of persons in employment;
(iii) the accessibility of the enterprise in terms of transport; and

PARA.TAB: (b) where reasonably possible, contain details of any associations or organisations, in addition to employment placement enterprises, which may be able to assist the person; and
(c) ask the person to nominate, from that number, an employment placement enterprise to which he or she wishes to be referred.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 14 adds a new subclause which provides:

BREAK.PARA: In making a determination under this section, the Employment Secretary may have regard only to

PARA.TAB: (a) the participant's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition; and
(b) the state of the labour market in the locality where the participant resides; and
(c) the training opportunities available to the participant.

BREAK.PARA: In moving this amendment to Clause 28, we are seeking to make sure that the employment secretary has regard only to those specific matters. Our amendment No. 17 to amend clause 31 requires omitting subclause (1) and including a new subclause which provides for the provision of full information for a person referred to an EPE.

A range of community concerns were raised with us in the committee considering the bill about empowering clients referred to EPEs to ensure that they had full information about both the EPE and the services that they could reasonably provide. These amendments have been suggested by community groups who have experience in dealing with unemployed clients to ensure that those clients have their rights respected and that their power relationship in dealing with EPEs is not such that they do not have full information or are unaware of their own entitlements. These amendments seek to provide some protection and further information for those clients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —In amendment 14 I think we address something that has been removed from the bill, which was the old capacity to benefit test. I welcome the fact that that has been removed, or does not exist in this particular bill. I welcome the fact that this amendment says that these are the only things that you can refer to when someone is referred to an EPE—the participant's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition, the state of the labour market in the area where the participant lives and training opportunities available to the participant.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the old notion of capacity to benefit there were a lot of people who were worried that they would be discriminated against unfairly. People with disabilities were one group. The effect of this amendment is simply to say, `Here's an incredible range of things that you can take into account when deciding whether or not someone can reasonably be referred to an EPE.' I think it is a comprehensive list and I do not think it discriminates. That is the point of that particular amendment.

Amendment 17, as Senator Chris Evans said, simply says that helping job seekers to choose the particular EPE which is right for them is appropriate because it will probably greatly enhance the likelihood of their achieving a successful employment outcome. In order to make a choice about the most appropriate EPE, I think job seekers need to be fully informed about the options which are available, and that is what this amendment does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The import of what we want to do here is to simply provide the basis for the cap and queue. We have cap and queue at the moment. I think that is the terminology in Immigration, but it is used in case management. There is not enough money to put everybody through case management who wants it. There was not under the previous government and there is not now. When the moneys run out and there is not enough money to pay for that service to be delivered, it would not be inappropriate to send someone. That is what this clause is getting at. It is not about the capacity to benefit; it is about whether the resources are available.

SPEECH.PARA: Since you mention the capacity to benefit, Senator Kernot, I just point out that if the resources were not available and you added that in—just say that you were prepared to agree to that amendment—which would allow the secretary to not have people referred when there was no money left, you would allow the secretary a much broader and less defined scope to refuse people. None of us like the terminology `capacity to benefit' but you would be creating a much looser capacity to refuse people in addition to funds not being available for other reasons, very loosely defined, which I think would be a mistake.

BREAK.PARA: All of us would like to imagine that everybody has the capacity to benefit from intensive employment assistance, but the community groups will tell you that that is not the case and that it is not fair to put people assistance who do not have that capacity through intensive employment. It is because of the consultations that we had with community groups following the release of the broad outline of these changes that we have introduced the community support program, which I think is worth about $10 million or maybe $11 million a year. It will mostly be for community providers to act as brokers and help these people find the appropriate help they need. If they have a drug problem and that is what is stopping them getting to work, intensive employment assistance is not going to fix that. They may have an alcohol problem or a mental illness problem. Often people in those circumstances do not know where to go to get help. No government before has provided a program like the community support program. I am grateful to the community providers for their advice and assistance in putting this together as a means of saying, `We'll help these people.'

You could argue that it is not an employment matter. If somebody does not have a capacity to benefit from intensive employment assistance and they have got another problem, you could say it is somebody else's problem. This department has been prepared to say, `It's our problem to help you find assistance to get rid of whatever it is that is putting you in a position at the moment so as to not benefit from intensive employment assistance.' That is why we have introduced that aspect of it. I will come to amendment 17 later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments 14 and 17 are together, Minister.

—Perhaps I should have suggested that they be taken separately. I would like to speak very briefly on amendment No. 14. I had a look at this and I am not sure that there is a very substantial reason to have amendment 14. Senator Kernot mentioned that it could discriminate against persons with disabilities, but that would then be illegal, I would have thought.
—I will put amendment 14 separately to amendment 17.

—Senator Harradine, under the provisions as they stand, the employment secretary can determine whether or not a person can reasonably be referred for intensive employment assistance. We are just saying that we think the factors which the employment secretary can be required to take into consideration should be limited. While we do not object to people getting community support, I think it is difficult to put in place factors which say whether they, for example, have an alcohol problem. If you look at other things, you will find that those who have problems will be referred anyway. I think it is wrong to include them in the referral. That is all we are saying. The capacity to benefit is not there anymore, but I think it informs our thinking.

—Minister, as I understand it, we are looking at section 28 of the Reform of Employment Services Bill. I took you to be saying that that is a provision that enables a cap and queue to be instituted. Am I right? If so, I do not see how you can tease such a proposition out of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, you might like to tell me, perhaps during the dinner break because I cannot see it now, how 28(1) refers to capacity to benefit.
—No, I said it's not in there.
—Yes, but it was not in here in the beginning.
—I just said it informs the thinking on screening people.

—Section 28(1)—section 28 contains (1) and (2), which is what we would have without (1A) being inserted—is for where the employment secretary con siders that a participant could not reasonably be referred to an employment placement enterprise. There are two reasons why that might be the case. One is that there are no resources. We have a limited amount of resources supplied to case management now anyway, so it is no different from that which we operate under now. There is a limited amount of money set aside for case management.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing might be that all the providers in that area are full. Quite apart from getting near the end of the year and not having enough money, they might be full. They each might be contracted. Just imagine four providers in one area of a region all contracted to have 100 people and all having 100 people on their books, so there just is not a place available in a provider at that time. That is what that is intended to get to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose this clause is judiciable. It is just terribly difficult to see how either of the situations that you talk about could be teased out of the expression `could not reasonably be referred to an employment placement enterprise'. I take it that what you are saying is that `reasonably' means economically viable. Is `economically viable' meant rather than `reasonable'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, section 28 is one of the decisions that cannot be reviewed. Decisions made under sections 27 and 28 are one of the non‐reviewable decisions.

—If somebody says `You have made a wrong decision here; it is not a reasonable decision, it is not a decision within the law,' would it be subject to a prerogative writ? You could certainly take that up on a prerogative writ, I would have thought. All I am saying is that it seems a very clumsy way of going about obtaining what you want. `Reasonably' usually means that, in all the circumstances—given the person's abilities, given the time and place—people cannot be referred. What you really are talking about there is not what is reasonable but what is economically or physically viable. I just say to you that you are leaving yourself open to people so minded to litigation. You cannot rule out litigation if you want to go off to the High Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, as I am advised, these provisions—I put the qualifier that there might be some commas and odd words here and there that are different—are essentially the same as those used to cap on case management. So the same situation applies where someone wants to be case managed and there is not a place. It is the same situation that we now have. I do not have any advice about whether someone has ever tried a prerogative writ against the employment secretary or whether they could. But I am advised that we are looking at the same sort of situation to handle the total resources available and the placements available in particular providers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed amendments indicate the sorts of things people would normally interpret as being referred to by the expression `could not reasonably be referred to an employment placement enterprise'. Those are, as amendment 14 states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the participant's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition; and
(b) the state of the labour market in the locality where the participant resides; and
(c) the training opportunities available to the participant.
As I understand it, they do not in any way encompass what is meant by `reasonably be referred to' in section 28(1).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just concerned that what the minister is saying is that, in an unreviewable decision, an eligible person effectively becomes ineligible for even a basic labour exchange service—not intensive case management, but a basic labour exchange service—if for some reason the EPEs in the area say, `We've filled all the places available. We haven't got a place available anymore.' Whether there are jobs out there they might be able to find for the person or not, the person is not going to be referred.

SPEECH.PARA: I had not fully understood that this provision was to be used other than to deal with circumstances of futility. What is being said now is that this is an economic tool to be used by the department broadly or narrowly to deny otherwise eligible persons even a basic labour exchange service. That is an even bigger reason why we should pass the amendment which Senator Chris Evans moved on behalf of the opposition and the Democrats. It is incredible that one could envisage circumstances where, because of the government's budgetary constraint, there may be jobs that a person on benefit could be targeted for through PEPEs but because the quota for that part of the year—the quarter, the half year or that portion of the year—has been taken up, that person is not referred at that time.

If this legislation is going to give the employment secretary the power to trickle out the unemployed over a period of a year, for example, then I think this is bad legislation. Whether that provision was in existence previously or not, in this environment—which is quite different from the previous environment—we are going to create a different circumstance. If this provision is passed unamended, we are going to be creating a circumstance where an eligible person will not be eligible for anything—except perhaps looking at touch screens—merely because of the financial constraints placed on that region by the employment secretary.

It might be that I am constructing circumstances that seem foreign, but they are possibilities. Given that the minister has talked about what might be done under other legislation that was not intended to cover the circumstances she is talking about with this bill, in future someone might use this provision to do something that was never envisaged—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is envisaged.

—Senator Cooney invites me to say that it is envisaged. Perhaps it is a question of degree as to just exactly what is envisaged and how this would be intended to work. Taking into account what the minister has said, there are even stronger grounds for the amendment Senator Evans moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Brien, perhaps I could be of assistance. If you go past the list of contents and come to part 2 on page 9, you will see that that deals with the provision of employment services. That is, generally speaking, all employment services other than intensive employment assistance. If you turn over a few pages and come to part 3 on page 15, you will see that that is the part that deals with intensive employment assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: It is that part that the clause we are dealing with—that is, clause 28—is a part of. This clause does not deal with a capacity to deny someone labour exchange. It only deals with the capacity to ascertain the appropriateness and capacity at the time for intensive employment assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't the point that Senator O'Brien made correct? This legislation—as you have said again and again for weeks now, Senator Vanstone—is directed in a way that would advantage those most in need. You have said that and you have explained that—and I use the word `explained' loosely—on several occasions. But proposed section 28, as Senator O'Brien said, seems specifically aimed at putting a limit to that.

SPEECH.PARA: You say that there is only going to be a certain amount of money available or, alternatively, that there is only going to be a certain number of places available. You have made that clear. But don't you come back to the proposition that section 28 seems to spell out loud and clear that this scheme is to be a limited one and that there is no real test of whether that limit is reasonable or not, beyond the judgment made by the employment secretary? That judgment, as you say, is not capable, in any event, of being administratively reviewed. There just seems to be a worrying gap in the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to go back a couple of steps and recap what we are talking about. We are talking about what is essentially a streaming process, aren't we?
—Oh—

—Yes, we are, even though it is not in the bill. We are talking about, in the first instance, people being assessed as eligible for intensive employment assistance. If you are assessed as not being eligible then under your broader scheme of things there is a community support program. You were wanting to take into account things like whether there was an alcohol problem, whether there was a grooming problem and whether there were literacy problems. Could you tell us how it would work if someone was assessed as not being eligible for intensive employment assistance and they had to go to the community support program? It is not covered in here, but you are relying on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with this clause now and this clause deals with the means by which the secretary cannot refer someone on in a very similar way to what happens now because of the limit of funds. Case management is now a capped program. It was, in the past, a capped program. It also deals with the capacity to not refer someone because all of the employment providers who have been contracted for places have people in those places. This clause does not deal with the capacity to benefit. This is not the appropriate power relating to that matter. This is a resources clause and a capacity to find a spot clause; it is not the one dealing with those people who might be judged as not having the capacity to benefit because when they went to the shopfront the job classification instrument so classified them. They are different sections.
—I ask the same question, Minister. What happens to the people who are deemed ineligible, even under these criteria?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the same question, Senator. I am trying to keep the debate on the clauses we are dealing with.
—Yes, but—

—Senator, I will come to your question. We have now spent maybe 10 hours on this bill when it was decided we would probably get through it in eight. I am simply trying to keep the debate to the clauses at hand. What happens to the people who do not get referred as a consequence of clause 28 is the same as what happens to someone now who is on a list waiting for case management; that is, they do not get case management until the funds are available or the places are available. That is what happens.

—Being deemed ineligible for a range of reasons is relevant. If you want to stick to this particular clause, that is okay, but the context is relevant too. If they are going to be deemed ineligible, are they ineligible to be considered for assessment under the other clause we are going to come to which is `informed by a capacity to benefit'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —You can say capacity to benefit is in context because it is in the bill. You might as well ask the question anywhere in the bill. This clause does not deal with those matters; this is purely a resources thing.
—I know.

—Well, I don't know why you keep asking the same question in relation to a clause that does not deal with that. This clause does not deal with that: it deals with the resources available—case management now, which is not the same as but is similar to intensive employment assistance. It is a capped program. There is no willy‐nilly amount of money available. Providers have contracts to handle a certain number of places at a particular time and if the money has run out and/or all providers in that area are full, someone is going to have to wait until a provider is successful in placing people and they move from having 100 places full down to 99 places and when a place is available they can go into it.

SPEECH.PARA: But if you are going to continue to ask the same question I suppose I will answer the question you want to ask right out of context just to suit you. Why not? You are the Democrats; why not? If you would like to ask it now, let us deal with your queries now, completely unrelated as they are to the sections of the bill. Let us deal with it now to save everybody having to listen to you ask the same question again and again and be given the same answer again and again.

The community support program is, in this respect, similar to LEAP, to new work opportunities and to a whole range of other labour market programs. They are not programs that have a legislative base. You can pore through here to your heart's content but you will not find it. It is the same as LEAP in that respect and the same as new work opportunities and other labour market programs; in other words, a service is delivered under appropriation powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you look at clause 119, to whom would you contemplate delegating power under clause 28—what members of the staff of the agency and what officers of the department—in making a decision which is fairly important?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We dealt with part of this question in the previous debate. You were concerned about an element of the secretary's powers. I would have to go back and check the record, but I said, roughly, that, in relation to contracting, the decision had not at that point been made—I have not subsequently checked whether it has—and the secretary would be considering very seriously whether to delegate at all. But under 28, without having discussed it with the secretary, I think the delegation would be appropriate because the contracting will be done on regional bases. The question of whether five providers in the area or 50 providers are all full is something that is going to be in the particular knowledge of someone closer to the coalface than the secretary can possibly be in each of those respects.
—The question is that amendment 14 be agreed to.
—The question now is that amendment 17 be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party believes that the government's proposal for a constitutional convention is a political exercise, an unnecessary and ill-conceived political exercise. We strongly believe that the best way to achieve a republic is via a sustained and rational debate by all Australians leading to an indicative plebiscite and, ultimately, a referendum.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the holding of a constitutional convention was a Howard pre-election pledge. It is an unusual pledge because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) intends to honour it. I acknowledge that it is the preferred vehicle of the government's to progress the debate on the republic, but the proposals in this bill, which include a massive change from compulsory to voluntary voting, holding a postal ballot, not an attendance ballot and a change to optional preferential voting—all of which are of the greatest significance to all Australians—were never canvassed by the coalition before this legislation was introduced.

Labor will not accept the government's plan to hold a non-compulsory postal ballot for the convention. The Liberals, in our view, are playing a huge confidence trick on the Australian people. These proposals are a blatant attempt to gain partisan political advantage for the Liberals, but the Liberals' master plan is also a grave error of judgment. Compulsory attendance ballots are a very strong tradition in Australia and the nature of such a ballot allows for a full national expression of the Australian people on their choice of representatives. Voting should be a communal act by Australians en masse, an affirmation of their commitment to democracy and its public processes.

Both Mr Howard and Senator Minchin are on the record in the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 May as stating they `won't be budged' from the proposed voluntary ballot and that it was `non-negotiable'. Perhaps they should think a little more seriously about this because Mr Howard's experiment with voluntary voting is signalling to all concerned that he does not regard the constitutional convention as important and that in fact a debate over the republic of Australia is a second string issue. Of course, many of the appointed delegates to the convention, those from the various parliaments around Australia, have themselves been elected at compulsory attendance ballots.

Similarly, any referendum on an Australian head of state would require a compulsory attendance ballot. Somehow, in the middle of all this, Mr Howard is proposing to introduce a gross mutation to and manipulation of our traditional voting system. The Prime Minister has to realise that, however much he wants to ignore the republic, it is an issue of passionate debate, it is an issue of vital national import ance and it is one every Australian should be engaged in.

In the many submissions to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee regarding this bill, there is an overwhelming call for the vote to be made compulsory. Ethnic groups, Aboriginal groups, women's groups and many individuals who do care that this convention is properly representative mount strong arguments in favour of the compulsory vote to ensure that everyone has their say.

The supporters of compulsory voting even include former Liberal Party apparatchik Mr Petro Georgiou. In his paper entitled `The case for compulsory voting', presented to the John Stuart Mill Society, he says that voluntary voting in the national context would be a grave mistake because it would overturn what is an ingrained political tradition. He says:
. . . to overturn compulsory voting would give the community an unequivocal signal that we as society's elected representatives have diminished our commitment to voting as a civic duty.

Let me explain why Labor so strongly supports our current system of compulsory voting in Australia and why the Australian Labor Party will entirely reject any moves away from this system. Compulsory voting is the hallmark of our democratic electoral system. It is what empowers people in the Australian democratic process. Everyone has a stake in the outcome and we believe that it is essential in our democracy.

When all Australians have had the opportunity to participate in the electoral process, whether you like the outcome or not, it is pretty hard to argue the outcome is not the will of the people. We are absolutely committed to the system of compulsory voting that has served this country so well and any moves away from this system will be strongly opposed by Labor, despite whatever threats the Prime Minister and his cronies may wish to hold over us.

Compulsory voting has been part and parcel of the Commonwealth electoral law since 1924. It is worth recalling that, when introducing the Commonwealth Electoral Bill, Senator Herbert Payne of the National Party said:

If people exhibit no interest in the selection of their representatives, it must necessarily follow, in the course of time, that there must be considerable deterioration in the nature of laws governing the social and economic development of this country.

Since that time, voters have, in Senator Payne's words, ensured that those who live under our form of government `see that it is democratic not only in name but in deed'. I challenge anyone to dispute that the system of compulsory voting has operated successfully throughout the country. Moreover, research has consistently shown that a vast majority of Australian voters support it. Professor Don Aitkin, commenting on his own research, wrote:

A plausible explanation is that the great majority of Australians subscribe to the belief not only that they ought to vote, but that unless citizens do in fact turn out and vote the framework of their democratic society will be in some danger.

People genuinely accept that citizenship and participation in a social democracy brings with it certain obligations—obligations that are largely unquestioned as part of our daily lives: paying taxes, attending school, driving on the right side of the road, abiding by the law and, of course, compulsory voting in elections. The acceptance by society of such obligations is what keeps and promotes our social and political cohesion.

Compulsory voting actually diminishes the alienation of the disadvantaged and disaffected from the political process. What we in the Labor Party believe is that compulsory voting actually provides society with a sense of ownership of the results of elections regardless of their outcomes. Voluntary voting would actually remove the obligation that is currently placed upon people to participate or to take an interest in issues that affect them.

So why does this government want to undermine our system of compulsory voting? There are two agendas that are being pursued by the Howard government through this legislation. The first is to throw obstacles into the path of the republic. The second, and more insidious, is their commitment to undermine our democratic process by abolishing compulsory voting in favour of a voluntary system.

The Liberal Party Federal Council supported voluntary voting in 1988. Senator Parer, when he was shadow administrative services minister, was an enthusiastic advocate. Senator Minchin has been an obsessive supporter. Senator Minchin has just convinced all government members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to support voluntary voting. Only yesterday, the committee recommended that Australia's compulsory voting system be scrapped.

Electoral procedures for this convention are really the first step in the Liberal's implementation of that policy. We say that the Liberal's approach is fundamentally un-Australian. We have already heard a lot of arguments from the conservatives against compulsory voting. The two most frequently used arguments are that it restricts the freedom of the individual and that the vote of the apathetic voter is not worth having.

We believe that the burden of compulsory voting is extremely light—and, certainly, it is perceived to be so by the vast majority of voters. In fact, it was ex-Senator Chris Puplick who described voting as `a minimum obligation of citizenship'. He said:

Strong and effective democracy requires at least a minimum degree of participation by all its citizens, not just those who are anxious to influence the system so as to get something out of it. The decisions of government affect everyone and they are much more likely to be made on behalf of everyone if everyone plays at least some role in selecting the members of Parliament.

The argument that compulsory voting caters to the lowest common denominator by enabling elections to be decided by the least informed and the most apathetic is elitist in the extreme. I believe that elitist view was encapsulated in the words of the Liberal's long time candidate and now member for Canning, Ms Ricky Johnston. She was reported as saying in 1992:
A compulsory system meant `dregs of society' got a say whereas with voluntary voting only those who were interested actually cast a vote.

There is little doubt that under systems of voluntary voting those who tend to turn out are overwhelming middle to upper class and better educated than those who do not. All available evidence that I have seen about non-voters points to the fact that they tend to be young, from lower socioeconomic groups, often of a non-English speaking background and disadvantaged. In short, they are the people for whom governments have a special responsibility. They are the groups who have less access to the resources to enable them to put their views forward to influence policy formulation. Who is to say that their vote is to be given less weight than that of the so-called `informed' sections of our society? They are John Howard's so-called `poor', `needy' and `most vulnerable in our society'. There is no wonder that Mr Howard wants to disenfranchise those to whom he promised so much and to whom he has delivered so little—in fact, those people in our society whom Mr Howard and his government have abandoned.

With the constitutional convention, the government has tried to advocate that Australians should not be compelled to vote at a ballot for a convention that is not binding. Yet, as we said in our minority report on this bill, the convention will be binding to the extent that its recommendations will form the model of the republic that will ultimately be put to the people at a referendum.

The bill advocates not only voluntary voting but a voluntary postal ballot. This is again a first for a Commonwealth election—plebiscite or referendum? We in the Labor Party believe that it is a very retrograde and serious precedent to set. A voluntary postal vote will not deliver on John Howard's commitment to a consultative process involving all Australians considering the issue of Australia becoming a republic. Labor is implacably opposed to a postal ballot for the constitutional convention.

Anyone who has changed their address since the last election and not notified the Australian Electoral Commission is going to miss out on a ballot paper. This will wipe out the vote of many hundreds of thousands of people. Anyone who may have trouble with the ballot paper or the process—and it is an unnecessarily complicated process and I want to address that issue later—would normally be assisted at a polling booth. Those people will now have to rely on an—as yet unfunded—hotline. Worse still, material will only be available in written English. For the blind, the frail aged, the illiterate, the disabled, the incapacitated and those who have trouble with the English language—tough! The government is not concerned enough about their vote—or our democratic process—to provide the level of assistance that they require.

It is also important to consider the experience of voluntary postal ballots in Australia. Voter turnout is generally poor. In our minority report we cited turnout figures of—at best—60 to 70 per cent. More usually, the figure is around 30 to 40 per cent. This result will only serve to fuel the arguments regarding lack of consensus about whatever might be the eventual outcome of the convention.

The decision to hold a voluntary postal ballot has been defended by the government on the grounds of cost. Our response to that very feeble excuse is simple. The cost of democracy has never before been an issue in this country; it should not be an issue now. What price do the Liberals put on democracy? A measly—in this context—$13 million. With the help of the Australian Electoral Commission, the government has costed the postal ballot at just over $36 million, while they estimate a compulsory attendance ballot would cost only $49 million. The difference in cost of $13 million will be further reduced if larger envelopes are required by the AEC to post voting material to enrolled electors and if a number of other factors—that Senator Bolkus will outline—come into play.

We say to the government that, whether the difference between a compulsory attendance ballot and a voluntary postal ballot is $13 million or less than $13 million, the integrity of our electoral system is worth the money. And, if the government is looking for up to $13 million for this, perhaps they can find it in their $1 billion Federation—slush—Fund. There seems to be plenty to go round there. There is no defence—budgetary or otherwise—for the government's proposed voluntary postal ballot. It can be justified only in terms of this government's lack of commitment to a republic and its desire to fundamen tally change our electoral system for its own political advantage by introducing voluntary voting through the backdoor.

In a move that only demonstrates further the government's desire to make this whole process as difficult and complex as possible, the government has proposed a ballot paper design and voting instructions which are so complex that voters will inevitably be confused and alienated. While the ballot paper layout allows either above or below the line voting, the actual ballot paper is quite different from the Senate style ballot paper to which Australians have become accustomed.

The government's voting system for the convention allows optional preferential voting at the federal level for the first time in our history. Below the line voters can cast a formal vote for from one up to the total number of delegates to be elected in any state or territory. But it is not easy. What you have to do is place the candidate number of your preferred candidate in the first preference box and so on. You find the numbers in the guide to the Constitutional Convention, which is sent in the same envelope as the ballot paper. This—deliberately, cold‐bloodedly and with political opportunism—makes the casting of a formal vote as hard as possible. In above the line voting, groups and candidates can lodge a group voting ticket showing preferences for candidates at least to the number of candidates to be elected. Up until this proposal came before parliament, well‐motivated governments had tried to make our voting procedures as simple, straightforward and accessible as possible. The Labor Party believes that, on an issue as significant as whether Australia becomes a republic, we must maximise the opportunities for Australians to express a view.

What Mr Howard is saying, by introducing voluntary postal voting in this bill, is that those who are elected to the convention will have a diminished role, even though they will be discussing one of the most vital constitutional changes that this nation could ever contemplate. It is clear what agenda Mr Howard and Senator Minchin really have: they do not want a convention or a republic, but they do want to change the fundamental nature and characteristics of Australia's electoral system—not just for this convention but for good.

It is the thin end of the wedge. The Liberals are using this election of delegates to the Constitutional Convention to attack the integrity of Australia's electoral system, but we in the Labor Party will never back away from the Australian ballot—a compulsory attendance, secret ballot which is the Australian way of voting. We will never accept the Liberals' perversion of our electoral system, a system which Australians are proud of and rightly regard as the best in the world. We will do everything possible to ensure the convention does not become just a device for Mr Howard to smother the republic and rort our electoral system. The first step along the way is to make the ballot for the delegates to the convention a compulsory attendance, secret ballot in the tried and true Australian tradition.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak off the cuff about an issue that is extraordinarily important in the history of this country, and that is the opportunity, as we move into the next century and indeed the next millennium and mark the hundredth year of our unity as a country, to upgrade and update our democracy, and to look forward to the sort of democracy we as a society want in a vastly changed world in the 21st century. In the wake of the last election, we have the proposal for a constitutional convention coming from this government and in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset that the Greens believe that the Constitutional Convention is a means of empowering the people, rather than the politicians, to formulate the sort of society and indeed the sort of parliament and government that they want to see working for them in the future. At the outset then, it is logical that we stand for a fully elected convention. We are opposed to the government appointing half the delegates. That has echoes of the Indonesian form of democracy, where the government appoints the heart and the people get to, within restrictions, appoint the other half.

Let me also say at the outset that we believe that this convention should be at least working on an indication of what the people want. It would be logical, it would be sensible, it would be democratically wise and, finally, it would be expedient in terms of the use of public money, were there to be a plebiscite with the election of those delegates for this Constitutional Convention—which is coming up in August, September or October—whereby people could vote for a republic or the continuation of a monarchy.

Then you would have a convention which had a directive—if the opinion polls are right—to work on what sort of republic the people of this country want, rather than a convention which is very likely to bog down into a dispute between those on it who feel that the monarchy should be retained and those who feel that we should be making a fresh start and that we are long overdue in this nation to have an Australian as head of state. If that is the outcome, and it is very likely to be, then there is going to be a great deal of wasted time and there is going to be a need for a consequent referendum anyway. Let us have the referendum now with this vote and let the convention get on with the business of formulating the republic, rather than wasting time with a debate on whether or not we should have one.

It is an historic opportunity to turn the constitution from a means of bringing together a disparate group of British colonies strung around the coastline of this great continent, to a means of stating the rights and responsibilities of Australia and, in so doing, charting Australia's role both domestically and globally in the next century.

We could do little better than to begin with the Australian ethos of a fair go and consider whether we might not write into the constitution an injunction to all those people who represent Australians in the future, that they should, in the consideration of every matter, not only be thinking of us now but also of those later—of going back to the wisdom of the indigenous people in this continent and around the world, which takes note of those who have come before us as well as those who will be there after us. At the very least, they should ask this question which should, I believe, be across the portals of this parliament: In everything we do, will people 100 years from now thank us for having done it? It is a very simple question, but it is revolutionary in its effect.

It would mean that instead of the expedience of the current economic fundamentalism, the impulsive and self-gratifying line of politics and, indeed, culture that is the hallmark of our current acquisitive and, in many ways, destructive society, we would be on the road back to a caring and long-sighted society which thought about those who come after us and, moreover, acted in their interests. I believe that we cannot really assess a quality of life for ourselves unless it takes into account the quality of life that we are bequeathing and shaping for those who come after us.

I believe that, if you look at the economic fundamentalism, the materialism, the gross self‐investment of current society in this country and around the world, you have to be appalled at the short‐sightedness of it, at the greed and at the lack of concern for those who come after us.

Last week, in the wake of an historic agreement between the state of Victoria and the Prime Minister of this country, I was motivated to go to the forests of Goolengook, the national estate forests in East Gippsland, to see how state and federal governments working together could be providing for that long‐term interest for future generations, if not for the rights of our fellow creatures on this planet. What I found frankly appalled me. Here we had grand forests, ancient forests, much of which was standing there at the time the Aboriginal people first sighted Batman and Fawkner, and which, with all its wildlife, is being fed to the chainsaws and bulldozers and shipped out at 20c a tonne to woodchippers making $75 a tonne as the forests are sent on their way to the paper mills, and therefore the rubbish dumps, ultimately, of the Northern Hemisphere.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that the simple dictum, if genuinely undertaken in everything we do, not only in parliaments but in boardrooms, in staffrooms, at home and in the neighbourhood, were to be asked in our deliberations, `What will people 100 years from now think of us in what we are doing?', it would radically change the decision making of the variety which allows us to sell for a quick profit ancient forests which ought to be part of the life, the inspiration, the adventure, the wonderment of all future generations of Australians. I feel that, instead of their thanks, we are bequeathing future generations anguish and anger at us for our short‐sightedness, our greed and our inability to deal with the rapaciousness which so often goes with the thirst for profit in the latter part of the 20th century.

We have an economic rationalist age upon us which needs curbing. We do not have a constitution or a set of laws which is about to do that but we do have an historic opportunity here to stop in our tracks and think about it. I think it would be better if this Constitutional Convention were left to the people and not to elected politicians, and were wholly given across to the representatives of the people and not to half the appointees of the government of the day, if we were to aim to really change for the better the way this country works for future generations and, indeed, the way it works as part of the community of nations in a century which has seen us go from an isolated distant part of the world to a part of a very small inter‐reactive single community of six billion people on this finite, beautiful little planet that we have inherited.

One of the things that ought to be looked at in a Constitutional Convention, in this historic opportunity, is a bill of rights, which a majority of Australians support according to opinion polls and which, as a very minimum, ensures that no Australians, no matter how small the minority in which they exist, are subject to discrimination, and a bill of rights which is built upon that ethic of a fair go on which I spoke at the outset. I quote from Mike Salvaris, the Senior Research Fellow at the Swinburne University of Technology in Melbourne who made a speech on May Day about the republic and, in part, said:

Constitutions can contain many important rights and in fact overseas examples show that they do. They can entrench fundamental human rights including all those which Australia has technically signed in international conventions but not implemented. One example: twenty years ago we signed a convention to make post‐secondary education free and what we've actually done is introduce fees. They can enshrine the right to local government. They can make full employment a mandatory goal of national policy. They can make industrial rights part of our constitutional rights and they can explicitly define rights that are often neglected, such as economic and environmental rights. They can set out the major goals and obligations and goals of key national bodies like the Reserve Bank which without legal direction has become a tool of private banks. They can enshrine our right to public ownership of major public utilities. They can make politicians more accountable and set out basic principles for open and honest government.

Many Australians believe these things should be included in a constitution. But it seems that the politicians think otherwise. National research in 1993 showed that 70% of Australians support the idea of a Bill of Rights enshrined in the constitution but about the same percentage of coalition parliamentarians actually oppose it.

Mr Salvaris goes on to point out towards the end of his speech the extraordinary situation we have on the planet in this heightened age of materialism where there are 358 billionaires who own between them the same as 2½ billion of the poorest people on this planet. I add to that, that one billion of those people are simply unable to get enough food to put in their bellies or to feed their children, and ensure that their children have the right to grow up and be fulfilled adults and part of the community.

We could and should, at the outset, recognise the indigenous people of this nation. We should recognise their prior occupation as the first nation people of Australia with a commitment to their rights and gratitude for the richness and tapestry of their culture which is imbued in the national tapestry itself and which makes Australia so special, so different and potentially so much wiser than simply draw on those cultures which have been brought to this continent and neglect that special, appropriate and land‐recognising and related culture of the indigenous people.

We can build into our constitution the concept of global rights and responsibilities. After all, we are in a single global community. We forget our obligation to move towards a global democracy, a global constitution and a globally responsive and responsible community of people. We simply leave that role to the multinational corporations, which are unelected, unrepresentative and totally short of the task of reflecting what the six billion people on this planet think, let alone able to understand the plight of the poorest half of the people in the world and indeed the poorest people in our own community in Australia. We could enshrine in that global democracy a simple statement of the tenets of democracy as we see them: one vote for one person and one value for one vote.

We could, of course, recognise in our constitution our obligation to the environment of this wonderful continent of ours—in particular, our obligation to ensure that it is left the better for our passing and is not serially degraded at record rates as is the case at the moment by each successive term of government, by each successive round of business and by each successive group of people who think that they can leave the problems of environmental degradation on the sideboard for the next generation to pick up.

That said, the Greens will be moving amendments to this legislation, which aims to establish a constitutional convention elected in the spring and sitting in December. As I said earlier, we will be aiming specifically to have an indicative plebiscite with the vote so that the convention can work on what sort of republic we want, if that is the wish of the Australian people, rather than get bogged down in a non-productive debate between the monarchists and those who want an Australian as our head of state.

Secondly, we should ensure that the elections for the Constitutional Convention are conducted similarly to elections for the Senate, including public funding. We will be moving amendments to that effect. I was impressed by Senator Faulkner, who spoke directly before me. Let me say this straight out: there is a move within the conservatives, by the Liberals and the National Party in this country, to get away from compulsory voting, which ensures that everybody's voice is heard, at least in the ballot box. It is a move towards giving greater power to those who already have and diminishing the power of those who do not have. It is the thin end of the wedge.

The move to simply having non-compulsory postal voting can be seen as downgrading the power of the people in the outcome of a constitutional convention while, at the same time, being an experiment to allow those who want to to change our grand compulsory voting system in this country, ultimately the fairest form of ensuring that everybody votes in future policy moves by governments at state and federal levels.

Thirdly, we will be moving amendments to ensure that all delegates to the Constitutional Convention are elected. We do not believe the government should be appointing people. We believe that the people should be totally empowered in so far as this Constitutional Convention is concerned. Why is it that governments cannot trust the people? Why is it that it is considered that 150 or so delegates are not available out there in the ranks of we 18 million and more Australians to bring a fresh, new view to the way our constitution should be shaped? It is because there is fear that the security we have in this now century‐old system, which vastly needs reforming, will be changed and that we as individuals will lose out. We should do better than that and put our trust in the people.

Fourthly, we will be moving amendments to ensure that the information that goes out from candidates about this important Constitutional Convention election vote is available in a language which people understand. For communities that have more than five per cent of people who do not speak English, it will be up to those who are standing in the election—and this will be available to them if our amendments succeed—to print material in the languages of those people so that they clearly understand what they are voting for.

Finally, we will be moving amendments to ensure that the Constitutional Convention, a gathering of elected people, can set its own agenda, can move beyond the agenda set by the government and can hasten and broaden the process as we move towards the new century. I think it would be a good thing if Greens policy, for example, for proportional representation in our house of government, the House of Representatives, were adopted. It would more clearly reflect, as the Senate does, the wish of the people rather than simply having a system which determines which of the big parties is set to govern. We would have greater plurality and more parties and independents in our parliament. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1897 and 1898 Australians from all colonies except Queensland gathered in Adelaide, Sydney and Melbourne to hold the constitutional conventions that led Australia down the historic path to federation. The founding fathers did so in a spirit which, despite the many divisions that existed in their respective home colonies, had at its core the belief that they were involved in the task of nation‐building, of shaping the form that a new Australian federation would take. It was a task that they took on regardless of their personal views as to whether the Australian colonies should take the final step towards nationhood. A century later, this government has no such vision and no such spirit. It has designed a process for constitutional reform based on fear. It is a process that is designed to pull Australians apart, not one designed to bring them together. It is a process that will entrench division, rather than promote the consensus that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) claims he wants.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than embrace and consider change in an open and constructive way, this government and, in particular, this Prime Minister have been dragged into adopting a process for constitutional reform that is, and has been, all about avoiding the very reform that it sought. Have no doubt about this: this is a process designed to alienate Australians from both the process and the outcome. It is designed to minimise their involvement so that this government can, at the end of the day, disregard and discredit the genuine desire that an overwhelming proportion of Australians have to resolve this issue. It seeks to take from the hands of ordinary Australians the decision they most want to make and one that they should make themselves: that is, whether we, as Australians, have the right to aspire to the highest office in the land—whether we want to become a republic.

There is no denying that this proposal for a people's convention is not the Labor Party's preferred means of achieving the republic. We believe that the best way to do this is to put this decision straight into the hands of the Australian people through an indicative plebiscite and, ultimately, through a referendum. Realistically, however, a people's convention is the only immediately available option that we have, and those of us who unequivocally support the republic believe that we should try to make it work. That is why we give some support to this bill and that is why we give some support to a people's convention.

But our support is not unconditional. The government have sought, in this bill, to abuse the desire that the overwhelming majority of Australians hold: that Australia should become a republic. They have contrived a poisonous bill designed to undermine many of the fundamental democratic institutions and principles of fairness that we, and the overwhelming majority of Australians, believe in. To the government we say, `We won't be party to your despicable attempts to subvert the democratic principles upon which this nation is based.' Accordingly, we will be seeking to make changes to this bill—changes to make the convention democratic, fairer and more reflective of community opinion.

The government's response to date to our more than reasonable demands has been childish and petulant, to say the least. The government has threatened to ignore our amendments upon the return of this bill to the House. It has threatened to return the bill in its original form to the Senate in the belief that we will buckle as a result of our desire to see the convention proceed. I say to the government that it needs to reconsider its standover tactics. We will not accept an abridgment of the amendments that will be passed by the Senate to the bill. Why? It is not because we are stubborn or unreasonable, but because we believe that democracy in this nation is not, and must never be, a tradeable commodity. There are certain basic standards in our democracy that simply are not negotiable.

If the government ultimately choose to ignore the will of the Senate, if they refuse to accept our democratic amendments and refuse to proceed with the convention—or proceed with a fully appointed convention—then it is the government alone that will be to blame. They will have to explain to the Australian people why they have not kept their promise, why they do not want a fair, open and democratic discussion of whether Australia should become a republic. Let me reiterate: the Labor Party is not keen to take part in a process that is ultimately designed to destroy the very ideals that we strive for. If the decision that Australians make on whether to become a republic or not is to be adjudged as fair dinkum, then it is critical that the process to get us there also be fair dinkum.

That is where our concerns about this bill begin. You only have to look at recent political history to see why this bill is before us in its present form. What brought it here? It is no secret that in 1994 the then Leader of the Opposition, Alexander Downer, was in a pickle. The coalition was unable to resolve its internal squabbling over the republic. When this Prime Minister took over—this Prime Minister who is a renowned monarchist—when he inherited the leadership, the idea of a people's convention served him well as a means to neutralise the politically damaging issue of the republic, and what it had become within his own party. But he did not embrace the idea of a people's convention because he wanted to embrace the discussion on constitutional reform. Once again, it was a means of avoiding the destructive internal party infighting and the damaging political effect it had on both him personally and the coalition.

The whole concept of a people's convention has been poisoned since its inception. It has been contrived in fear and timidity, not in hope or vision. Rather than a means for considered deliberation of constitutional reform, it has always been a means for the coalition to avoid making a decision on this issue. When, earlier this year, the Prime Minister decided to push ahead with the convention to keep his election promise, it was, once again, not because he was prepared to consider change, but rather because he feared what would happen if he was seen to be resisting that change.

Unlike the founding fathers of a century ago who embraced the processes of change, and who led this nation to federation, this Prime Minister fears change and refuses to lead. This is a weak and sneaky bill and it reeks of the Prime Minister's fear of tackling the republican issue head on. Nowhere is this more evident than in the Prime Minister's second reading speech. In a speech where he could have outlined his vision for Australia's future, our destiny, our place in the world, what did he do? He did what he always does on the big issues; he equivocates and runs for cover.

Only in the first and the last paragraphs of his speech did he describe the nature of the choice to be put before the people's convention, and then only in a formal way. Yet he devoted some three paragraphs to discussing both his and the government's reluctance to change our constitutional framework. In the remaining 18 paragraphs—some 78 per cent of his speech—he described in mind‐numbing detail such amazing relevancies as whether the ballot papers would be bar coded, the size of the ballot paper and whether appeal processes under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 would apply. This is the extent of the leadership and vision of our Prime Minister. He cannot see further than the most convenient bar code. No‐one expected a Gettysburg Address—least of all from this Prime Minister—but the Australian people did expect, and did deserve, something better than this.

This lack of leadership, vision and courage manifests itself in just about every clause in this bill. The whole thing is designed to leave the government with a way out. How? Firstly, this bill is undemocratic. It is a dangerous experiment in voluntary voting and it does seek to disenfranchise millions of ordinary Australians by ensuring that as few of them as possible express their views on this import ant issue. Secondly, because the government has sought to defy convention, it has sought to rig the appointed delegates to the convention—especially the parliamentary delegates—to favour the coalition. In doing so, once again, it seeks to prevent consensus, the test that the Prime Minister himself has laid down for determining the convention's success. Finally, because the government has failed to set up a framework through which the convention can undertake its deliberations, once again we have failure on this issue.

We in the Labor Party could try to walk away from such a weak and sneaky bill, but we do not. The approach that we have taken is to seek to amend the bill to make it democratic, workable and fair. We want to give the Australian people every opportunity to send a loud and clear message to the Prime Minister—that is, if he is not going to lead on this issue, he should get out of their way. We will do this by moving amendments which empower ordinary Australians and make the process democratic. That will help them to express their opinions on the issue and it will make this process fair and democratic.

Unless this bill is changed, it can be fairly said that over seven million Australians probably will not vote and close to three million people will have difficulty voting. Most of these will have enormous difficulty receiving their voting package.

With respect to the government's contempt for the Australian people on this issue, the first indication is its embracing of a voluntary postal ballot to elect delegates to the convention. If a voluntary postal ballot is held, it will be the first time in a Commonwealth election, plebiscite or referendum that an issue will have been determined by this means. The government, in arguing to support this approach, argues the question of costs. The government, for instance, is currently arguing that a voluntary postal ballot will cost approximately $35½ million compared to $49 million for a compulsory attendance ballot. These figures are rubbery. These costings are based on false assumptions. Unfortunately, I do not have time to go through all the false assumptions, but there are some that are stark and unbelievable and they cannot be ignored.

BREAK.PARA: The government, for instance, is proposing to mail out to every elector information about the convention, providing details of the election, how to vote, details of each and every one of the candidates who have nominated and a couple of envelopes. This package will also include the most important document of all—the ballot paper. Although no-one is precisely sure how many candidates will run, in New South Wales, for instance, it has been estimated that there could be anywhere between 200 and 500 candidates. Not surprisingly, these envelopes will have to carry a considerable amount of information.

Naturally enough, you would expect that the government's costings would be based on sending out this information in a decent sized envelope. If you presume that, you would be wrong. The government proposes to send all this information out in one ordinary sized envelope. Even Aladdin's genie would have had trouble fitting into that.

More realistically though, the government would have to send out this information in a package that is more approximately the size of a tax pack. Were they to do this—I believe that if this bill is not amended, within 48 hours, they would make such a decision—such an extra cost would cost the government $8 million alone. So in one fell swoop the cost differential between a compulsory attendance ballot and a manifestly inferior voluntary postal ballot will fall far from the government's claimed $13½ million to $5½ million. There are some other cost cuts that I will go to later on.

Other than highlighting the government's duplicity over this issue, a more important principle is at stake. Unlike the government, we on this side of the parliament believe that the cost of democracy has never been an issue and should not be one now. Secondly, the government has also argued that Australians should not be compelled to vote at a ballot for a convention that is not binding. Yet the convention will be binding to the extent that its recommendations will form the model of the republic that will ultimately be put to the people at a referendum.

Furthermore, voluntary postal voting sits uncomfortably with the Prime Minister's commitment before the election. It is another breach of commitment. Before the election he made this commitment to consult all Australians at the beginning, the middle and the end of this process. How can we truly describe this as a people's convention unless all Australians participate in the process and unless all Australians have an equal capacity to so participate?

Under the Howard‐Minchin proposal for a voluntary postal ballot, not all Australians will. For instance, the Australian Electoral Commission has admitted that up to two million Australians change their address each year. Since this ballot will be held some 18 months from the last federal election—in fact, some two years from the last full habitation review—more than three million people may not receive a ballot paper simply because they have not notified the commission of their change of address.

Further, material about the ballot will only be available in writing and in English. This is likely to disenfranchise many of those Australians who are blind, the frail aged, the illiterate or those whose language skills are not of sufficiently high standard. Two and a half million Australians come from a non-English speaking background. Most of these people are currently assisted through their attendance at polling booths or the use of mobile polling booths.

Another issue was that of people overseas. Only after pressure from the Labor Party on this issue has the government allowed the ballot paper to be distributed to approximately 200,000 Australians who are likely to be overseas at the time of the ballot. That is going to cost another $1½ million or so and that is a considerable reduction on that differential of $5½ million. Together with extra savings that we believe can be made by staggering the counting of the ballot, the differential comes to some $2 million or $3 million, nowhere near the government's initial claim of some $18 million or so.

A voluntary vote is likely to be used by those within the government, such as Senator Minchin, to support their ultimate desire to see a voluntary voting system introduced at federal elections. We saw evidence of this just this week through the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in the 1996 election. Unfortunately for the government, some 72 per cent of Australians disagree with any such move.

Let us face it, the history of voluntary postal votes in this country—a system that has been used primarily for local council and trade union elections—is not good. Recent experience in Victoria and South Australia is testament to that. Although there are rare instances where voluntary postal ballots attract some 60 per cent or more return, the more usual figure is a 30 to 40 per cent turnout. Such a return here will be used by some to discredit any message sent by the electorate through its preference for pro-republican or pro-monarchist candidates.

If the opinion polls are right and some 60 per cent of Australians who do vote vote for pro-republican candidates, the monarchists will try to claim, as I predict they will, that only 36 per cent of the total Australian population supports a republic. On this basis, they will then try to argue that there is no clear consensus in favour of a republic. If a more likely 35 to 40 per cent turnout is achieved, they would say that only 24 per cent voted for the republic and, as a consequence, there is less support.
An example of this distorted behaviour has already been demonstrated by the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), a leading monarchist, who, in the most recent edition of the Adelaide Review, stated:

Even if republican candidates win two-thirds of the vote in the election for delegates . . . that still leaves the Convention `do you want a Republic' vote at about 88 to 64 which is hardly a `consensus' or even a particularly overwhelming majority for change.

So, even if there is 66 per cent support for a republic in the electorate, as reflected through this ballot, the government already is position ing itself to argue that that is insufficient for a consensus. That is from a government which, on the back of one vote, is willing to claim consensus in the Senate for major changes that affect the lives of citizens every day.

I must also say that, if you do want a bipartisan position here, the dynamic of a voluntary ballot is flawed. It encourages political opponents to spend time drumming up support amongst their own supporters rather than amongst the general community, particularly those yet to make up their minds. If the PM is serious about building a consensus among the Australian people, either for or against the republic, then it is the middle‐of‐the‐road swinging voter who must be convinced to vote one way or another.

So we do have problems with the voluntary voting proposal. Of course, we will move amendments to it. We also have immense problems with the secrecy aspects of the proposal. We contend very strongly—I think the evidence is there to support our contention—that, in a four‐week ballot where the ballot paper will be floating around for public and not so private access, there will be enormous pressure on the secrecy of the ballot.

We are not satisfied with the security proposals put forward by the government. The proposals depend on the date of birth as the major security measure in identifying the person who voted. Given the prevalence of availability of dates of birth to a whole range of people, including nursing home owners, flat owners and employers, we do not believe that the security measures are adequate.

We also have problems with the voting system. The government misleadingly says that they have adopted the Senate style voting system, though what they have put up is absolutely nothing like it. What is above the line is nothing like what is above the line in the Senate voting system, and what will be below the line is also nothing like what is normally below the line in the Senate system. The government's defence in respect of this, which I will go to in the committee stage of the bill, is one which I think is demeaning to the Australian democratic system. If you wanted to ensure that as many Australians as possible were confused or excluded from the system, then you could not have come up with a better proposal than the one that the government has come up with.

We are also concerned with the process of the appointment of delegates to the people's convention. Despite the fact that they will make up half the convention, and thus be highly influential in its deliberations, we have only the Prime Minister's word that appointments will occur in the manner which is described in the second reading speech.

I have to say at this late stage that, if the government was interested in bipartisanship, they would not have sent out letters to their appointments to the convention today and in a manner which was non‐consultative with the parliament. They knew there was a proposal coming up to ensure that the parliament had a bipartisan approach to the selection of those appointed delegates. They have seen our amendments for some time, but they chose to pre‐empt, in a very divisive way, the consideration of the Senate of those amendments.

As a consequence, today they notified a group of people that they will be the appointed delegates to the convention. We say to the government that our proposed amendment still has relevance, and we will pursue that, together with amendments, to provide a fair balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you had your way, we would not be debating this tonight; we would be debating it—

—If I had my way, every Australian would be able to front up at a plebiscite and express their democratic view as to whether Australia should become a republic. If you had your way, we would not be taking the first step that we are facing now. We would not be doing that at all. You should be more concerned about your preselection and ex‐Senator Crichton‐Browne than worrying about trying to subvert the democratic processes that are quite important to people when it comes to constitutional reform.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Constitutional Convention was announced at the start of this year, on behalf of the Democrats I welcomed it, acknowledging that the government was meeting a commitment it had made. But I do not welcome the way this government has chosen to implement that commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 is not about providing the mechanisms for a fair, reasonable and inclusive debate on Australia's future. Far from it, we say. This bill is essentially about two things. Firstly, it is about allowing the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), whom we know is openly opposed to the concept of a republic, by a combination of ownership of appointments and ownership of the formulae for representation, to engineer, to stage manage, to manipulate—in other words, to stack—the Constitutional Convention in favour of his desired outcome. Secondly, this bill is an illegitimate, Liberal Party driven, Nick Minchin inspired, ideological experiment in voluntary voting.

We are fortunate, I might say, that the debate on this bill has coincided so neatly with the tabling on Monday of the report of the inquiry by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters into the conduct of the 1996 federal election, because that report revealed very clearly the agenda of some in this government with respect to voluntary voting.

It is no secret that the Democrats, like others, would have preferred an indicative plebiscite to gauge the feeling of the Australian people on this issue prior to the expenditure of millions of dollars on what has the potential to become a celebrity talkfest. What is the point of holding a convention before the views of the Australian people on the fundamental question about whether we want to have an Australian head of state are ascertained?
