What we are faced with now is a potentially divisive, expensive and, most of all, overly complicated constitutional convention grudgingly offered by the Prime Minister in response to former Prime Minister Keating's republican timetable and framework announcements.

The Democrats could have lived with a constitutional convention. We could have tolerated it because it was clearly the only option available to us under this coalition government. They were honouring their commitment, and it seemed a reasonable compromise.

BREAK.PARA: But that was before the government began to politicise the whole event. That was before Senator Minchin and the Prime Minister started to inject their own political and electoral agenda into this important debate about Australia's future as a nation. I do question the motives behind the finer detail of this bill, and I do question Senator Minchin's assertions that the departures in this bill from normal electoral practice are only the result of budgetary restraint.

The government has provided in this bill for a non-compulsory postal ballot. This is a monumental departure from the time‐honoured Australian practice of compulsory attendance voting, and it is a departure to which we are strongly opposed. Is the Prime Minister trying to suggest that electing delegates at a constitutional convention, designed to discuss the very shape of our nation in the 21st century, is any less important or any less significant than an election to determine who will be your federal, local or state member of parliament? I think a lot of Australians would strongly disagree with the implication behind the Prime Minister's view of why we can have voluntary voting.

Aboriginal Australians, people from remote and rural areas, the elderly, the disabled, Australians of non‐English speaking backgrounds and Australians with learning disabilities should all be very worried about the precedent being set here. There are innumerable foreseeable and unforeseeable problems associated with the conduct of a postal ballot, and Senator Bolkus clearly articulated many of those.

We should pay attention to the fact that more than two million Australians change address each year. They will not receive a ballot paper if they have not informed the Electoral Commission of their change of address—and, as I recall it, they only get a week to do that in this process before the roles close—nor will the hundreds of thousands of Australians who happen to be travelling overseas at the time of the election. They would normally vote in an overseas polling booth. On this occasion, they will not have the opportunity.

A postal vote conducted in English only will effectively disenfranchise those from non-English speaking backgrounds. It will disenfranchise those with literacy problems, the blind and the aged because, at a normal election, these people would receive assistance at polling booths or mobile polling booths. This kind of assistance will not be available to that extent at this election, although the Electoral Commission have indicated they will provide assistance via an 013 free call line. But you have to know it exists to ring it, and you have to know how to read English to find out that this facility is available to you. I do acknowledge that the Electoral Commission have said they are going to advertise in 11 languages. I think that is welcome, but I do not think it overcomes the fundamental problem.

According to the government's calculations, a postal vote instead of a normal attendance vote would save—although it is a bit hard to estimate—around $18 million. If you look at that in the starkest terms, we would be paying less than a dollar for every Australian towards having the most democratic opportunity to debate probably one of the most important questions facing our country and its government—that is, its relationship with its citizens.

I have heard the government say that we are obsessed with compulsion. I say that this government is obsessed with implementing an electoral system which ensures that the Liberal Party advantages itself in future electoral contests and retains its status as the ruling party within the coalition.

Senator Minchin wants voluntary voting in all elections—federal and state. Compulsory voting, according to him, `has contributed to the depth of cynicism, apathy and ignorance in the political process'. Not only is it `a fundamental breach of the civil liberties of individuals in a liberal democracy', but it has `damaged the Australian political process' and `weakened the political parties'.

What rubbish. To suggest that government is not the concern of all citizens is an absolute furphy. To suggest that compulsory voting is the route of cynicism and apathy in the political process is just plain dishonest and manipulative. But bad workmen always blame their tools.

I was interested to hear the explanation offered by psephologist Malcolm Mackerras on ABC radio in Canberra this morning. He suggested that the Liberal Party, after 13 years in opposition, has developed a great big chip on its shoulder and wants to change the system to benefit itself but is not willing to be honest about it.

It is a pity that the idea of a peoples convention has been hijacked by Senator Minchin's particular obsession with voluntary voting. I am sure if you asked Petro Georgiou, if you asked Senator Alan Eggleston—although we know what his views are—if you asked the Liberal Party federal executive, if you asked a range of Liberal Party state directors and if you asked the National Party, some of them would tell you they think it is a great pity too and they are opposed to what is happening with it.

There is some support for Senator Minchin from others but it is purely political self‐interest. They rely on research that shows that the Liberal vote would increase if voter turnout decreased. According to a news poll in February 1996, if voting were made voluntary at least 19 per cent of Labor voters but only 14 per cent of coalition voters would be likely not to vote at all. Malcolm Mackerras said this morning that surveys such as this one translate into a two per cent swing to the right. How convenient.

Research does not demonstrate, however, that a decline in voter participation would advantage the National Party and I am sure they are paying close attention to this debate. In fact, the abolition of compulsory voting in any election is against National Party policy. I suspect that National Party candidates were prominent among the 24 per cent of coalition candidates who indicated strong support for compulsory voting in the 1996 candidate survey.

There are very strong arguments for retaining compulsory voting in this election and in all elections in Australia. It has been the norm. It is not that you do not want change but there are sometimes very good reasons for preserving things that work well and reflect history. To a great extent, compulsory voting says something about the Australian character. We like having to be focused and forced to go along and make a choice. We are not asked to do it very often. It has been the norm since 1924, having been introduced to combat voter turnout as low as 58 per cent in the 1922 election. The rationale for its introduction was expressed by the independent senator who moved the Commonwealth Electoral Bill as follows:

Claiming to be a democratic community we naturally expect the people of Australia to be sufficiently interested in the constitution of the national parliament to see that it is thoroughly representative of political thought in electoral divisions. Parliament is supposed to be a reflex of the mind of the people. If people exhibit no interest in the selection of their representatives, it must necessarily follow, in the course of time that there must be a considerable deterioration in the nature of the laws governing the social and economic development in the country.

I think that statement still holds true. Compulsory voting is accepted by Australians as a national tradition. Australians accept that it is their duty to vote and in the main they do so on a Saturday, usually at their local primary or high school, more often than not in a spirit of willing participation and community spirit.

Voting provides most of these people with a sense that, on this occasion, what they are doing matters. Their vote counts. A man said to me recently, in response to all these arguments about mainstream Australia:
Do you know who mainstream Australia is? They are the people who have no power, no say in what goes on in their country, no form of redress if they are unhappy, except for their vote at the polls.

I think compulsory voting ensures the expression of choice of all those who are eligible to vote, not just those who choose to vote. A compulsory vote will ensure that, as far as is possible, the delegates are elected according to the wishes of all citizens. I think compulsory voting assists in legitimising the entire electoral process and it gives authority and ownership to the outcome. I note from recent AAP reports that even Fiji's Prime Minister is now committing to the introduction of compulsory voting in his plans for constitutional reform.

The Democrats say: `Yes, let's have a convention if that is how you honour your commitment, but let's make it a proper peoples convention by ensuring that all Australians are given the opportunity and encouragement to participate.' Conducting a voluntary postal ballot with a ballot paper requiring a PhD to decipher it does not encourage people to vote; in our view it turns them away. We have spent millions of dollars since 1984 educating Australians on how to cast a formal vote in a normal Senate election. We have done reasonably well in that quest. Why overturn that now? Why introduce, overnight, a confusing competing process?

This is a very important debate. This is about the future of Australia and all Australians should be encouraged to participate, if not directly by putting themselves forward for election or appointment, then by being present and attending a polling booth on the day.

This convention represents, according to Michelle Grattan of the Australian Financial Review `a return to politics on the cheap'. I will defer to her vast experience on the matter of a `return' to politics on the cheap, but certainly if cost is the government's rationale for holding a voluntary postal ballot instead of the compulsory attendance ballot, as is the norm, then this is indeed politics on the cheap. But I do not think it is cost; I think it is a much more sinister longer term agenda.

I would like to turn to the issue of equality of representation of women in the parliament and to women in positions of power generally and say that we believe women should be given encouragement to actively participate in this debate; that is, in the convention. The Prime Minister has promised to ensure a proper balance between men and women at the convention and Senator Minchin has indicated his own preference for a 50‐50 representation. We welcome this and urge the government to abide by its promise. Will this be reflected, for example, in the fact that 50 per cent of the government's appointed delegates will be women?

We think we need to go further and to legislate to ensure that women candidates are given proper exposure and that there are an equal number of them there to be chosen. There were no women at the Australasian federal conventions in the late 19th century. Women's representation in parliaments across Australia is still an average of 20 per cent. Twenty per cent to represent 52 per cent of the population is just not acceptable.

The Democrats do not support quotas, and we would not support the implementation of quotas in this situation, but we do believe that to require those setting up group voting tickets in the election to have half their candidates as women is one way to address gender inequity, and we will be moving an amendment to that effect.

As this is essentially a single‐issue poll where candidates are, for the most part, either for or against the question, we think candidates for election, as well as appointees, should be required to indicate where they stand on the issue. We will be moving an amendment to ensure that candidates are required to declare this at the time of nomination. Even if they want to say, `Well, I am on the fence on this one,' we think voters choosing them should have the right to know this.

We also urge the Prime Minister to require appointees to publicly declare their point of view prior to the close of nominations for the election. I think this is a protection against deliberate stacking of the processes by those who would be trying to hide their particular position from the general public. The Democrats are avid republicans. We do not believe Australia as a democratic and modern nation should have as its head of state a person who lives in another country and whose legal and constitutional position in relation to us is inherited. In our view, those who advocate the status quo support a technical subservience to a group of people who are not elected and who did not earn their place through endeavour or merit.

We view this debate as the ideal opportunity for the people of Australia to explore the important question of what sort of nation we want to become in the next century. This will be our second century as a federation. Do we want to retain a legal attachment, even if only symbolic, to the British Crown, when the sentimental attachment has long since faded? I do not think we do, but then I do not believe Australia should move into the next stage of our history under a cloud of illegitimacy because the Constitutional Convention issued its verdict amidst allegations of stacking and experimentation.

We understand the Prime Minister's concern to ensure a proper balance in representation, so that indigenous people, women, migrants, youth and people from rural and remote areas are properly represented. But, rather than the Prime Minister appointing the 36 non‐parliamentary delegates, we think he should have allowed for the federal parliament to make the appointments via the committee process or through some other mechanism. That again would protect the convention from allegations of stacking. I do not think the spoils of victory extend to the right to make the appointments on every single statutory authority or convention or public body in existence.

We also agree that state and federal parliamentarians should have an input, but we question the formula used by the Prime Minister to decide on the number of delegates to be chosen by each federal party and from each state. Under the Prime Minister's formula, the coalition will have 25 parliamentary representatives at the convention and the ALP will have only 13. An Australian republic will persist beyond the current political arrangement of a coalition majority, and a Prime Minister with foresight and a sense of fair play would have acknowledged that. We question the formula used by the government to determine the number of delegates to be elected from each state and territory.

In conclusion, I express my regret that the government has chosen to use this debate as a political device. Ideally, a move to a republic would have been a unifying experience, not a cause for finger pointing or experimentation in voting techniques. If the government spit the dummy and say that it is voluntary voting or no convention, then we are entitled to ask: how committed were they really? In fact, they might be secretly very relieved if the convention does not go ahead, because then they will not have to proceed with the next step of giving Australians a say in an indicative plebiscite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In preparation for tonight's debate, I read through the second reading speech for this bill, the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997. It is not called the republican convention; it is called the Constitutional Convention. I notice that the government representatives often call it the republican convention, but it is actually called the Constitutional Convention, which would, I imagine, generally make people believe that what is going to be discussed is the constitution. This is wrong, but that is their opinion. The second reading speech says:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular,
‐ whether or not Australia should become a republic;
‐ which republic model should be put to the electorate to consider against the status quo; and
‐ in what time frame and under what circumstances might any change be considered.
You think, `That's reasonable' but later, on page 2, it says:
The Coalition had previously contemplated referring other constitutional issues to the convention—
Gee, we are lucky they did not—
but has decided that on balance, this convention should deal only with the question of a change to a republican form of government.
That is of course a complex subject—

The government is conscious of the advocacy of other proposed constitutional changes within the community, and will consider ways in which the government can facilitate sensible consideration of the more significant of these proposals.

I see a very strong thought control in this process. Once the government gets together a group of people who have been selected and elected, what means will it use then to try to control their thoughts? We have seen a lot of thought control lately. We have seen community bodies who have worked their rear ends off to do service to the community, to provide information where governments often do not provide information, to be able to provide things which can be of great use to the community and which also often save money—save money in crisis care, in crisis management, in all sorts of things. We have seen groups like that in recent times have their funds cut or threatened to be cut for the terrible crime of speaking out.

With all of the control mechanisms that are available within this bill and within the selection process, if you get that many people together and, lo and behold, either the government or certain members of the government are not able to control the thought process of that many people in one group at one time, what means are they going to use to try to control the outcome considering it says in particular `which republic model' and `in what time frame'? What if, for instance, the government actually allows them to meet—another way of trying to control not only their thoughts but the thoughts of the Senate—for 10 days in December this year and they decide they cannot develop their own model of what other people should think or decide on and they need to go out to the community, they need to ask the government to fund a process of going out to the community to discuss what other people want, what the community in general would like to see develop into Australia's constitution in the next century?

What will the government do to try to control that outcome? After all that, will they then say, `That's not what we really wanted.' Will they then accept that decision? Will they accept that some people might still be able to think for themselves despite the efforts to control the outcome? I just wonder. I note at the end of the first page of the second reading speech it says:
Balanced and easily understood information on the issues will be prepared and distributed widely before the election of delegates.
I also note there is a very limited amount of time that the actual delegates will be able to give out their own information. It continues:
That material will explain, in plain English,—
let us pretend that no other languages are spoken in Australia—
how the existing constitutional system operates. It will identify the arguments for and against change.

Can the candidates not speak for themselves? The government also wants to control this process of what people believe they are going to be deciding upon so it will approach the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy and the Australian Republican Movement.

So already we have decided that we are dealing with a minimalist option: do we have an Australian head of state or not? I think Senator Brown's idea of having an indicative plebiscite before the election is a good idea. That means that we can already do that simple stage of saying, `In general, do you think that Australia should have an Australian as a head of state?' We can get that issue out of the way. It does not bind anybody, but it gives everybody an idea of whether or not they are working in the right direction or not, and then you can get onto the really interesting things. That is, if Australians in the majority do believe that we should have an Australian as a head of state, what kind of country do we want to live in in the next century?

What are we going to do? Do you think it is going to be right to simply change the head of state and assume that people are going to be happy with a constitution that was put together with all the best of intentions over 100 years ago? Are there not a number of people in our community who know that there are issues about the roles of states, the roles of local governments, the roles of federal government, the roles of courts, whether or not we have freedom of speech, whether or not there should be a bill of rights and, instead of handballing environmental destruction from one government to another, whether or not we have ecological sustainability as a right of citizenship? If you ask young people, that seems to be on the top of their agenda.

Do we forget about those concerns? Do we go into something that could be exciting, creative and inclusive or do we try to stifle debate and perhaps punish those people who lobby? If there are any funds going to any groups who may have an opinion on this, perhaps they will get a little letter saying, `If you don't be quiet, we're going to cut your funds too.' Is this what we are going to get by way of a debate? Is this what we are getting at the moment? Is this what should be ringing bells in our heads that perhaps we should have other rights built into our constitution because we can see quite clearly that some of those rights are being threatened as we speak?

If we have a situation where the majority of the Senate supports the views of many people in the community that the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill, not the Republican Convention (Election) Bill, ought to be changed and altered, as we have the right and the responsibility to do for any bill that we are dealing with, what do we do if the government picks up its toys and goes home? What kind of representation is this if the government says, `No, we understand we ought to be looking as if we're doing something but, if you change it in any way to actually do something to make this more inclusive, we're not going to do it.' How long can any government stand out?

What would happen to Australia if the United Kingdom moved to change its head of state and Australia was left with a constitutional monarchy—that is, a constitutional monarchy without a monarch. We have to start thinking about this issue. We have to be grown-up about it. We cannot say, `There is no law, there is no constitutional ability, for this government to say, "You may not change this bill because it is about the Constitutional Convention."' No announcement was ever made to say that there was one section of laws which cannot be altered by the Senate—that is, anything to do with constitutional debates or debates in relation to a republic.

There will be a backlash if there is an attempt to try to gag the community's concerns and gag the legitimate role of the Senate in trying to bring the community concerns to the parliament. If the majority of the Senate votes for changes to this bill to make it more inclusive, what kind of basis would any government use to say, `This form of bill cannot be amended and should not be amended. So there'?

There are a number of people—and I would have to include myself very strongly amongst those—who believe that we are at a very exciting point in history. That exciting point is the opportunity to look back over the last 100 years. We can look at the things that have gone right, the things that we have learnt, and we can see what we want as a nation for at least the next century. We want to see the values in Australia, but at the same time we can see that values in general are being ridden roughshod over by some totally undemocratic force in relation to international corporations via the World Trade Organisation.

We have never been under so much threat. The sovereignty of Australia and many other nations has never been under so much threat. In my opinion, there has never been a period of greater need to think about what we as a country deserve to have as constitutional rights. There has never been a greater need to make sure that whatever process we take to go towards that goal is as inclusive as possible. It is totally wrong for me as a politician to consider that my view is any more important than anybody else's. I have the opportunity to speak in parliament but other people do not. They could try to speak through their politicians but often do not.

I want to know, therefore, how we got to a situation where the government decided that there were going to be nominated candidates, they set closing dates for nominations but, ironically, the nominations were never opened. Who saw the ads in the paper asking the general public to think about who they thought would be good to be their nominees? Who saw that ad? Guess what, there wasn't one—not that I know of.

So there was a closing date for nominations but they were not ever opened. Who was able to make those nominations? Who knows? Where were the guidelines? Who knows? There weren't any. I did not see any. I asked for them and I was told that there weren't any. This is a private club with no written guidelines. But, obviously, some people must have known the rules. So we will have to wait with bated breath to see who is part of that private club.

I have mentioned before that there might be a spread of groups represented, but we have no indication whatsoever of how that might occur. Parliamentarians know—and there are quite a few that might be a part of this process—that the government says it does not wish to be prescriptive. So there is a fairly large chunk of this selected group for which there is no process to make sure that half the population—by way of women—is represented. How can you make sure that in this process there is a fair representation of non-English speaking people who have taken Australia as their home or of Aboriginal people for whom this is an extremely important debate or of young people?

How do we know that we will not get a group like the Prime Minister's daughter and his daughter's friends and those people who all have a particular upbringing, a particular viewpoint of what they want in life and a particular outlook? How do we know that we will not get a group of conservative young people or a group of monarchists amongst Aboriginal representatives? How do we know that amongst the selected group we will get any range of opinions represented at all? The answer is that we do not know because the process is not open, it is not free. The only indication I have had that there will be anything other than autocratic decision making is that the names will be run by the Leader of the Opposition. We do not know who is on the short list. We do not know if there is a short list. We do not know if there is a long list. We do not know how many people and what kind of process people went through to put those names forward.

I think this is a pretty good indication that things are going to be difficult and very much controlled. We also know that amongst our elected representatives, as Senator Kernot indicated, we have about one in five who are women—and that has gone up in recent times. Female representation in the Australian parliament has been one of the worst representations of the western world. If you were to take that alone, how would you then make up the difference amongst the other selected candidates? What would the government be doing? The answer is that we do not know what will be happening. Perhaps they will just say, `We will take the representation as it is in parliament.' What does that mean for that half of the population who feel that they are not being fully represented by those people who are attending the Constitutional Convention?

BREAK.PARA: As always, I would like to see that such a Constitutional Convention may just have the hope of bringing something positive, may just have the hope of not being totally controlled in its outcomes. I very much doubt it, but I would like to think that there are enough people in the community who are concerned about the outcomes to make sure that good, representative people from a wide range of opinions are elected to the Constitutional Convention. I would like to hope—and it might be a faint hope—that some people who have a mind of their own and who are not going to be cowed by those people who want the debate to be as quiet as possible, as limited as possible and with no threat to the current constitutional monarchy, will escape into the system amongst the selected delegates.

I would like to think that the range of opinions that exist amongst the coalition will be represented. I think it is a pity that there is such a great parliamentary contingent of this delegation. It is also a pity that the chair and the vice chair have automatically been selected from politicians. So there is already an assumption that what we will have is a political agenda. It is such a pity to think that we cannot have a situation where the delegates from that Constitutional Convention could elect their own chair. It does not bode well for their ability to make other decisions without direction.

How much direction will be given by the government during this process? What notice will be taken if, by sheer accident, the Constitutional Convention ends up being represented by people with a range of opinions who can speak for themselves, who actually want to see changes to our system, who believe that just changing the head of state without looking at the other things that go with it does not mean a lot if people really believe it is important that Australia becomes a republic?

Perhaps it is a good thing to think about the indicative plebiscite and get that through—and do it, as has been suggested, by compulsory voting, because we all know very well that those who have a lot of money benefit from non-compulsory voting. If you have to get people to go out of their houses to vote in an Australian election—or even to go to the effort of putting in an envelope to vote—the ability to have access to paid media, to advertisements and so on, is obviously very important. We also know that the reality is that even now there is limited ownership of the Australian press and that a total range of opinions is not always possible within our media. So it is important that we see that there is compulsory voting, to make sure that everybody participates in a very important decision. Otherwise the government is saying, `This is not as important as other decisions.'

If we are going to have compulsory voting—which I very much hope we are—we should have the indicative plebiscite and then get on to the important issues: how we go about this and what kind of republican model we choose. I would like to read that as broadly as possible. And perhaps, instead of having a group—however good—of Constitutional Convention delegates deciding what the rest of Australia should decide, we should make sure that enough people contact those delegates and say, `We want a say too.' Let us take it back to the community, before you ask us further about anything that binds Australia in relation to the republican debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise here tonight to speak to the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997. I would be more pleased were I speaking to a bill to establish a people's convention. We are not doing that. I would be even more pleased—even overjoyed—were I speaking to a bill to establish a referendum that would look at the question of whether or not Australia might become a republic in the near future. But we are not doing that either. We are playing a part in a slimy act by our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to break his word, to get out of an election commitment which he made very publicly before the election last year—when he was in some difficulty within his own party—to establish a people's convention. What have we got? Anything but a people's convention.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place, let me declare an interest—as I did during the deliberations of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. I am a founding member of the Australian republican movement. I have a long held belief that Australia should become a republic. In 1981, within my party in Western Australia—and I made mention of this in my first speech in this place—I was instrumental in moving a motion at a special state conference that later became our policy at a special national conference of my party. TALK.START.PARA: —He's in a plane.
—He is winging his way to the cricket.
—And why not?

—He is winging his way to the test match at Lords. He is probably one of the very few Australians who will be able to see the opening session of the test match at Lords, because Australian television does not show it. —Baroness Thatcher is the next one on the list. After that, what does he do? He goes and sees the Queen. It is interesting to note, Senator Calvert, that when he meets the Queen, he will not be meeting the Queen of Australia. You know that as well as I, the people of Australia and Mr Howard know that.

BREAK.PARA: I am not comfortable about the fact that Mr Howard will meet our head of state when that head of state does not hold the title `Queen of Australia'. She only takes that title when she is in this country so, when the Prime Minister of Australia meets the Queen of England, Queen Elizabeth II, he will not be meeting her as the monarch of Australia. That is something that has to be changed. But it is not something that will be changed—or possibly even advanced—by the legislation contained in the bill before the Senate tonight.

On this side of the parliament—with the support of some others, hopefully—we will endeavour to rectify that situation through amendments. I have to be honest: I hope that we are successful in that, and that the government does what I am told it did earlier today—I was not in the chamber at the time—when the minister in charge of the business being considered at the time spat the dummy and withdrew some legislation. I hope the same thing happens on this occasion; I hope this proposed Constitutional Convention will die a death in this place—or very soon after it leaves this place. I hope we can do that, because, if it happens—as a result of the efforts of ourselves and other people in this place—we will be doing the people of Australia a great service. We will be saving them an enormous amount of money on a shoddy, bizarre proposed election.

Why is the proposed election bizarre? My colleague Senator Bolkus, in his excellent contribution here earlier this evening, went to great lengths to explain why it is bizarre. Senator Kernot and Senator Margetts, who followed him, added to his explanations of why it is bizarre. Very briefly, we are only proposing to elect half the convention. We are not going to elect the whole convention and, even with the delegates who will be elected, we are not doing it fairly throughout Australia.

Nobody has made any bones about the fact that we are doing it. Normally, when you make statements like this about government legislation, you get interjections. The place is silent other than my speaking. I appreciate people holding to the conduct of the place and abiding by standing orders, but it is not fair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will tell you what I think of your arguments.
—One can understand why Senator Calvert is quiet on this fact—because Senator Calvert comes from a state which will be proportionately over-represented at the convention.
—We will have equal rights as the states.

—You will not have equal rights at all. You will have more rights from Tasmania than the people of New South Wales will have. You will have more delegates proportionately to the convention if it goes ahead. If the ballot goes ahead, you will have more delegates from Tasmania, per head of population, than there will be from New South Wales or indeed from Queensland.
—So what!

—Senator Calvert says `So what!'. Democracy does not mean a damn to the people on the opposite side. They have to follow through with Mr Howard's phoney bill, Mr Howard's fraud of a convention. It is not anywhere near the promise that he made before the election. It is probably useful that the Prime Minister is on his way to the cricket, on his way to Wimbledon, on his way to meet with Baroness Thatcher, and on his way to meet with the Queen.
—On his way to where Keating went before he became Prime Minister. He flew over—what did he call us?—the hell hole of the world.

—You got that quote wrong again, Senator, but then you are used to getting things wrong, aren't you? You probably will have to get up in the very near future and apologise on that one too. You are getting very used to doing that. Hopefully, you have got the dummy back in and you are not going to spit it here any more.

BREAK.PARA: We are not going to walk away from the challenge that is presented to us as a political party. Our cards on this matter are very clearly on the table. Going back to Mr Keating's statement in the 1993 election, and followed through in our policy documents since then, we have not hidden from the fact that we are in favour—when the people want it—of having a republic in this country. We do not know where we are going to go, and when we do get the option of doing that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, point of order. I just thought I might assist Senator McKiernan. He is quite right. I asked, `Was it the hell hole of the world he called us?'. He is right. It was a question, of course, and the answer is: no, it was the farce end of the world, or something—without the `f' at the beginning. That is what he referred to Australia as, and he consistently went to Europe and London. He only went to Asia when he became Prime Minister. He had no real interest in Asia whatsoever. I thought that would assist the debate so that I could allow Senator McKiernan to go on without calling a quorum on him.

—Senator Vanstone, you know as well as I do that that was not a point of order. In no way was it a point of order, and you did not even claim it was. It does not assist debate in this place. (Quorum formed)

—I am very pleased to see that so many of the senators from the government side of parliament have come in to witness this contribution that I am making here this evening. I am pleased that there are some government representatives in the country who are not winging their way over to see the Queen.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party's position on this bill is very clearly on the record, particularly so from the contribution made by my colleague, Senator Bolkus, here this evening, but also as Senator Bolkus and I participated in the deliberations of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. I commend the report from that committee to those that are interested in this particular debate. I particularly commend the minority report of the Labor Party senators and, indeed, the minority report from the Democrat senator, Senator Murray. The concerns are widespread about this piece of legislation. They trawl the whole area of community concerns about what the government proposes in this bill, not the least of which is the impact and effect of what a postal ballot would do.

The committee heard evidence that the bill discriminates against those who have no literacy skills. This claim was not refuted by the government. There were claims that it discriminates against many Australians, particularly students, who will be at different addresses. We heard evidence during the deliberations of the committee that up to two million Australians change address from one year to the next. So there will be a difficulty—and the Electoral Commission admits this—in catching up with those people.

It will be particularly disadvantageous for Aboriginal communities. Also—and I expressed this during the hearings—I have great concerns about the security that will surround the voting procedure for Aboriginal communities, particularly those in remote areas. It will discriminate against and disadvantage those Australians who will be travelling overseas. It will disadvantage non‐English speaking people, and millions of them have, as heads of their household, people who do not have a command of the English language as good as we would probably like them to have. Also, it would generally discriminate against those who are less powerful in our society. Maybe it is the wish of the government to do that. Maybe that is what they are about.

I mentioned in passing my concerns about the security of the ballot in remote Aboriginal communities, but even greater concerns were expressed to the committee; concerns which we were not able to get adequate clarification on from the Electoral Commission officials or indeed from the parliamentary secretary who also appeared before the committee. An immense scope for fraud exists through the use of the postal ballot.

There will be some security provisions built into it, but those security provisions, including the bar coding, are themselves not perfect by any stretch of the imagination, as indeed we know. Our own very good system of voting which is in place now for elections is not 100 per cent perfect and errors, manipulation and electoral fraud have taken place in the past. But the scope for it to happen in this particular ballot is just immense. It is mind‐boggling that we in this chamber could be proceeding with this proposal here tonight.

The ACTU had their concerns and they are experienced in the area of postal ballots. They drew the committee's attention to the more vulnerable sections of our community, the elderly who live in nursing homes. There are many good nursing homes, we know, but there are also some nursing homes which are not so good. It must be remembered that management in the not so good nursing homes, as well as management in the good ones, would have access to the birthday details of residents in the home. Another security provision that is supposed to protect the elector after casting their vote is for them, if they are able, to put their date of birth on the back of the envelope, which can be then checked by the Electoral Commission when they receive the envelope. There will be some people who are disadvantaged, who have sight problems, who will not be able to do that. There are also others in our community who, unlike me of Irish origin—I write my date of birth with the day, the month and then the year—write their birth date in reverse and there are others who do it in a different way again. That will cause a huge difficulty for those checking the security of the ballot.

The ballot for the supposed people's convention does not address those 76 individuals who will be appointed to it. Senator Margetts drew attention to the fact that there may have been adverts calling for nominations to be appointed to those positions but only 36 of those 76 are going to be nominated from the community. The other 40 are going to be politicians. In the break‐up of those 40, are there going to be equal numbers between the government and the opposition throughout Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a chance.
—Certainly not a chance. Is it going to be anywhere near equal numbers?
—Do you hold equal numbers in parliaments? Just a small fact.

—You will get your opportunity, Minister. You can make your contribution and I will come in and listen to it. (Quorum formed) There are a couple of things that I want to conclude with. Attention was drawn by a number of people to what might be the ballot paper. The committee heard evidence that there could be up to 200 delegates from New South Wales. During the committee hearings, we directed questions to the Australian electoral office. We asked if they could help us in our deliberations in understanding the size of a ballot paper that would contain 200 names. We were provided with a draft ballot paper which, unfortunately for tonight's illustration, contains only 140 names. Were it to contain 200 names, obviously things would be more cramped. If things were more cramped, the names of the individual candidates would be less readable. For somebody like me, who needs glasses, it is going to be impossible for some members of the community even to read the names that are on here. That is what we are going to be faced with.

BREAK.PARA: To fit in with the financial situation, this ballot paper—it probably will be this size in New South Wales and possibly in Victoria or the other larger states where there will be a big number of candidates—will have to be folded three times to fit into an envelope. That envelope will have to be big enough to hold two other envelopes and instructions on how to vote and not exceed the weight and size limits imposed by Australia Post in order for the ballot paper to be posted for 35c or so per item, if it goes overland, and it quite likely will. It is quite likely that it could cost in the region of 70c per item. The government's argument about saving money by running a postal vote instead of a full presence vote that would occur in the course of a normal election is blown out of the water. It may very well be blown out of the water when the nominations for the convention, if the convention is ever held, come to the fore.

The final thing is that, even in the conservative south of my home state, my electorate of Western Australia, the people are not happy with this proposal. They have written to me, certainly the Central South Regional Council of Western Australia have written to me, with great concerns that the proposal in the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill that the people of Australia will vote upon is not wide enough. Their concerns are manyfold. They name five things, but they go on and talk about another seven things. I did not give Mr Hassell, the secretary of the organisation, any hope that I would be able to change the bill before the Senate in order to accommodate his interest, but I did say that I would try to represent his interest in this place. I have shown a copy of this letter to the whip on the other side and I have asked permission for the letter to be incorporated into the speech that I am making this evening to the Senate. I seek leave for that letter to be incorporated.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—
CENTRAL SOUTH REGIONAL COUNCIL OF W.A.
Representing Industry, Civic and Government interests in the Central South.
Established February 1947
Secretary: Mr A.W.B. Hassell, B.Ec, R.M.B. 359 Pingelly, WA 6308
President: Mr I Brandenberg, PO, Lake King, WA 6538
7th May, 1997
Senator Jim McKiernan
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator
Constitution Convention Canberra December 1997

This organisation is both alarmed and disappointed by the announcement from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister Senator Nick Minchin with the provisions of legislation introduced into the House of Representatives on March 26th this year concerning election to the Constitutional Convention.
We believe the proposals are severely flawed.
Firstly

Mr Howard in his election manifesto announced that any issue relating to the Constitution would be allowed to be discussed. The legislation will allow only the issue of changing to republic or otherwise.
Secondly

Parliamentary representation of forty is to be divided equally between the Commonwealth and the States with the Central Government having representation equal to the sum of representation of all the states. We believe that the Commonwealth as one Government amongst nine should have representation equal to each of the others (not the sum).
Thirdly

The announcement states that the elected representation of the States would be on a similar basis to representation in the House of Representatives. We believe the representation should be equal between states.
Fourthly

The announcement stated that there would be a non refundable nomination fee of $500.00 for those who nominated for election to the convention. As such a fee would not apply to appointed delegates nor to parliamentary delegates. We believe that this provision is unjust, unfair and discriminatory.
Fifthly

Nominations for election to the Constitutional Convention closed on May 2nd without any visible prior notice. The only way that this writer knew about them closing was because Malcolm Turnbull was on television complaining on the evening of May 1st because the nominations were closing the next day.
This organisation believes that the Constitution should be amended to
1. Have justices of the High Court appointed by State Governments in rotation with only the Chief Justice appointed by the Commonwealth.

2. Any two State Governments by an absolute majority in each of them of the members of the State parliament (whether bi‐cameral or uni‐cameral) should be able to require the Commonwealth to conduct a referendum for a change to the Constitution.
3. The Commonwealth Government Executive should be required to have all external treaties (including all those already in existence) ratified by the parliament of the Commonwealth.
4. The Commonwealth to be expressly precluded from using its `External Treaties' powers to overrule State Authority.
5. Return income taxing powers to the State or exclusive power to tax goods and services including fuels be the preserve of the States.
6. Ensure that the Commonwealth does not infringe state rights in regard to land administration.
7. Ensure that all changes to the constitution invoked by the High Court in the past be declared null and void.

This organisation requests that you ensure that the legislation is amended in the Senate to accommodate all our objections. We believe that you, as a Member of the Senate, the upper house of Parliament which was designed to protect the rights of the States in the Federation have a responsibility to ensure that the forthcoming Constitutional Convention has the opportunity to change our Constitution to preserve the federal structure which is under threat in the current trend.
We would greatly appreciate your advice as to what action you propose in response to our request.
Yours faithfully
AWB Hassell
Secretary

Incorporating the shires of Boddington, Brookton, Corrigin, Cuballing, Dumbleyung, Kondinin, Kulin, Lake Grace, Narrogin, Pingelly, Wagin, Wandering, West Arthur, Wickepin, Williams and the Narrogin Town Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and Senator McKiernan for your assistance in my being able to speak now. It is my turn for chair duty, and I appreciate the assistance of my colleagues. I am very pleased to speak in the debate on the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997. I think it could probably be better called the `breaking convention bill'. I also am pleased to speak in this debate as a South Australian senator, a representative from a state that, in 1894, was the first place to see women win the right to vote. Anybody who has had a passing interest in or knowledge of the campaign run to achieve that success in South Australia over 100 years ago will know how vitally important being able to participate in the parliament and the elections of the day was to women then and in large part is to women today.

SPEECH.PARA: The women back then had such a long and tough campaign. Many times that proposed amendment was brought into the parliament and thousands of signatures were gathered by industrious women working around the colony of South Australia. It was a matter of great rejoicing to read the descriptions from the women themselves of how they had to walk home from North Terrace to Prospect very late at night, but it did not matter because they walked with lighter feet because they had won that right to vote, to participate, to have their say. What women wanted was an opportunity to have a say. They had to win that right against very many people who argued, and indeed still argue, that women are not really fit for public office and are not really able to have a proper say or give proper consideration to or deliberate on issues, particularly the so-called larger issues of the day.

In South Australia, women were very clear that they did want to have a say, and they have shown over the many years since that they are more than able to represent their views and the views of many constituents who often feel better represented by women because they themselves are women or that women have a different sympathy for the issues. Anyhow, if we are in a democracy and want broad representation, clearly we would want as wide a representation as we can. I am delighted that South Australia is the state that started the run for women to have an opportunity to vote in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you're not alone.

—I will allow that interjection, Senator Vanstone, that I am not alone; because it will allow me to distinguish between you and your good colleague Senator Minchin—also from the same state. I will come back to that in a moment. It is interesting just in passing to note that Aboriginal women in South Australia also were able to vote after that ballot in 1894 when the legislation was passed into law in 1895. Aboriginal women did have the opportunity to vote and did exercise their vote. They subsequently lost that opportunity in the federal bill of 1902. The history on this matter is full of pertinence and nice ironies about the debate and the concerns confronting us tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Not too long ago, in late May—a mere three weeks ago—I held a function in this place which I called `Women and the People's Convention'. I invited to speak at that convention Helen Irving, Deborah Cass, Hilary Charlesworth and Sue Dunlevy representing the media, for their important contribution to issues of public debate like this one. What we were campaigning for was 50 per cent representation of women amongst the delegates both appointed and elected at this coming convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you will congratulate us if they are 50 per cent.

—I note that the paper today—and you often tell me never to believe what I read in the paper—says that Senator Minchin is minded to accept 50 per cent women to the convention. I am not clear whether Senator Minchin will actually accept 50 per cent of appointed and elected delegates. He has designed this legislation to designate a percentage representation of Aboriginal people and young people but, to this point, there is still no designated representation for women. `An appropriate percentage or representation' is what I believe the wording of that bill to say. I note that Senator Minchin—at least as reported in the paper which you, Senator Vanstone, tell me not to believe—now says that he is minded to accept 50 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted if we can get a 50 per cent representation of women. That is fair. For the record it should be noted that women are conceding a percentage or two of representation in this country, but we are not unreasonable. I am one who would argue that fair is fair: 50 per cent is a very good way to go in terms of representation.

I do not know what has changed Senator Minchin's mind. I mentioned him before because he also is from South Australia and until now—and even in large part in the design of this bill—I have had the view that Senator Minchin would have opposed the right for women to vote in 1894. He is very grudging about the benefits of moving towards a republic in this country. He is certainly not of the same South Australian ilk as his Liberal colleague Steele Hall, who went a long way towards electoral justice for the people in South Australia when he reformed the lower house vote and did away with probably one of the better gerrymanders in this country.

It is also interesting to note that when Don Dunstan was Premier he raised and won the issue for reform of the upper house in South Australia after fighting it through the South Australian parliament and in the community. I arrived in South Australia in 1969 and was shocked to discover that, if I did not own a property and I did not have a university degree, I was not entitled to vote in the upper house in South Australia. Fortune has favoured me and I was able to exercise my right to vote, but thousands of women were not.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what party was he from?

—Don Dunstan saw that reform through the upper house in South Australia. One of the things that is very interesting to learn is that people will often say, `This is not an issue that really bites to the heart of the community; they don't care,' but, yes, they do. Time and time again electoral reform has proven to be a very significant issue that enjoys and brings great support for the people proposing it. Certainly, Don Dunstan's name is associated with that electoral reform, and it is to his benefit. As I said, Steele Hall was associated with electoral reform, to his political disadvantage.
—And what party was he from?

—Senator Vanstone, you should stop shouting at me. You should know already—and you do—that I am being very even‐handed here in reporting the truth of those reforms: Steele Hall was the Liberal Premier. He is a different sort of Liberal from a lot of others in this place. Since you have provoked me, Senator—not really, because I am not able to be provoked by you—let me say that I am sure that Senator Minchin is not of the same Liberal Party as Steele Hall. There is some grave doubt about where half the Liberals in South Australia reside. One could recall that at the moment the Liberal Party in South Australia is very publicly divided—something like 50 per cent—in its parliament, straight down the middle. It is line ball about who might be Premier next week—it depends on just who has the votes.

SPEECH.PARA: You should be cautious with that interjection, Senator. I would have thought—and if it was not clear, I would like to make it clear—that when I was referring to Steele Hall I was quite clearly acknowledging a Liberal contribution. I do not believe I called Don Dunstan a Labor man but, since you are asking me to put a party ticket on Steele Hall, I will put a party ticket on Premier Don Dunstan.

The point is that electoral reform, which is often argued as not a matter of principal concern to the community, always turns out to be a matter that enjoys considerable community support and subsequent respect. When people argued, as Don Dunstan did, for one vote one value, we wanted some kind of fairness and equity for the people of South Australia in their representative vote for the upper house.

By way of an extensive preamble, that leads to a few other points that I want to make. As I said, I was very pleased to host a `Women and the People's Convention' because of my passionate commitment to building on the vote won for women in 1894 by the marvellous women and a number of significant men—after all, only men in parliament were able to vote for that change and their voting record should be noted. The women of South Australia have history and that campaign on their side and it is important that this convention build on that and that women in 1997 should be equally represented at the people's convention. It is long since past that there is any argument that says that women are not fit to hold public office or represent their views and the views of many people they know.

We have in this bill a proposal to move to non-compulsory voting. This is a very frightening change. I believe that it is a very significant change and a very frightening change because it is asking us to support in this place a significant change to what I think is one of the characteristics of this country. Compulsory voting is Australian. It is how we are. It actually enshrines in effect and in symbol the understanding that everybody is equal in Australia. There is no one vote more important than any other vote. We do not have a hierarchy of votes. We do not say that people who have university degrees have a better vote than people who work on assembly lines or push cars through Mitsubishi, Ford or Holden. We say that everybody in Australia has a vote and every vote is equal to every other vote. That is Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, it's not true in the Senate, of course.
—Any move to change that would change a symbol and a critical, central core part of Australia and what it is to be Australian.
—It's not true in the Senate.
—I believe that the people—
—You keep ignoring that because you don't know how to answer it.

—I believe that the people of Australia would much prefer to have an opportunity in a referendum to make their view clear about their desire for an Australian head of state for Australia. They want that.
—Why don't you answer that?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I would appreciate some assistance so I do not have to keep raising my voice over chronic interjections.
—Order! Senator Vanstone, please.
—Mr Acting Deputy President—
—What are you doing, Senator Vanstone?

—I will, on your instruction, contain myself. I was simply inviting the senator to address herself to whether she thought there was one vote, one value in voting for the Senate around Australia. She refused to do so. But, at your instruction, I will not raise that again.
—I welcome that commitment, but in future when you rise you will wait until you are recognised by the Chair before you speak.

—The point I was making was that compulsory voting or the requirement for every Australian to attend at elections and referenda is Australian. It is part of our character and it represents the fact that we on this side certainly very strongly make no distinction between any one vote and another.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question of compulsion, I do find the coalition remarkably slippery. It seems that it would like to move away from compulsion when it comes to voting. Quite often we hear the commitment of the coalition to opposition to compulsion. I note with interest that it is this same opposition that has just made it compulsory for any child attending child care to be immunised. It is not an option; it is now a compulsion. You will not get child-care assistance unless your child has been immunised. It is not a case of saying, `It's a good thing; let's educate people to immunise'; you must. In particular, I find that curious since that same coalition when in opposition fought me all the way on proposals to make sure that there was quality care provided in child-care centres. The coalition is very slippery in the way it argues about this matter.

The point has been very well made by my colleagues that this legislation does not take into account people who cannot read English, whether they are unsighted or short‐sighted or whether they are not familiar with the English language. I think that is a significant move away from the efforts put in place over the years, particularly by the previous Labor government, to ensure that people did have access to the necessary information so as to be able to exercise their vote.

Today at lunchtime I went out to a rally of the Association of Non-English Speaking Background Women of Australia, ANESBWA. They were actually campaigning by way of protest at the cut of at least $40,000 of their moneys to continue that organisation to assist women of non-English speaking background in this country. There is a nice irony that they have lost their money recently in the budget, we have a rally at lunchtime and I can come in here and say that we are also seeing, as part of a consistency, legislation that is also denying women and men from a non-English speaking background access to easy information to enable them to exercise their vote.

A few years ago I represented Australia at the Southern African Development Coordination Conference, SADCC, as it was known then, in Mozambique. It was very interesting to be in Mozambique at that time and to learn the interest and the enthusiasm with which Mozambique was about to welcome advice from Australia on how to conduct elections. In particular, they were very enthusiastic about the electoral education scheme that Australia had developed—a mobile service in this country that was particularly focused on assisting Aboriginal people.

The mobile service would go to remote and rural communities and ensure, by way of education and time out to talk with people, that Aboriginal people understood their rights and were able to exercise their vote at elections and referenda in this country. It is interesting to note that in the budget before this the $19 million to maintain that service was also removed from the Australian electoral scene. It is interesting and very ironic.

As other countries emerged to a democracy they used to look to Australia for the assistance and the advice that we could offer. We were very pleased to offer that advice, but I find it is terribly sad, and beyond that really, that such a commitment to electoral education is now no longer part of the Australian electoral scene. I welcome Senator Minchin. It is time you turned up to take this in person across the chamber instead of via the benefits of electronic media.

I think much more needs to be said about this. I have made the point that I think compulsory voting is very much part of the Australian character. It is Australian; it is part of our symbol. It is interesting to ask: what sort of country are we and what are our symbols and mechanisms? I was terribly interested to note that Senator McKiernan took some of my lines that I have written right here. We did not speak about this; it is just that great minds think alike. We have a Prime Minister (Mr Howard) who has just gone to the United Kingdom. We have a Prime Minister whose interest in symbols is actually characterised by the opening of the Lord's test, some strawberries and cream on the lawns of Wimbledon, popping in to see Baroness Thatcher, and then visiting the Queen of England. They are unashamedly the symbols of our Prime Minister.

That is where Prime Minister Howard stands. It is way out of step with so many people in Australia. Well over 60 per cent of Australians have indicated that they clearly see that the time has come for this country to move to becoming a republic. They want to do that with some kind of generosity, not by this mean‐spirited, creeping and grudging approach to whether or not Australia will be a republic.

What kind of government do we have when it cannot see the importance of the opportunity of the centenary of Federation—the moment that could be chosen in history to say, `It is in celebrating this 100 years that we choose to acknowledge the change of Australia to becoming a republic.' At the opening of the Olympics, the Prime Minister of the day proudly would be able to announce an Australian head of state to represent Australia and to speak for Australia at the opening of the Olympic Games.

Those opposite who argue the importance of trade with our nearby nations should be sympathetic to the importance those countries place on the emerging pride this nation has in moving toward becoming a republic. It is a grudging bill, Senator Minchin. It is also a very dangerous bill. It is, in the end, un‐Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disappointing that the Senate has before it a bill such as the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill, a bill that is not designed to facilitate establishing the true representative views of the Australian people on the issue of a republic. The bill is a nasty and grubby attempt by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to do everything possible to prevent the process of achieving what the majority of Australians want—an Australian as our head of state.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Senate has before it is a bill that advocates a process that is designed to place as many hurdles and barriers as possible in the way of electing to this constitutional convention people who truly represent Australians' views on the republican issue. It is a bill that will see a majority of delegates who agree with the Prime Minister's narrow agenda and anachronistic views elected and appointed to the convention.

It is a pity that we have this bill before the Senate rather than a bill that would allow for a direct vote by the Australian people on the question of whether or not Australia should be a republic and hence have an Australian as head of state. But, most of all, it is an absolute disgrace that the transition of Australia to a republic has been robbed of the dignity it deserves.

I would first like to focus on the matter of the electoral system that the Prime Minister is advocating in this proposed legislation and the flaws associated with it. I find it ironic that one of the main arguments used by monarchists for maintaining the constitutional monarchy is the old adage `if it ain't broke, don't fix it', yet we have a bill that is not advocating following our normal compulsory attendance voting system in electing delegates to the convention—an electoral system that is proven and has provided for fair and democratic elections in this country since 1924.

So do we have the Prime Minister and anti-republicans calling for use of this electoral system that most definitely ain't broke? No. Instead we have a non‐compulsory postal ballot system being proposed. This electoral system will see the greatest number of Australians disenfranchised from this Constitutional Convention election process. They are going to be cut out of this extremely important process—a process of historic proportions—because the system chosen by the Prime Minister to elect delegates to the convention is designed, quite specifically, to make it difficult for all Australians.

We are going to see a package, probably around the size of the Tax Pack, arrive in the mail—and the rest is up to us. Who are the people who are going to be disenfranchised most? It is going to be the elderly and the frail, the young, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, people in remote areas, people for whom English is a second lan guage, people who have literacy problems and people with disabilities. In fact, this Liberal government is continuing in its normal vein because the people who are going to be disadvantaged and left behind in this process are the Australians who are continually being kicked by the coalition government with all their other policies and budget measures. At least we can say that this government is consistent: consistent at cutting Australians out—out of security, out of protection and out of participation.

The Australian Electoral Commission has already stated that there could be up to two million people who do not even get a postal ballot, merely because they have moved recently and have not updated their address details. This government prove with this bill that they believe in active citizenship only when it is cost effective—at least, that appears to be the excuse they are using this time round.

On the matter of cost, the Australian Electoral Commission is going to have to send these out: a ballot paper, although at this rate most Australians will be lucky if they even get one of those; an envelope to place the completed ballot paper in; an envelope to return to the Australian Electoral Commission; and an information booklet—one assumes and hopes that this will be provided.

All of this, and what does the government base its costings on? Sending out one small, normal sized envelope. So much for credible financial estimates. The government claims that a compulsory attendance ballot for the Constitutional Convention is both cost prohibitive and unnecessary. This rings hollow. As Senator Faulkner outlined earlier, the Australian Labor Party has never believed that the cost of democracy is an issue, nor do we believe it should be one now.

We on this side of the chamber support the use of a compulsory attendance ballot because it is the system that ensures that all Australians get a say. It is a fundamental principle of the Australian electoral system which is now going to be cheapened by the Liberals, merely because they do not have faith in their own convictions on this matter and they are not brave enough to go before the Australian people—before all Australians—and put their argument against the republic. Why is this the case? Because they know that Australians would overwhelmingly support a republican model.

Not only is the Prime Minister doing everything he can to ensure that this Constitutional Convention electoral process is one of disempowerment for Australians; he is also ensuring that it is the pro‐constitutional monarchy voices that are heard above everyone else's. The Australian people will be more than aware of the confidence trick the Prime Minister is trying to play on them, and I am sure they will be unforgiving of him.

The Prime Minister is effectively guaranteeing that the Constitutional Convention will not come up with resolutions supporting a republic, because he is stacking the appointed delegates in favour of the government at a ratio of two to one. Talk about a man who likes working with good odds.

I would also like to mention the issue of gender equity with respect to the Constitutional Convention. This is an issue I have not heard any government members mention. If the Prime Minister is trying to recreate that historic event at the end of the last century where a group of men got together at the Constitutional Convention to decide whether Australia would become a federation or not, he is going about it the right way. There is no commitment by the coalition to ensure that women have proportional representation at this convention. Perhaps there is a point of consistency there as well, given the large number of policy and budget decisions that also have disenfranchised and disempowered women in the Australian community.

We all know that the Prime Minister is yesterday's man. The real problem is that he is trying to make Australia a yesterday's nation. This bill is just another step backwards. Where is the dignity in our transition to a republic? Under this government, there is none, and this bill will go down in history as a slight, as a reflection on the poor quality of this country's Prime Minister and this country's federal Liberal government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make my position clear from the beginning. I want more than just a republic. I want Australia to be a just republic. What we have got from this government in this Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 is a proposal for a constitutional convention which is fundamentally anti-democratic. As Senator McKiernan pointed out earlier this evening, it is clearly not about a people's convention. The bill we are debating tonight is fundamentally in breach of the pre-election commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to involve the Australian people fully in the debate about the Australian republic.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall that the Prime Minister has in the past attacked the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, because it was said that he sought to impose his views on the Australian people about the need for an Australian republic. What we have here though is a Prime Minister who seeks to impose his views by stealth. How does he do it? In his usual weak and sneaky manner. This bill is primarily aimed at making it as difficult as possible for Australians to actually be involved in this debate.

The Prime Minister is quoted in today's press as saying that, as far as he was concerned, the republic issue had gone away. Quite clearly, he is wrong. That is just what he wishes to be the case. This bill quite clearly reflects his wishful thinking.

If you look at the question of the appointments, what you see is that there is quite a blatant bias towards conservatives in this country. Rather than having equal numbers from the various forces represented in this country on such a fundamental issue as the future constitutional make-up of this country, you see a mechanism being put in place which will ensure the domination of this convention by conservative coalition delegates. In terms of the appointed persons, under this proposal you would see 25 coalition delegates, 13 Labor delegates and two delegates from the minor parties or the Independ ents—and one of those Independents would be drawn from a hat. What a joke.

BREAK.PARA: The appointment of the non-parliamentary delegates equally is a joke. No-one knows who has been asked to nominate. No-one knows what criteria are being used to allow the Prime Minister to make his judgment on who he regards as appropriate. People have been asked to decide tickets of candidates for the election not knowing who is actually going to be appointed. The Prime Minister is trying to keep groups such as the Australian republican movement in the dark for as long as possible. He is trying to make things as hard as possible, and of course what he is trying to do through this bill is to extenuate that process.

The election process contained in this bill is also a joke. A system has been designed that will clearly disenfranchise, in my view, quite possibly the majority of people. It is designed to be voluntary, which of course is completely at odds with the way we vote for everything else within the government system of this country. It sends an implicit message that the government does not regard this event as particularly important. It seeks to denigrate it. It seeks to delegitimise the whole process.

By also seeking to establish postal voting, the system seeks to disadvantage the homeless. It seeks to disadvantage those who move regularly. It disadvantages renters. It disadvantages students. It especially disadvantages young people and it especially disadvantages a group in the community who are known to be supportive of the republic.

Various estimates by the Electoral Commission have demonstrated that over a million Australians move every year, and it is likely that up to a million people will not actually be on the rolls at their correct address. If we look at the situation in recent council elections in Victoria, we see quite clearly the likely consequences of such a proposition, because this is the model the undemocratic government in Victoria seeks to adopt for local government.

In the elections in Monash, based on the state electorate of Oakleigh and the suburbs of Oakleigh, 119,118 voters were enrolled for the Monash Council elections, of which 74 per cent actually voted; that is, 88,000 voters. In various wards the rate of return fluctuated between 67 and 77 per cent. Over 3,000 ballot papers were returned with the voting packs marked `return to sender' because of the inaccuracies in the voters roll.
