An unknown number of voters were admitted to the ballot after ballot papers were completed and declaration slips were signed by people other than the intended voters. Signatures on the declaration slips were only checked to the extent that the right name had been signed. Or, if ineligible, actual voter signatures were not checked at all. Of the unknown numbers of ineligible voters no longer residents or ratepayers in Monash, we cannot tell how many actually participated in the ballot.

A further 3,000 ballot papers were excluded from the count by the returning officer because of their late arrival or because of mistakes by voters in completing the bureaucratic procedures associated with the ballot. The largest incidence of voter exclusion was where a group of voters forgot to sign the declaration slip or removed it themselves or inserted it in the ballot paper envelope after sealing it.

There was also a very high incidence of family members signing the wrong declarations; that is, husbands signing their wives' declarations and vice versa. Voters who had a signature incorporating a different surname from that appearing on the voters roll, such as those who were newly married or separated women, also had their votes excluded where that difference was detected. Where the signature was illegible, the voter was excluded from the count. It is quite clear, from the assessments of those who are reviewing this matter and the residents groups in Oakleigh, that the blind, disabled and elderly who had someone complete their declaration slips on their behalf had their votes excluded where the signatures did not seem to fit the voter's name.

There was a pattern emerging from the election, where there were confusion errors and where there were allegations of fraud in regard to the number of voters excluded from the election. It made the whole ballot within that electorate, according to the assessments of community groups in the district, subject to challenge. It is quite clearly indicative of how unacceptable that model of voting is for government elections.

The nature of the particular balloting system that is being proposed and the particular ballot papers in question is quite confusing. One would have to ask whether or not it has been designed to produce exactly that result, because it is quite clear to me that, in any examination of these ballot papers, they would maximise informal votes. While it might look like a Senate ballot paper, it quite clearly is not. The rules are not the same as for a Senate ballot paper.

There is quite clearly a question here about the capacity to rort this balloting system. A complex method of filling out and returning maximises the chances, in terms of the ballot, for an increase in the informal vote, even for those who are actually committed to voting in such an election.

Some 2.5 million Australians, as I understand it, come from non‐English speaking backgrounds. It strikes me that those people for whom English is not their first language are quite clearly disadvantaged by this system of voting, particularly as there will be no translations of the material. It further disadvantages a significant group of people who are known to be strongly supportive of the need to have an Australian republic.

The other argument that is put is the question of cost. As Senator Faulkner pointed out earlier this evening, the cost of democracy has never been an issue in this country before. So why is it now? Why is it now a question of the cost of democracy? As far as I am concerned this is yet another miserable and pathetic effort by the apologists for the royalist position in this country to actually try to subvert what is quite clearly the majority will of the Australian people on this issue.

People indicate that the government is clearly following a minority position on these questions. This is despite the fact that the government promised it would give the Australian people full involvement in the processes leading up to the formation of an Australian republic. The government has rejected the simple concept of a plebiscite on whether Australians want an Australian as their head of state. Yet that is the fairest way of directly involving the Australian people in such a basic proposition. I believe it is because the government of this country knows what the answer would be to such a simple proposition as that. People would overwhelmingly say `yes' to that question. It would not be possible, under those circumstances, for the government to rort the system in terms of the expression of the Australian people's will. This is the sort of question we should be discussing: what is the mechanism by which Australians can best express their will?

The Australian people deserve a lot better. This country deserves a lot better than it is getting from this particular bill. The Australian Labor Party's amendments to this bill are designed to improve people's capacity to actually participate—to give Australians a fair go in deciding such an important issue. We want everyone to have a say. We want to be able to give everyone a chance to think about the issues. We are encouraging people to actually participate in such a fundamental question as this. Instead of showing people leadership on such a basic question, what you see is this Prime Minister wimping it yet again, as he has done on Wik, on the stolen children, on jobs and on industry policy. He would like to bury the issue but we are not going to allow that to occur.

It is important that the Senate also makes sure that the Prime Minister does not get away with such a blatant attempt to bury such an important issue. He should be held accountable. He should be held to the promise that he made to the Australian people to involve all Australians in the process of this convention and to genuinely make it a people's convention.

That means that we should have a proper election for candidates. We should not allow the rorting of the system to go on in the way that it is proposed in this bill. We should be seeking to ensure that there is a genuine capacity for people to participate and have their say in the sort of country that they are to inherit. We all have a real interest in this proposition. As far as we are concerned, the proposed method to select candidates to the Constitutional Convention should be condemned. This process is quite clearly aimed at undermining the credibility and the potential usefulness of the convention itself.

Our particular concerns go to the issue of the method of selection of the parliamentary representatives which gives an unfair advantage to coalition parties. There is a lack of an open, transparent and representative process in the way in which other appointments will be made. The method of election of elected delegates should be fundamentally reviewed. A voluntary system involving direct elections should be proposed. Otherwise, the proposal by this government—what is essentially a voluntary and postal system—will effectively disenfranchise a large section of the population, particularly those who have moved in recent years. It will also ensure that persons from a non‐English speaking background, the poorest and the less literate sections of our community, will be disadvantaged.

The proposal being voiced by this government is quite clearly a political experiment for the broader application to the Australian electoral system. It is a system that Senator Minchin has championed. Mr Georgiou in Victoria—from the same party—has indicated that it is a mistaken view adopted by Senator Minchin. It is rare that I agree with Mr Georgiou, but on this occasion I do.

Senator Minchin, your proposals and those of your Prime Minister, are fundamentally elitist and undemocratic, and it is disingenuous and discriminatory for you to suggest that other actions should be taken. Your proposal is designed to minimise the level of political participation in this country—not to maximise it. It is designed fundamentally for you to gain narrow political advantage as you perceive it in the short term and to disadvantage the rest of this country. What is being proposed is a form of ballot paper which, as far as I am concerned, is unnecessarily complex and constitutes a major disincentive to voting. It is aimed to further disadvantage people who have difficulties with both language and literacy.
We are suggesting that the government ought to adopt a genuine Senate style of voting. We are the first to admit that the Senate has its limitations. But it is a far better system of voting.

TALK.START.PARA: —There's more of us than you. It's very democratic.
—Well, it is quite clear, Senator Minchin, in terms of the state that you represent and the state that I represent, that I am here representing a far greater number of people than you are.
—What about Senator Cook and Senator Murphy as well?

—You make the point that Senator Murphy is here. I have made the point on many occasions. The system of voting for the Senate is not perfect, but it has a far greater equity than the proposal that you are seeking to introduce here to rort the system for your narrow political and ideological advantage, as you perceive it at the moment.

BREAK.PARA: The proposed voting system that we are suggesting would ensure a much higher level of public participation and a much higher level of genuine legitimacy to the process. We say that the electoral system should involve the Australian people to the highest level possible. By and large, I think the Australian electoral system is by international standards far better than I have seen in most other places. It does allow for a much fairer and freer system of election than in other countries.

What you are proposing is to dilute the legitimacy of the electoral system in this country, to undermine its authority and its legitimacy. You should be condemned for that. What we are saying is that compulsory voting is a minimum requirement for active citizenship in this country. It is not much to ask of people to actually vote, and to ensure that they do, so that we do get representative government and a representative decision making process in this country. This is the system of voting that we adopt in all other levels of government; the system that has been tried throughout this country for a very great period of time. It has stood the test of time.

What you are suggesting, for your narrow political advantage as you see it, is that the poor and the dispossessed—the disadvantaged in our society—be discouraged from entering the political system. So we would have a situation like in America where those that most need government and the political system to act on their behalf are least encouraged to participate. The political system in the United States, as a consequence of that, is aimed at directly assisting those already with wealth and power and privilege. What you are seeking is an electoral system to be introduced more broadly, using this as a model, which you believe would see your constituency advantaged to the detriment of ours. We say that we will not stand for that. We say that we stand here for all Australians, but particularly those who need government the most—not your people, who need government the least. That is what is fundamentally at stake here in terms of the ideological divide on this question.

We are suggesting that there needs to be a genuine process through the Senate to ensure full participation in this debate. I hope that the Senate will look favourably upon the amendments moved by Senator Bolkus. I trust that they will. The Senate should stand up to the government on this basic question. I trust that the bill from Senator Minchin and the Prime Minister will be defeated.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being nearly 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a welcome opportunity this evening to expose the hysteria being deceitfully fabricated by individuals who are motivated by the jaundiced views against the Lyons Forum. For some time now, a ludicrous and dishonest campaign has been run, especially by some of my friends in the media. The allegations and conspiracy theories would make McCarthyites blush and would be laughable if they were not peddled as though there were some actual rigour to them.

BREAK.PARA: What is the Lyons Forum? The Lyons Forum is named after Prime Minister Joseph and Dame Enid Lyons. By the vote of their fellow citizens, Joe Lyons reached the pinnacle of public life for men and Enid Lyons what so far had been the pinnacle for women. Joe Lyons was the only Australian to be both Premier of his state—namely, Tasmania—and Prime Minister of the Commonwealth. Enid Lyons became the first woman member of the House of Representatives and the first woman to be a federal minister of the Crown.

Joe and Enid had 12 children and the principle of family unity, love and loyalty that is involved in a family unit was very dear to both of them. It pervaded the whole of their private and public life. The family values they exhibited to the nation provide a role model for families in the future. In her maiden speech Dame Enid said:
The foundation of a Nation's greatness is in the homes of its people.

That is the Lyons Forum motto. The Lyons Forum is a group of coalition members and senators who believe that families are important for the nation. It was formed to initiate and monitor legislation with respect to its influence and effect on the family unit. It has four fundamental beliefs. The first one is:
Members of the Lyons Forum believe that the family is the fundamental unit of society and is the prime agency for the total development of children.
Senator Murphy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Somehow that attracts interjections from the opposition. In the report Bringing Them Home , the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission quotes Byler with approval when he says:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the family is the most fundamental economic, education, health care unit in society and the centre of an individual's emotional life . . .

Let us turn to the Convention on the Rights of the Child, of which, I have to say, I am somewhat critical, but which the Left wing upholds in this country as though it is some great document. What does this document tell us about family life? It is:

Convinced that the family, as the fundamental group of society and the natural environment for the growth and well‐being of all its members and particularly children, should be afforded the necessary protection and assistance so that it can fully assume its responsibilities within the community.
It goes on to say:
Recognising that the child, for the full and harmonious development of his or her personality, should grow up in a family environment, in an atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding.
So that is the first point of the Lyons Forum's beliefs. The second one is:
We believe marriage is the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life . . .
That has attracted some ridicule.
Senator Neal interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to comment on Senator Neal's interjection. Do you know where that wording is from? It is directly out of the Family Law Act, introduced into this place by your hero Senator Lionel Murphy. Section 43(a) of the Family Law Act says, there is:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as—
wait for it—
the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life.
So it is hardly something that the Lyons Forum thought up overnight. It is in the Family Law Act of this country. The beliefs of the forum go on to say that we believe the family unit:
. . . provides the environment in which nurturing of children can best be undertaken.
The Convention on the Rights of the Child clearly acknowledges that. The third belief is:
We believe the well being of the family is essential to the stability, morale, security and prosperity of the Australian nation.

If the first two points are accepted, as they are by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, by the Convention on the Rights of the Child and by sections in the Family Law Act, I think the third point that the Lyons Forum believes in stands on its own. The fourth and final point is:
We believe that Government through its activities should promote the family as the fundamental unit of society.
The Convention on the Rights of the Child tells us that the family unit:
. . . should be afforded the necessary protection and assistance so that it can fully assume its responsibilities within the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. I came down to the chamber because I heard the senator say that Joseph Lyons was the father of 12 children. He only had 11 children in his family. If the senator is implying anything improper about children outside their marriage, he should withdraw it.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—One died, you fool.
—Senator Abetz—

—I withdraw that, Madam President. The Lyons Forum is the organisation that has been labelled somehow as sinister, secretive and extreme. It has been labelled as sinister and secretive because it does not disclose its membership publicly.

BREAK.PARA: I am a member of Rotary International. I am a member of the Liberal Party. I am a member of the RSPCA. None of those organisations disclose their membership publicly and, might I add, nor does the trade union movement in this country, nor does the Australian Labor Party, nor do the Australian Democrats. By the same analysis, they are somehow sinister, somehow secretive. But, of course, the most galling thing of all is that all these journalists who write these things and promote these things on the airwaves, I am sure, are members of the Australian Journalists Association, which similarly does not publicly disclose which of its number are actually members of that association.

I would have thought that anybody concerned about today's society, if we have a look at the statistics on drugs, if we have a look at the statistics on suicide, if we have a look at the statistics on antisocial behaviour amongst the youth of this nation, would know that there is, very unfortunately, a common thread that is often found—that is, a dysfunctional family background. That is very, very sad. Therefore, we in the Lyons Forum say that if we can somehow arrange or assist families not to become dysfunctional, the youth of this country would be so much better off.

There have been some astounding assertions made, for instance, that the organisation is patriarchal. There is a female member on the executive, a superb female member, the honourable member for Lilley, Elizabeth Grace. She is a fantastic member who, I am sure, will continue to serve the people of Lilley very well.

Then they tell us that none of the members of the forum are divorced. That is also wrong. I happen to know of a member in the forum who is divorced and has remarried a woman who was divorced and had a child from the previous marriage. That assertion is completely untrue. When those sorts of facts are pointed out to the journalist concerned, do we get an apology? None whatsoever. So, once again, we have this misinformation. Within the Lyons Forum, we have married people, divorced people and remarried people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Single people!

—And single people, as Senator O'Chee kindly reminds me. So we cross the whole spectrum of society. To try to paint us as a narrow group within society is unfair, is unsustainable on the facts and is, I have to say, something which I deeply regret.

BREAK.PARA: In conclusion, I do not in any way apologise for noting in my first speech—and might I add that I did this before I actually knew of the existence of the Lyons Forum—Dame Enid Lyons' words:
The foundation of a nation's greatness is in the homes of its people.

I said that in my first speech, quoted it, attributed it to Dame Enid Lyons and I stand here unapologetic for the fact that I believe that our nation would do very well to be more concerned about its families and the family unit. I simply ask those within the media who want to pedal their jaundiced views: attack us but use facts that are sustainable and not mistruths which are clearly untrue and unsustainable. I for one, along with many others in the coalition, are very proud to stand and be publicly identified as a member of the Lyons Forum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some in our community who are superstitious about the 13th of the month falling on a Friday. That was the case last Friday. There were some people who were particularly unlucky on that day. But I would suggest that the majority of Australians were very lucky. I want to elaborate on that point and draw attention to reports in Saturday's newspapers and exemplify the point of those who were unlucky. The West Australian had a headline on page 11 which read `Rapist must go: Ruddock' and the Weekend Australian had this headline on page 3 `Ruddock to deport rapist, swindler'.

SPEECH.PARA: Anybody who cares about a free, open and fair immigration system for this country and those who are concerned about our refugee and humanitarian programs would be aware of the very good decision of the High Court of Australia in the matter of Mr Guo Wei Rong and Mrs Pan Run Juan. It is the latter on which I want to concentrate, but I am particularly pleased to record Minister Ruddock's decision with regard to the rapist in Perth. That was causing a great deal of consternation amongst constituents of mine in Western Australia who made contact with my office. I recognise that decision.

But the decision I particularly want to recognise is that of the High Court of Australia in the matter of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) against Mr Guo Wei Rong and Mrs Pan Run Juan. I want to concentrate my effort here tonight on Mr Guo. He has led a very chequered career which brought him to the attention of the authorities way back in 1985 when he was apprehended in Hong Kong and fined for smuggling a boatload of people, human beings, into Hong Kong. We do not know how many trips he had made smuggling these people in before he was apprehended, but the apprehension and the fine did not deter him because the very next year he was at it again. He was apprehended again and sent back to China where he was sentenced to two years in a labour camp in China for his illegal activities.

BREAK.PARA: It is important to digress for a moment to note that today we see in our newspapers photographs of the gates of the Whitehead detention centre in Hong Kong closing. I went to that place some years ago as part of my parliamentary studies and witnessed some 6,000 people being detained there in conditions that were not very pleasant for the individuals and that were certainly not very pleasant for somebody to look upon how human beings were living there. I am very pleased that the Whitehead camp in Hong Kong has closed. That blight of boat people in detention on our society has very nearly been brought to an end in that part of the world.

Let us get back to Mr Guo. He served his apprenticeship in shipping people illegally into Hong Kong—to whatever fate is something others have to address. But Australia was to get a taste of him. In April 1992, he, his wife and one of his two children—and that is important to remember—arrived illegally in Darwin on a boat named the Jeremiah. There were 10 other people on that boat. He and the rest of the people on the boat applied for refugee status in Australia, but he was rejected after a departmental review of his application. He did not accept this decision willingly and participated very publicly in a demonstration with others on the roof of the buildings of the Port Hedland detention centre. They received quite an enormous amount of publicity for that protest and some of the people actually hurt themselves pretty badly when they jumped off, but not Mr Guo.

He appealed the earlier rejected decision to the Refugee Review Tribunal, but in September 1992 that was rejected as well. In October 1992, he was forced by the minister of the day to leave Australia. In October 1993, a year after he left Australia, the couple's third child was born. I said earlier that it was important to recognise the number of children because we do hear quite a deal of claims made by people about China's one child policy. Here was a person who fled China after having two children—he left one behind—who was returned to China, had a third child and then fled again.

They came to Australia on this occasion on a boat named the Quokka, which was carrying 24 people. It landed in Broome in Western Australia in December 1993, where they again applied for refugee status in this country. That application was rejected but, in accordance with Australia's laws, they appealed against that decision to the independent review body. In May 1994, their appeal was rejected. That was the fourth occasion that their claims for refugee status and their applications for protection visas in Australia were assessed and rejected.

But Mr Guo was a determined man, and he had quite a deal of support in his applications. He and his lawyers trotted off to the Federal Court of Australia. They made an application to try to overturn the review decision. The application was duly heard, again in accordance with Australia's laws. Mr Justice Sackville dismissed the application in May 1995. Five: nil. The application was rejected on five separate occasions.

As I said, Mr Guo was determined. He—and the lawyers who were providing benevolent service to him free of charge—then took the case to the full court of the Federal Court of Australia. On 26 February 1996, in a landmark decision, Justices Beaumont, Einfeld and Foster handed down—in their wisdom—a decision which overturned all the laws that this parliament was making and had made in regard to the determination of refugee decisions in Australia. In short—it was quite a lengthy decision by their honours—they determined that they had the right to determine who was a refugee and who was not, despite what this parliament had said.

Timing was important in this. Although it was during the hiatus period of an election, the minister of the day decided to appeal against the decision to the highest court in the land: the High Court of Australia. Last Friday, the High Court, with their honours Chief Justice Brennan and Justices Dawson, Toohey, Gaudron, McHugh, Gummow and Kirby, handed down a unanimous decision overturning the decision of the full court of the Federal Court of Australia. I certainly welcomed that decision—so much so that yester day I gave notice of a motion I wanted to move in this place.

Today I asked for formality for that motion, which I thought was a relatively simple motion. It was in four parts. The first part noted the High Court decision, the second part called on Mr Guo and Mrs Pan to accept the decision. The third part suggested that they make their own plans to immediately leave Australia. The fourth part called on the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) to set in motion whatever lawful procedures were available to him to effect their removal if the individuals did not do that themselves. The matter was not declared formal, and hence tonight I am putting my reasons for putting the notice of motion.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Newcastle Youth Forum University of Newcastle

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to talk about a recent trip I made to Newcastle and some of the discussions I had with young people in Newcastle—in particular, with students who were feeling the effects of budget cuts to the University of Newcastle.

SPEECH.PARA: I arrived in Newcastle the weekend before last, at a time when there was quite a degree of upheaval. The papers had been dominated by issues such as the BHP pull out—the closure of the steelworks in that region and the consequent job losses over the next two years. On a happier note, I was there at a time when two conferences geared towards issues of environmentalism and sustainability were taking place.

I was proud to take part in a youth forum organised by youth workers, social workers and charity workers in the region. It was at a place called the Ark, which happens to be the new headquarters of the Salvation Army in that region. I also attended a place called the Pod, which is a public place funded by youth—with no government assistance, I might add. It is full of computers, and facilities for young people to take refuge, talk or have a place of their own.

BREAK.PARA: It is worth noting that the level of youth unemployment in Newcastle is higher than the national average. The rate of youth suicide, specifically for younger males in the central coast region, is amongst the highest in the industrialised world. I certainly got the impression from many young people in the area that they felt they faced quite an uncertain future as a result of the BHP closure. Many of them were worried about job opportunities for themselves and their families and were equally concerned about access to education and training facilities and the opportunities for them and their families to be involved in reskilling and skill development in the future.

Many of these young people made clear to me that they felt that their city could make the transition from being a steel city to being a smart city, but they acknowledged that it requires a gutsy government that is prepared to invest in long‐term future sustainable industries. That means putting money into areas like education, research and environmentally sustainable fields. In fact, I think these days more people are employed in the education sector in that city than in the BHP steelworks.

I mentioned that while I was in town the Pathways to Sustainability Conference was happening. The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) was a guest at that conference. He had to face many protesters who were, understandably, lamenting this government's record on issues such as greenhouse gases and other environmental issues.

The conference tied into young people's view of a green, high‐tech future for the city of Newcastle. They feel that the future of Newcastle entails more than simply mines and vines; it entails high‐tech, sustainable and information based industries of the future. I was also impressed by plans for an—at this stage—environmentally friendly waterfront development. As I understand it, it is funded primarily from better cities funding. Understandably, the people of that region are very concerned as to whether or not that development—and the consequent employment opportunities—will go ahead, given the changes to funding arrangements involving better cities projects.

But I return to education, because this seemed to be an issue that recurred in my discussions. Contrary to suggestions made by the minister today that institutions, higher education institutions in particular, in remote or regional areas—I might add that the University of Newcastle is quite a large institution—are being well looked after and strengthened, I would like to point out some of the changes that have taken place at the University of Newcastle as a consequence of budget measures.

They have lost 40 general staff from the Finance and Property Division; 40 general staff have been shed from the University Secretary and Registrar; in the Faculty of Architecture, the budget has been slashed by $250,000, two academic staff have gone, there are no funds to repair equipment that is badly in need of repair; in the Faculty of Art and Design, the budget cuts have taken away $720,000 and nine academic staff, contact hours have been reduced and many of the consumables and supplies are now available on a user pays basis.

The Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences have lost over $1 million, six academic staff, eight general staff, and they have had a reduction in support staff as well; the Faculty of Economics and Commerce have lost $666,000 and 15 academic staff, three general staff members will also be lost; the Faculty of Engineering have targeted savings of over $1 million with 11 academic staff and 20 general staff due to lose their jobs; the Faculty of Law is due to lose around $200,000 as well as four academic staff.

The Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences will lose over $2 million and 14 academic staff and 30 general staff are due to go; the Faculty of Music will lose over $200,000, two academic staff and four general staff; the Faculty of Nursing, $340,000 will go, six academic staff and three general staff; the Faculty of Professional Education has a targeted savings of around $150,000, one academic staff member and one general staff member, the research is $20,000 down; and the Faculty of Science and Mathematics have targeted savings of, I believe, around $1 million with 18 academic staff and 13 general staff to go. The total number of academic staff made redundant is around 95. The total number of general staff made redundant is around 198 at this stage.

The university may have less staff but, of course, as the minister insists, enrolments have been maintained. Accordingly, class sizes have jumped, student contact hours have been reduced, tutorial times of course have been reduced as well. The library has cut its budget by around $900,000 and it is proposed that something like 21 library staff will also be shed. I think they are quite startling figures. They certainly give a local and very specific perspective of the kinds of job losses and the impact on quality as a result of budget changes over the life of this government.

I also note the government's claims that it has enhanced opportunities for young Australians in regions such as Newcastle, and across the board. I cannot help but mention the proposed common youth allowance—the announcement made by Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security, earlier today. We will see people who are not employed, people who are not engaged in education or training, those who are not studying, under the age of 18, lose their benefits.

Earlier tonight, Senator Abetz got up to talk about families and how they must be adequately looked after and resourced. What this government has just done to Australian families with the CYA—the common youth allowance—is absolutely shameful. It is all very well to tout families as being places of safety and security, but how can you really misread the economic reality? Consider the economic situation of families today, struggling in many cases with one or even two parents out of work, and now they have this further burden to endure of young people who are under 18, who are not employed, who are not in educational training, being deprived of any kind of benefits.

While I listened to Senator Abetz's speech regarding the Lyons forum, I have to say that, while I acknowledge families can be heaven on earth at times, they can also be places of absolute terror and destitution for some people. If we talk about protecting young people in Newcastle or anywhere else in this nation, we have to ensure that families and family environments are safe, that they are adequately resourced, that they have money, that they have access to employment, and that they have ways and means to get out of poverty.

The young people that I met at the Ark and at the Pod in Newcastle shared these concerns. They talked about issues of sexual abuse and drug abuse at home and homelessness. They talked about those young people who could not access benefits, such as homeless benefits, because they did not know what rights they had or what benefits they could access. In fact, sometimes they were victims of their own resourcefulness, because they found ways of finding a day here or a night there where they could stay with friends or families or kind strangers and charity workers who would take them in. But those hidden homeless statistics are rarely taken into account by governments and by welfare systems.

We know that poverty is intimately linked with unemployment. I think the youth unemployment figures released this month are a sad reminder of the fact that youth unemployment is at crisis point around this nation and, particularly, in Newcastle. Finally, I would like to thank those people of Newcastle for their hospitality and I look forward to returning to update those young people on what has been happening in these decision making bodies and others around the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to place on public record the extent of the jobs crisis facing the people of Bowen. It is interesting that I am following Senator Stott Despoja, because I will be referring to the comparability between the situation in Newcastle and the situation in Bowen. But before speaking, I would like to thank my colleague Senator Ian Macdonald, who deferred his place on the speakers' list so that I do not have to speak at 100 miles an hour. Thank you, Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is appropriate that I should be speaking in these circumstances, because it gives me the opportunity to say that I do believe there is, in regard to the crisis in Bowen, a cross‐party approach. I would like to just recognise the work that the local member, De-Anne Kelly, has already done in lobbying ministers of the government to recognise the extent of the crisis. I refer to a press release in the Bowen Independent on 28 May, `Kelly lobbies ministers on Bowen's future.' The local member has already indicated her concern and approached ministers.

Equally, the Labor state opposition has been to Bowen and has made strenuous representations to state government ministers about the need for a rescue package. They have also had discussions with the council and clearly they are equally as concerned as the local member.

Many senators would not know very much about Bowen. It is a small seaside community. It has traditionally had an employment base largely connected with the meatworks at Merinda, some primary industry and some tourism. The plight of meatworkers from the Thomas Borthwick and Sons Merinda works has been highlighted in recent months. The meatworkers were four months into a 12 months agreement—registered with the Industrial Relations Commission last September—when the management called the agreement off, just like that, and put forward another one, a non‐negotiable agreement in which the workers would have to work longer than 40 hours per week for less than the award wage. For some this pay cut equalled up to $150 per week.

Naturally the meatworkers refused to agree to this and Thomas Borthwick and Sons, owned by Nippon Meat Packers of Tokyo, have said that the Merinda works will not be reopened. Moreover, they have gone on to say that the buildings will be demolished, which seems to be an extraordinary waste of a very appropriate facility. I know that a number of people in the community would like to see a feasibility study of whether or not a community cooperative with an interest‐free loan from state and federal government could reopen the meatworks. There has also been talk of the building being listed as part of the national heritage, that it would be absolutely criminal to bring the building down.

While Bowen is a small community and does not have the big numbers of Newcastle, the extent of job loss is indicated in these figures which I would like to table. These figures highlight the problem in Bowen because there has been an increase in the registered unemployment benefit recipients of some 286 between November last year and May this year and some figures that I obtained while I was in Bowen last week indicate that the figures now could have increased to 1,275. Whether we look at those figures—the official figures—or whether we rely on the word of mouth figures, which I am sure have considerable reliability, we are looking at between a 44 per cent and a 50 per cent increase. That is way ahead of even the highest in Queensland which is Rockhampton and Ingham at around 35 to 36 per cent in the six months. So clearly Bowen does have an enormous problem.

When BHP announced the 2,000 job losses in Newcastle within the next two years, an instant response from federal and state governments and a $20 million rescue package was announced within a matter of a few weeks. I commend the federal government on its prompt response to that situation, although I note that that will be a crisis in two years time. I do not begrudge Newcastle having that assistance. It is very much needed. But the crisis in Bowen is now. The jobs have gone, 1,275 are on the DSS unemployment lists and we have still to hear from federal government. I know people in state parliament were hoping that there would be something in the Queensland budget and unfortunately there was not. Clearly, there has to be some immediate, urgent action.

I have joined De‐Anne Kelly in writing to a number of ministers—Minister Vanstone, Minister Moore, Minister Anderson and indeed the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—putting these four points that were highlighted to me last week. One related to the meatworks. I have already talked about how many members of the community were interested in establishing a community cooperative, if that is a viable option. Obviously some form of feasibility study would have to be done and that would have to be done speedily, because we need urgent responses. There are primary industry and tourism opportunities in the region thatcould be enhanced if relevant federal and state departments offered professional advice and some strategic financial incentives.

Thirdly, Bowen should be in receipt of an immediate grant of assistance under the assistance for depressed regions program. I note from the budget papers that there is something like $20 million in that program. I am sure that, under any criteria, Bowen would have to qualify. Finally, the council and the community are not just sitting back waiting for government to respond. They are taking their own action. There is talk of establishing a Bowen's future think‐tank, which would meet in the next month and work with federal and state governments and the community to start to develop a practical course of action to plan options for job regeneration both immediately and in the future.

There is nothing more depressing than talking with people who feel that the world has gone by without giving them due care and consideration. Certainly there are many people in Bowen who just wonder whether federal and state governments realise where Bowen is on the map. I am sure that, with the efforts of cross‐party support, we will get some urgent action on a scale comparable to that in Newcastle. It is equal to the crisis that faces Newcastle, with BHP withdrawing so many jobs. The difference is that the crisis in Bowen is now. Therefore, it is absolutely essential that the relevant ministers respond immediately and send their representatives to Bowen to sit down with the council and start to talk of both short‐term and long‐term packages to assist this small town.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Do any senators or members own or have any joint‐ownership of, or interest in any pastoral leases; if so: (a) which senators or members; and (b) which leases.

(2) Do any senators or members have shares or other financial interests in any companies which in turn own or have interests in any pastoral leases; if so: (a) which senators or members; and (b) which leases.
(3) Can a list be provided of the names of the people or entities which hold each of the Western Australian pastoral leases.

(4) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 433 dated 17 February 1997, in particular paragraphs 10 to 13 and 15, why is the information sought `not comprehensively documented and, therefore not readily available'.
(5) Does this mean that the Western Australian Government does not know which lessees in Western Australia own multiple pastoral leases, and how many they each hold.

(6) Does the Western Australian Government know which leases in Western Australia are owned by corporate entities for which pastoral leases are just one investment, as opposed to those lessees who own single leases and are in fact owner‐operators.
(7) If the Western Australian Government, or the Commonwealth, does indeed know which lessees in Western Australia own multiple leases, can this information be provided.
(8) If the Western Australian Government, or the Commonwealth, does indeed know which leases in Western Australia are owned by large corporate entities, can this information be provided.

(9) Is the Minister aware of the report on the front page of the West Australian of 1 May 1997, in which it is stated that the Western Australian Government and the Western Australian Pastoral Board, which regulates Western Australian pastoral leases on behalf of the West Australian community, have been aware of ongoing illegal operations on pastoral leases and taken no action to correct those illegal activities; if so, what action is proposed to rectify this situation.
(10) What is the make‐up, constitution and function of the Western Australian Pastoral Board.
(11) Does the Western Australian Pastoral Board have any community, environmental or Aboriginal representation.

(12) Has any economic cost‐benefit analysis been conducted into the pastoral industry which totals up all the direct, indirect and hidden subsidies to the pastoral industry and compares these with the returns to the community from pastoral leases; if so, what were the results of these analyses.
(13) How much rent, in total, does the Western Australian pastoral industry pay to the Western Australian Government each year.
(14) How much is expended annually by the Western Australian Government in: (a) administering; (b) regulating; (c) monitoring; and (d) assisting, the pastoral industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)‐(2) All Members and Senators are required to register their private interests and to regularly update their declarations. These registers are available for public inspection. In addition, Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries are required to provide and regularly update a declaration of their private interests and also to declare any interest which might be affected by their decision in relation to particular issues. As Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, I have no knowledge of declarations by other Ministers and by Parliamentary Secretaries. Should the Honourable Senator wish to obtain information in addition to that which is publicly available about the private interests of Members and Senators, he could approach them directly. They will of course, exercise their judgement in this matter.

(3) The Government of Western Australia is responsible for land management, including pastoral lease administration and the issue of land titles, in that jurisdiction. The information provided in response to parts (3) to (14) of the Honourable Senator's Question has been supplied to the Commonwealth by the Western Australian Department of the Premier and Cabinet.

A list of the names of the people or entities holding Western Australian pastoral leases is available by requesting a copy of the registry printout from the Pastoral Board of Western Australia and on payment of a $40 fee.

(4) The Land Act 1933 (WA) does not require a pastoral lessee to reside on his/her lease. In the absence of a residential clause in pastoral leases, the need to comprehensively tabulate this type of information has not arisen.
(5) No. This information can be extracted from the registry printout mentioned in the answer to part (3).
(7) The information can be extracted from the registry printout mentioned in the answer to part (3).

(8) About 50% of Western Australian pastoral properties (which may consist of one or more pastoral leases) are held by corporate entities. In the absence of definition, it is not possible, however, to specify how many of these might be regarded as "large corporate entities."

(9) Yes. The report referred to was inaccurate and the correct position was presented in a second report published in the West Australian on 2 May 1997. As the activities are referred to are not illegal, no action is proposed.

(10) The Pastoral Board consists of five members who are currently: Mr L M Kelly—Chairman, (former officer of the Department of Land Administration); Dr G A Robertson—Chief Executive, Agriculture Western Australia, ("ex officio" member); Mr J A de Pledge—Pastoralist nominated by the Pastoralist and Graziers Association of WA; Mr D Halleen—Former pastoralist nominated by the WA Farmers Federation; Mr W Rose— A senior manager in the Department of Land Administration.
The Pastoral Board is constituted under Section 98 of The Land Act 1933.

The Board has its genesis in the Board of Appraisers which was established by legislation (Land Act 1898) in 1917. This became the Pastoral Appraisement Board in 1963 and then the Pastoral Board in 1980.
The function of the Pastoral Board is to advise to Minister for Lands in matters relating to Crown land held under pastoral lease pursuant to Part VI of The Land Act 1933. Some of these aspects are:
‐ appraisement of lease rental
‐ rental relief because of droughts, cyclone, fire or flood
‐ adequacy or otherwise of development plans
‐ lease forfeiture
‐ stocking rates
‐ measures for erosion control and land rehabilitation
‐ agistment
‐ cultivation and clearing on pastoral leases
‐ transfer (sale) of pastoral leases.

In general, the Board administers pastoral leases, subject to the Minister, to ensure the land is managed and worked according to sound and accepted methods and that usage is directed to the conservation and regeneration of pastures.
(11) The representation of Board members is given in the answer to part (10).
(14)Pastoral Board costs for 1996/97 are estimated to be $156,000.
In addition, Agriculture Western Australia estimates it will spend $10.3M on programs related to the pastoral sector of the State's agricultural industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 7 May-1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Sugar Industry Infrastructure Package (SIIP) which is partially-funded by the Federal Government is resulting in the destruction of tens of thousands of hectares of coastal wetland habitat in north Queensland.
(2) Is the Minister aware that, in some cases, extensive works relating to the SIIP have commenced prior to the completion of the joint Commonwealth/State Environmental Impact Statement.

(3) Is the Minister aware that, in addition to the Federal Government directly funding the destruction of the wetland, the proponent, Queensland Department of Natural Resources, has proposed that the Federal Government should draw funds from either the Wet Tropics Management Authority or the Natural Heritage Trust to attempt to rehabilitate some of the areas lost.
(4) What is the Minister's position on this proposal.

(5) Given that the SIIP involves the destruction, disruption or alteration of areas of fisheries habitat, can the Minister table copies of any independent studies which guarantee there will be no adverse impacts from the SIIP on commercial or recreational fishing

(6) Given that the SIIP involves the destruction, disruption or alteration of areas of endangered species habitat, including that of the mahogany glider, for which the Commonwealth Government has instituted a rescue package program, can the Minister table copies of any independent studies which guarantee there will be no adverse impact from the SIIP on the mahogany glider or any other endangered species.

(7) Given that the SIIP involves the destruction, disruption or alteration of natural drainage patterns in areas adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area, can the Minister table copies of any independent studies which guarantee there will be no adverse impacts on the water quality within the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area.
(8) What is the full level of Commonwealth funding for the SIIP, including actual infrastructure work and remediation
(9) Can the Minister table a map showing the total areas affected by the SIIP, including the breakdown of habitat loss by type.
(10)(a) What other proposals are yet to be assessed under the SIIP; and (b) what are the areas involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cooperative environmental assessment process currently underway between the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments will ensure that any impacts on coastal wetland habitats are minimised. I will examine this assessment carefully in order to ensure, so far as the powers available to me permit, that unacceptable environmental impacts do not occur.

(2) My Department has advised me that no works on any outstanding SIIP projects have been undertaken prior to the completion of the Commonwealth and State Government environmental assessment processes. In relation to the north Queensland projects, three cane rail extensions were approved by the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments as part of Stage l of the Riversdale/Murray Water Management Scheme project and have now been completed. The works were subject to an environmental assessment for Stage 1 of the project and were approved by both Governments in 1995.

(3) and (4) My Department has received advice from the Queensland Department of Natural Resources that it has not applied for funding under the Natural Heritage Trust for any SIIP projects. The Wet Tropics Management Authority also indicate that they are not aware of such a proposal.
(5) My Department has not commissioned any such reports. These issues will be examined as part of the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments' environmental assessment of outstanding SIIP projects.

(6) and (7) My Department has not commissioned any such reports. These issues will be examined as part of the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments environmental assessment of outstanding SIIP projects. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 8 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the 1996 announcement by the Minister of a review of the existing Commonwealth Special Education program:
(1) Has the review been established; if not, when will it be established.

(2) If it has been established; (a) what, if any, are the terms of reference for the review; (b) what guidelines, if any, have been set for the conduct of the review; (c) who is conducting the review; (d) who are the members of the promised consultative group and how were they selected; (e) when and to whom will the review report; and (f) will the report be made available to the public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The review was established in 1996 following the announcement of the review in the 1996‐97 Budget.
(2) (a) The terms of reference for the review are as follows:
‐ investigate the role and responsibility of the Commonwealth in special education and the relationship to State initiatives;
‐ examine the current methods of allocating Commonwealth funding to sectors for special education;
‐ investigate the current mechanism used to allocate funding to students with disabilities;

‐ investigate opportunities for more effective provision of special education services (eg. for specific schools to specialise in the provision of services for students with disabilities from all sectors and for sectors to share resources); and
‐ provide advice on improved or alternative means of the Commonwealth providing financial assistance for students with disabilities.
(2) (b) There have been no guidelines set for the conduct of the review.
(2) (c) The review is being undertaken by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA) and being informed by a consultative group of key stakeholders.

(2) (d) The consultative group is chaired by DEETYA and consists of a member of each of the three education sectors (government, Catholic and independent), a representative from a non‐school organisation providing special education services and a parent representative. The special education service provider and parent representative were nominated by ACROD, a peak interest group in the special education area. Members were drawn from most States and Territories across Australia.
Following is a list of consultative group members:

ROW.ENTRY: Conference of the Education Systems Chief Executive Officers (CESCEO) on behalf of the government sector
CESCEO on behalf of the government sector

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (e) The review will report to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training in September 1997.

(2) (f)The purpose of the review is to inform the Minister. Interested parties will be given the opportunity to comment on any proposed changes to the Commonwealth's arrangements for funding special education.
